review_text: Great game! I have beaten both metro 2033 redux games (the previous ones). I like metro exodus for it's graphics and great story. It does a really nice job to keep your interest in playing it but I got too scared of the mootants so I quit for two months and then continued. I don't recomend it to people that get scared easily.

For me, this game is "A beautiful overrated and incredibly annoying test of patience".

The intro were so effing long I had to go into the game folder and delete those darn three videos and you should do the same if you don't want to spent an hour long watching that shjt when you first start the game.

Slow pace, so much walking. There are literally 10 more badass soldier on the train and I have to do all the work for them, alone, make no sense. And my chick and her sugar daddy keep yelling at each other all the time.

NPCs talk a lot and continuously, and argue endlessly, one person hasn't finished speaking yet and the other has already jumped in and yelling. The English dub is really bad, cringe and tense with a weird accent, I had to switch to Russian dub to listen to it less annoying.

Annoying buzzing sound (on my watch I guess) really drive me crazy!! WTF what that? Idk if it is a bug/glitch or game's feature but I can not stand it any second. F that sheat!

One thing that seemed really cool at first but turned out to be really ridiculous was the sound effects, for example when an NPC was talking, I was standing right in front of them but when I turned the camera left/right/behind I couldn't hear them anymore, it was funny and ridiculous.

Well, based on the "very positive" reviews on steam, the game doesn't seem bad at all, maybe it just isn't for me, after 5 hours I'm lost it and I'm like "fvck that shjt I'm out".

Lethal Company â€” Corporate Horror Meets Co-Op Chaos

Lethal Company throws players into a darkly comedic sci-fi world where you and your crew of unfortunate contractors are sent to abandoned industrial moons to salvage scrap for a ruthless megacorporation. What starts as a simple job quickly spirals into a tense, unpredictable experience as every mission risks becoming your last.

The game shines in its cooperative gameplay and emergent chaos. Working together to explore derelict facilities, avoid traps, and carry loot back to the ship creates constant tensionâ€”especially when creatures begin stalking the halls. Communication, quick thinking, and teamwork determine whether you escape alive or become yet another â€œunfortunate lossâ€ on the company ledger.

The progression loop is simple but addictive. Collect scrap, sell it, buy better gear, and take on more dangerous environments. Each moon offers unique layouts, hazards, and threats, making every run feel fresh. The randomness of enemy encounters and environmental quirks adds to the thrill and unpredictability.

Atmosphere is one of the gameâ€™s biggest strengths. The dim lighting, eerie soundscapes, and unsettling creature designs create an environment thatâ€™s equal parts scary and hilariousâ€”especially when panic sets in and everything falls apart. The blend of horror and humor gives the game a unique charm that keeps players coming back.

Final Verdict:
Lethal Company delivers a perfect mix of tension, teamwork, and unpredictable fun. Whether you're playing seriously or embracing the chaos, itâ€™s an endlessly entertaining co-op experience filled with memorable moments and dark humor.

â€œTerrifying, chaotic, and ridiculously funâ€”clock in, survive, and hope the Company approves.â€

review_text:
A friend recently introduced me to this. The amount of features/achievements and how unlockables seamlessly weave different game elements together is definitely worth the price. As for the primary "Game Worlds," here are my thoughts.

Mini Golf - Solid! Piss off your friends with Collision Mode enabled.
Slaughterday Night Live - I'm not usually one for FPS modes. But the music makes it mildly addictive.
Ball Race - Pretty good Super Monkey Ball mode. But I wish you could jump.
Virus - Again, not an FPS person, but you can cheese this mode in the Minecraft custom map.
Little Crusaders - This is the cutest damn minigame I've ever played in anything ever. Full stop. Dragon ragdoll!!
Zombie Massacre - Also is not my genre, but it's cool that better players can save you if you run out of lives.
Accelerate Kart Racing - Mario Kart but with items themed after some of the other game worlds and workshop kart skins. My kart is Maxwell the cat. I like it.

one of the best story games i played .... anyone might notice some glitches rarely but over all its worth it 9/10

Resident Evil 7: Biohazard marks a bold and terrifying return to the seriesâ€™ survival horror roots. By shifting to a first-person perspective, the game plunges players directly into the claustrophobic and unsettling world of the Baker family, delivering an intensity and immersion rarely seen in horror games.

The atmosphere is pitch-perfect: every creaking floorboard, shadowy hallway, and grotesque detail contributes to a constant sense of dread. The gameâ€™s visuals and sound design are exceptional, combining to make even familiar settings feel deeply menacing.

Gameplay emphasizes survival and careful strategy. Ammo and resources are scarce, forcing players to think before they act and heightening the tension of every encounter. Puzzles and exploration are intelligently designed, rewarding curiosity while maintaining a constant sense of vulnerability.

The story is gripping and horrifying, blending psychological terror with body horror in a way that feels fresh yet unmistakably Resident Evil. The Baker family, particularly Jack Baker, are unforgettable antagonists whose presence keeps players on edge throughout.

Overall, Resident Evil 7: Biohazard revitalizes the franchise with a terrifying, immersive experience that balances horror, story, and gameplay flawlessly. Itâ€™s a must-play for both longtime fans and newcomers seeking a true survival horror thrill.

Rating: 9.5/10

Overall, Resident Evil 7 is a pretty intense ride. Coming from Resident Evil 2 remake, this one definitely hits way harder in the scare department, even if the first-person view makes some of the boss fights feel a bit awkward. The DLCs are a mixed bag, some fun, some not really my thing, but theyâ€™re unique enough to keep things interesting. 

All in all, itâ€™s a solid horror experience thatâ€™s worth checking out.

ğŸŒŸ [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/45575657]Follow Ainsel Reviews - Curator for the weird & lovely[/url][/b] ğŸŒŸ

I didnâ€™t walk into that house to be a hero.
I just wanted her back.
That was my first mistake.

Nothing prepares you for the Bakers. No horror movie, no nightmare, no childhood fear. They donâ€™t just attack you â€” they claim you. Jack speaks to you like youâ€™re already family. Marguerite feeds you like she wants you to rot properly. Lucas watches you break and laughs because he knows heâ€™s already won.

Every time I healed, the pain returned differently.
Every time I lost part of myself, something else grew in its place.
The house learned me.
Room by room. Breath by breath.

And the worst part? A part of me understood it. The mold doesnâ€™t lie. It shows you exactly what youâ€™re made of â€” usually blood, panic, and very bad decisions.

The DLCs feel like the memories I tried hardest to bury. Fragments, regrets, things I didnâ€™t want to relive but kept resurfacing like the swamp water in my lungs. Some offered closure. Some reopened wounds that never had time to close.

I survived.
But survival feels like a technicality.

If you play this â€” and Iâ€™m not saying you should â€” just remember:
That house doesnâ€™t stay where you left it.
It follows.

The scariest thanksgiving game of all time, even after a speedrun I was still scared by some of the events that happens within the game. A lot of secrets to uncover, as well as a good amount of side content as well. Overall, would still recommend it to anyone that wishes to go though with this game during the season of Thanksgiving, and truely be apart of the family.

RE 7 was an incredible journey from start to finish. What struck me the most was the psychological depth of the story. The game doesnâ€™t rely only on jumpscares or gore; instead, it builds an unsettling narrative that slowly gets under your skin. I was fully immersed from the very beginning, and the tension never really let go. Every twist hit at the perfect moment and kept me completely hooked.

The world-building is another major highlight. The environments, small details, and characters all work together to create a story that feels carefully constructed and genuinely thought-provoking. You can feel that every room, note, and encounter has a purpose, and that makes exploring incredibly rewarding.

The DLCs also deserve a mention, they're a must-play. They add great post-game content that feels meaningful rather than just extra filler, and they gave me even more appreciation for the whole game.

If I had to point out one weaker part, it would be the section on the ship. It slows down the pacing and drops a bit of the tension that the game builds so well elsewhere. Itâ€™s not bad, just noticeably less gripping compared to the rest.

Overall, Resident Evil 7 is another excellent entry in the saga. Finishing it at 100% was absolutely worth it, and Iâ€™d highly recommend it to anyone who wants a tense, atmospheric, and memorable horror experience.

Just bought the game after seeing that it got big updates. My friend keep recommending it so I had to try it. Not dissapointed and I can see why they recommend it. 

The main gameplay is you creating this big community where your tribe is thriving and make a living out of what the environment gave you. The tutorial explain very clearly on what to do and I can easily follow it without having a question about what is what. Somehow my community is thriving even only with foods and woods lol they need so little.

I have several question tho, why is the BGM so  little? I almost can't hear it at all. Not just that, I also wonder why there is a new wall decor keep showing on the screen even if the player still doesn't know what it does? I do feel like there are too many unnecessary pop up happening at the start of the game making it confusing for me. And while on that point, I do feel like the way the community gathering resource is a little slow on normal difficulty? I had to plan my community member precisely to get the necessary resource at the start. I do feel like that shouldn't be necessary at the start of the game.

Overall, a really solid game. Can't wait to see and try other maps too. I come back later when I got another time free from work.

I tried this for the first time, and my early experience was pretty good. The atmosphere
is strong and the world feels harsh in a way that fits the game's setting. Building up a settlement,
assigning workers, and trying to keep everything stable kept me engaged.
The Ul takes a bit of time to get used to. Some panels feel bulky, and the resource area can get
crowded once you start unlocking more production buildings. The conveyor system also feels a little
unclear at the moment - I wasn't always sure how much it was actually helping. Upgrading buildings
didn't feel like a big improvement early on, so it was hard to tell when an upgrade was worth it.
Even with those rough edges, I enjoyed the core gameplay loop. Expanding, managing resources, and
dealing with the survival challenges is fun, and there's clearly a strong foundation here. With
continued improvement, this could become a really solid survival city-builder.
Overall, I'd recommend it to players who enjoy colony management and don't mind some early-
access roughness

After a long time away from strategy games, New Cycle reminded me why I love this genre. The dynamic weather is incredibleâ€”especially the snow, which makes the world feel alive and really affects how you plan your city.

Progression feels rewarding, and itâ€™s exciting to unlock new buildings and systems as you go. I didnâ€™t encounter any technical issues, and the game ran smoothly during my play session.

Balancing resources, expanding your settlement, and adapting to changing weather keeps the game exciting and visually impressive. Iâ€™m looking forward to future updates!

Highly recommended ğŸ‘

This game has a very clear tutorial that walks you through how to grow your village without making things confusing. The best part is that you essentially get two modes: a hard Survival Mode (story mode) for a real challenge, and an easier Casual Mode for when you just want to build without the stress of raids or starvation. This flexibility is great. It makes the game easy to recommend if you are new to the genre or just want a more relaxed building experience

The game is simply fantastic. I was genuinely impressed by how much content it already has â€” and this is just the ALPHA version, keep that in mind. The amount of technologies, buildings, and events is more than enough to keep you hooked for hours.

I do think the game could benefit from randomly generated maps, as that would add even more replay value. The tutorial is somewhere between small and medium in size and I actually got so absorbed in the gameplay that I completely forgot to research new technologies. Unfortunately I didnâ€™t get many notifications about it and by the time I realized my mistake, it was already too late - I didnâ€™t have enough resources. I started rushing my research, but I still couldnâ€™t catch up, and eventually the separatists rose against me and I lost my village :D 

Also, it would be amazing to play this game in Ukrainian someday - that would make the experience even more enjoyable for me.

Overall, Iâ€™m left with only positive impressions. Not many strategy games manage to truly grab my attention, but this one did.
Thank you for the game!

New Cycle is a survival-focused city-building strategy game that attempts to merge classic settlement management with the tension of rebuilding civilization after a catastrophic solar event. Developed by Core Engage and published by Daedalic Entertainment, the game imagines a future in which intense solar flares have brought the world to its knees, wiping out infrastructure and scattering humanity into isolated pockets. Your task is to lead one such remnant community from its most fragile early days toward a revitalized industrial society capable of enduring the harsh new reality. The premise is familiar enough for fans of survival builders, but New Cycle approaches it with a broad, systems-driven ambition that aims to capture the slow, methodical rise from improvised shelters to structured industry.

At its foundation, New Cycle offers an extensive management loop that revolves around resource gathering, worker roles, production chains, and technological progression. You begin by establishing basic shelters and securing essential supplies like water, food, and raw materials. As the settlement stabilizes, the complexity deepens: you introduce new professions, research scientific advances, erect specialized buildings, and manage increasingly intricate supply lines. The game presents multiple biomes with distinct challenges, from resource-poor deserts to storm-ridden forests, forcing you to adapt your strategies to the environment. Seasonal cycles and extreme weather eventsâ€”sandstorms, floods, electrical anomaliesâ€”add urgency and unpredictability, pushing you to plan ahead while reacting to sudden setbacks. The rhythm of development feels natural for players who enjoy long-form planning, letting the settlement evolve organically as new eras unlock.

A notable strength of New Cycle is the sense of growth reflected in its visual and atmospheric presentation. Early structures are makeshift and rudimentary, yet as you progress into new eras, your settlement gradually transforms into a more industrialized and organized cityscape. Lighting, weather effects, and environmental detail contribute to the mood of post-collapse rebuilding, emphasizing how fragile your people are compared to the forces around them. Zooming out, you can appreciate the sprawling networks of roads, workshops, farms, and factories that begin to define your settlementâ€™s identity. While the interface is still in need of refinement in some areas, it generally supports the management tasks with clear resource displays and functional menus. The overall tone is one of struggle intertwined with hopeâ€”a world where every advancement feels earned.

Despite these strengths, New Cycleâ€™s early access state means that several aspects of the experience feel unfinished or unbalanced. Some mechanics, such as worker assignment and production optimization, lack the polish or transparency seen in more mature city-builders. Information feedback can occasionally be insufficient: resources may deplete unexpectedly, weather hazards sometimes arrive without enough warning, and certain buildings feel disproportionately essential or inefficient. The pacing can also be uneven, with stretches of slow development followed by abrupt surges in difficulty. Some narrative or decision-based elements, hinted at in the gameâ€™s description, are present but not yet deeply realized, making moral or strategic choices feel more cosmetic than impactful. These issues donâ€™t break the experience, but they serve as reminders that the game is still evolving toward its broader vision.

Another area that may divide players is the tempo of gameplay. New Cycle leans heavily toward slow, incremental progress, echoing the grind and patience required to rebuild from scratch. For some, this creates an absorbing, meditative challenge, but others may find the pace too sluggishâ€”especially when waiting for complex production chains to stabilize or for research projects to unlock. While the game includes systems for accelerating time, the inherent density of tasks and the need to react to disruptions can make the process feel drawn out. Those who thrive on micromanagement and careful long-term planning will likely appreciate the depth, but players seeking faster or more dynamic progression may feel the weight of the gameâ€™s deliberate pacing.

Even with its early access limitations, New Cycle presents itself as a thoughtful and promising entry in the survival city-building genre. It offers a compelling foundation built on resource scarcity, environmental volatility, and the satisfaction of constructing a self-sustaining society in a damaged world. Its visual atmosphere, layered systems, and sense of gradual progress create a strong framework for future updates and expansions. The game is clearly aimed at players who enjoy methodical, detail-oriented building experiences and who are willing to tolerate some rough edges while the developers refine balance and usability.

Ultimately, New Cycle is a game about enduranceâ€”both for the settlement you are guiding and for the player willing to shepherd it through an unforgiving landscape. It has the potential to develop into a standout title once its systems mature and its pacing becomes more consistent. For now, it remains a solid, intriguing, and sometimes rough-edged foundation for what could become a deeply satisfying post-apocalyptic city-building experience.

review_text:
I have played this game for some time, even from the early days, so there is my review. 

The graphics made a big step up. There are moments when I leave the mouse and I enjoy the atmosphere of the game.  

Also, the skill tree has been changed many times, so I can tell that it is more or less better, even though there are some improvements possible. 

New zombies are cool, and also.. they are more intelligent.. :D My previous tactics from early days are not so effective now. But I like that is a little bit more of a challenge. There are things like the water system, which could be richer and more realistic like before, but never mind. 

If you like building bases, exploring? Try it. These are reasons I am playing this game till this day, and yeah, the waves are so much fun too. :) And with friends you will have even more fun and hours played, trust me. :D

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Simulation, Strategy
review_text:
7 days has been my go to game, for more than a decade. It has been through so much changes and evolved over time. It has been updated, reworked, backtracked and rebuilt so many times, that the game is simply unrecognisable from it's first versions. Even now that the game is fully out, there is still big content missing: Bandits/bandit camps, story, etc. This is an amazing game I go back to, every few updates, to see how much it has changed and whats new.  It is, a real labor of love.  The devs are dedicated, and listen to fans. They do regular live stream where to respond questions and ask opinions whilst explaining upcoming changes. 

There is still room for improvements, sure. But what the game is now, is still very flexible for varying playstile, but no matter what, it is a complete blast!

review_text:
I went from dying multiple times in my first few days in a multiplayer server with experienced friends helping me to surviving my first blood moon with no deaths at all on a solo play server.

This game is very punishing, and mostly fair. There's a LOT going on. The introduction is ok, but the best learning is from trying things out, failing, and doing better next time.

There is a creative mode option as well that is very helpful for trying things out with little to no consequences.

There's an excellent 'perk' system that allows for a wide variety of playstyles, from the simple melee bruiser, to the intellectual trap master, to the classic stealth archer, and many more.
Fundamentally, it's all about killing lots of zombies using a variety of increasingly outlandish tools.

Occasionally there's a multimodal masterpiece that touches on all the softest and most bedraggled places inside you and makes demands of your fundamental humanity to be accountable for the state of the universe. 
That surveys the sum of the furthest reaches of where you have extended your thinking and makes all those years of feeling mushy minded into an actual shame because you may go there all the time on your own but other people are speaking it out into the world in ways that display such thoroughly grounded comprehension. It feels like love making of the sort you could've and should've been offering to the world if you'd just only been slightly less broken.
And you're left breathless and enthralled and so grateful that the handheld dimensions of which we're the inheritors are being used by visionaries to glorify the heart of the world.

I decided to write this review since I see a lot of people have a rough time with the entry barrier into Master Duel. 

Master Duel is described by Konami as the place where you will duel at the highest level and when they say highest level they are not downplaying it. First things you need to be aware of is that yes there is a barrier when you start playing that at first might seem overwhelming, but you need to remember you are jumping at the deep-end of the Yu-Gi-Oh! dueling experience. Some people criticize Master Duel for not being beginner friendly, and although I do agree there is a curve to adapt to in terms of dueling, specially for people who are returning to Yu-Gi-Oh after many years away or people who have only watched the anime or who are experiencing the brand for the first time, I also think the game gives you the tools so that you are able to build a strong deck very early into the game. 

Chances are yes you are going to get whooped during your first couple of duels, but that is to be expected since you are at the first steps of your deck building but if you put your time to learn the ins and outs of the game, it is a great way to enjoy the franchise. 

Some useful things things for people willing to give it a shot:
- Master Duel is very very F2P friendly, the game gives you so many easy ways to get gems (the currency used for opening packs) and occasionally even give you full structure-decks through things like friend code referral and such. If you manage your gems correctly you can easily make a viable competitive deck in just a few minutes and can probably average a new deck every month or so.

- Do your tutorials (skip them if you have a basic understanding of the game) and after, when picking one of the 3 beginners decks, just pick the one that matches your latest understanding of Yu-Gi-Oh! 

- Before entering ranked matches, go to solo mode and there you will find many "missions" that reward you with cosmetics such as mates, duel fields, sleeves and even some actual card, but most importantly finishing the Duel Strategy missions reward you with a total of 2,400 gems. By doing solo mode not only can you unlock different rewards but you will also fulfill some of the challenges and missions that reward you with even more gems. 

- Now when it comes to currencies we have gems which are used to open card packs and just buy anything from the store and you also have crafting points (CP) ranging from Normal, Rare, Super Rare, and Ultra Rare points. These CP are used to craft cards individually which is helpful if the card you are looking for is not available on any dedicated pack or if you only need to craft 1 copy of that card. In principle crafting a card take 30 CP regardless of the rarity (and when crafting there is a random chance of it being one of three different types of foiling which basically just means how shiny the card will be). Then some cards you don't want can be dismantled into CP of the corresponding rarity of the card going from 10 - 30 CP depending on the foiling of the card dismantled. One thing to note with CP is that not all cards can be dismantled as some free cards you get wont be able to be dismantled, but every card from pack openings can be dismantled into CP (cards from structure decks can't be dismantled tho). Best tip is to spend your SR CP and UR CP wisely and only when you really want or need a card since they are the hardest points to gather at first.

- Now before building a deck, opening packs and crafting cards you need to ask yourself the most important question when joining Master Duel for the first time - Which deck do you want to play with? - This is the most important decision you will have to make since the deck you chose will be your partner for the first month or so, so more than a meta deck just go for the one you will have the most fun with.

- Once you know which deck you want to go with, the best thing to do is to just create a deck and add all the cards you will want in it, that way you will know which cards you have, which cards you are missing and their respective rarities. Then you have to best options, one of them is to take one SR or UR card from that archetype and craft it, in doing so you will unlock a secret pack from that archetype which then you can spend your gems opening packs to get cards from that archetype. You can also go into the store and look at the structure decks and see if the archetype you want is available there, that way by spending 500 gems you will get access to the core of the archetype and can be a shortcut to building your desired deck.

- 2 PRO TIPS when it comes to gems are NEVER SPEND GEMS on the MASTER PACK since the amount of cards in it makes it impossible to get anything you actually want (you are better sticking to secret packs) and also ALWAYS BUY THE DUEL PASS since this battle pass not only returns your gem investment if completed but also rewards you with limited-time accessories and tons of CP from all the rarities.

- If you really want to add a meta element to your deck you can also go to the shop special section and under bundle deals you will see bundles with 10 Master Packs and also a meta staple card. 

- With all of this said if you dismantle any and every card you dont need and if you claim your rewards and open more packs you will end up with a good deck to enter ranked as any cards you dont get can probably be crafted with the CP earned from the dismantle of cards. 

When it comes to dueling the game helps you flagging posible actions that can be taken or cards that can be played in case you are not fully experienced with your deck. As you climb through ranked you will earn more gems that can be used to make your deck stronger and such. 

Again, as this is a competitive TCG it does take time to settle in but the more time you put and as long as you are playing cards that are fun to you I really think this game has a lot to offer for Yu-Gi-Oh! fans. Ranked might be a tough pill to swallow at first but by making mistakes and losing duels is how you will learn.

You know...I was pretty damn late to the whole Nier party....I was always interested in playing Nier Automota since it released, but life is life and I always put it on the backlog again and again until one day I decided to give this game a shot. It's funny because I only found out about this games existence a few days before I played it. I scrolled through the screenshots and thought "oh, this games a prequel, I'll play this game once and then watch the other endings on youtube to prepare for my Automota playthrough" OH HOW WRONG I WAS. Playing this game blind for the first time was like falling through a rabbit hole that just kept getting deeper. It made me laugh, shout and downright ball my eyes out. each playthrough slowly adding more pieces to one of the most deep and interesting tales I've ever experienced in my life. Once those final credits rolled, I sat back in my chair and stared at my monitor for about 20 minutes just processing the sheer ART I just witnessed. I'm currently halfway through Automota experiencing the same thing on that game too. Please do yourself a favour and play this game, It's nothing short of a masterpiece of fiction and touches on serious topics that many creators dare touch upon. It's borderline changed my life and all I have been able to think about every single day since I finished it. (If you read this all the way through then forgive my rant, I am just so damn passionate about this game and can't believe it took 25 years of my life to experience it)

In my opinion, this is one of the most interesting political strategy games ever made. The atmosphere is outstanding, the music fits perfectly, and the graphics are lovely for a game of this genre.

If you're looking for a strategy game that focuses more on political depth and decision-making rather than just constant battles and sword-fighting, this is the one. I'm not saying the war mechanics are badâ€”far from itâ€”but the core of the game lies in governing, diplomacy, and managing your nation, rather than simply rushing to conquer everything like a careless child.

CRPG renaissance

Divinity: Original Sin â€“ Enhanced Edition is a tactical role-playing game that revitalizes the classic CRPG formula with depth, freedom, and smart writing. It combines strategic turn-based combat, meaningful player choice, and cooperative gameplay to create one of the most complete role-playing experiences of its generation.

The story follows two Source Hunters investigating a mysterious murder in the city of Cyseal, gradually uncovering a plot that threatens the fabric of reality. The narrative is layered with humor, moral ambiguity, and philosophical undertones. Dialogue choices matter, influencing character relationships, quests, and even combat outcomes.

Gameplay is defined by its interactivity. Almost every object, surface, and environmental element can be manipulated. Fire spreads, water conducts electricity, and poison ignites. Combat becomes a puzzle where creative thinking often wins over brute force. This system rewards experimentation, not repetition.

Character creation and progression are flexible. Players can customize skills, attributes, and abilities without being locked into rigid classes. Cooperative play enhances this freedomâ€”two players can explore, argue over choices, or separate to pursue different objectives simultaneously. The resulting dynamics make co-op feel organic rather than forced.

Visually, the Enhanced Edition improves textures, lighting, and interface clarity while keeping the gameâ€™s distinct hand-painted fantasy style. The redesigned UI and full voice acting make exploration and dialogue more immersive. Every conversation and environment feels alive and reactive.

The writing maintains a balance between wit and seriousness. Quests often carry multiple solutions, and morality is never simple. Whether youâ€™re solving a murder, arguing with a talking shell, or deciding the fate of an entire village, the game constantly invites critical thinking and reflection.

In essence, Divinity: Original Sin â€“ Enhanced Edition is a masterclass in player agency and tactical depth. Itâ€™s challenging, rewarding, and endlessly replayable. Every decision feels personal, every victory earned through intellect and creativity. It stands as one of the finest examples of modern role-playing design rooted in classic principles.

The combat feels great, and fighting robot dinosaurs does more than justify the price.

The graphics are pretty good for everything other than the people, and if that's a sticking point for you then I would still recommend going with the remaster either via upgrade or buying it outright.
There is a good range on difficulty from Very Easy, to Ultra Hard. I personally found it to be best on Hard/Very Hard as it makes you use more of your tools, but I also find the jump from Very Hard to Ultra Hard to be a bit much compared to the others.

The writing is... mediocre. Many points are rehashed several times on several different occasions and the dialogue swings wildly between stock NPC templates and amusing if not interesting characters, most of which I find to be located in the DLC. To its credit the few times the game gives you a choice in how to respond it feels like the choice is actually different from the others, but they do all lead to the same point in the end.

The combat has unique systems, and a good number of monsters to fight, even with a fifth of them being some flavor of "large cat with a gun strapped to it back". There probably could have been a bit more variety in monster types, but the ones that do exist each have their own strengths and weakness to exploit, so combat feels more engaging than just "hit the thing till it dies". 

Overall a great game, and if your looking for multiplayer Guerrilla has just announced an MMO in the same world so keep an eye out for that.

My feelings on the game are a bit mixed. Generally speaking it's a good game. It's enjoyable for the most part. HOWEVER

First and foremost, there are a lot of things that were improved on:
- more and varying enemies
- improved area details
- more content
- improved graphics
- incredibly beautiful music
- world feels much more alive 

HOWEVER, here are my nitpicks:
- WAY too many abilities (my controller buddies will understand that one)
- parasitic game design with the abilities 
- puzzles are less creative than from the predecessor
- story is alright, however it feels like a downgrade from the story of the predecessor and doesn't make a whole lot of sense at certain points

At times it feels like the game is an Ori game in name alone. I REALLY liked the first game for what it made different from most games. I don't really understand why Ori needed weapons in this game? Especially since they feel a bit off for a character like Ori. 
Sure, Sein existed in the predecessor. Which you could technically count as a weapon. And certainly the first game had a lot of different ways to engage with enemies (stomp, throwing them into thorns, throwing glowing balls at them, throwing their own projectiles back, etc.). Perhaps I'm just thrown off that Ori was given swords, a giant frying pan, bows, spears, etc. in this game. Might just be me tho.
The sheer amount of different trees that can be found throughout the game make the trees much less special to find over time.
I remember playing blind forest for the first time and getting very excited for every tree I found. In "Will of the Wisps" finding trees does get tiring after a while due to the sheer oversaturation of them (not to mention all the other stuff you can find, like shards). 

I kind of wish that Ku would've played a bigger role/would've been playable for longer. 

At times it feels like the devs tried making a different game, but had to use the Ori IP for it (That's just my tinfoil hat theory tho, lmao)

If you expect puzzles like in "blind forest", this is not really the game for you. Stick with the first game.
This game focusses much more on combat and for that it's well done. The bosses are challenging and enjoyable (My favorite is Mora). Less abilities or a different way to implement them all would've been preferred from my point of view.
If you want a lot of bosses, play the Hollow Knight series instead.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps â€” A Breathtaking Journey of Light and Emotion

Ori and the Will of the Wisps invites players into a beautifully crafted world filled with wonder, danger, and heartfelt storytelling. From the very first moments, the game showcases a vibrant, hand-painted art style and emotional depth that elevate its platforming adventure into something truly unforgettable.

The game excels in its fluid movement and refined gameplay. Oriâ€™s expanded abilities make traversal smooth, responsive, and deeply satisfying. Whether youâ€™re dashing through forests, gliding across windswept plains, or navigating intricate platforming challenges, every moment feels buttery smooth and expertly designed.

Combat has been significantly enhanced. A new suite of weapons and abilities adds depth and strategy, making encounters dynamic and rewarding. From fast-paced battles to clever ability combinations, the system offers a welcome layer of complexity without overwhelming players.

Exploration and progression are deeply rewarding. The interconnected world encourages curiosity, offering hidden secrets, side quests, and upgrades that enrich the journey. Each new area feels distinct, beautifully animated, and filled with environmental storytelling that draws you deeper into the worldâ€™s lore.

Visually and musically, the game is a masterpiece. The stunning art direction, expressive animations, and emotional soundtrack by Gareth Coker create an atmosphere that is both magical and affecting. Every momentâ€”peaceful or intenseâ€”is elevated by the gameâ€™s impeccable presentation.

Final Verdict:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a breathtaking and emotionally resonant masterpiece. With its polished gameplay, gorgeous visuals, and powerful storytelling, it stands among the best platformers ever made. A must-play for fans of world-class 2D adventure.

First playthrough review time.

This game continues the style of the first one, with smooth platforming and a clear layout. The level design, graphics and gameplay are nice, and each area has different hazards to watch out for. I played both games with a keyboard and mouse, and the controls work well enough for the movements the game asks for.

The early parts are simple, mainly teaching basic actions. As the game goes on, the paths get more complex and the obstacles become trickier. Some sections rely on quick input, while others need steady timing to avoid mistakes. The difficulty rises at a steady pace, so the progress through the areas stays manageable.

Overall, the game is focused on movement, timing, and careful navigation. The game demands timing and focus in every sections.
A masterpiece, very fluid movements, graphics looks absolutely amazing. One of the best Metroidvania imo.

I wish this game would get more recognition because it is a phenomenal game. A rock-solid followup. The devs really nailed the visual polishâ€”every scene element has smooth, detailed animations that make the world feel lively, and the extra layering gives the whole game a stronger sense of depth. There are also a lot of smart quality-of-life touches that other Metroidvania-style games should definitely learn from: the death penalty isnâ€™t excessive, thereâ€™s no pointless grind or â€œtrash timeâ€ and the speedrun challenges are super efficient to retry. Mess up? Boomâ€”instant restart. And when you finish a run, it sends u right back to the starting point eliminating unnecessary waiting or backtracking. Plus, all hidden items can be collected before finishing the game, so you never get permanently locked out just becuz the story moved forward.
[b]Downsides:[/b] Map opens with an awkward lag and doesnâ€™t remember ur zoom level. The pacing falls off right before the endâ€”thereâ€™s one brutally hard area that completely breaks the flow. New soundtrack doesnâ€™t have any standout tracks, mainstory is pretty forgettable, and the guidance toward new areas is really unclear.

[i]Ori and the Will of the Wisps[/i] is a masterwork. The game takes everything that made its predecessor great and enhances it, while adding new mechanics that greatly improve gameplay and expand the Ori universe.

In continuation from its predecessor, the game's visuals, lighting, and audio are as stunning as ever, and character movement and combat are fast and fluid. Worldbuilding extends upon what already exists in the Ori universe, with unique locations such as the coastal and colorful Luma Pools, the dark and scary spider's nest of Mouldwood, the cold and beautiful snowcapped Baur's Peak, and the sandy and desolate Windswept Wastes, all of which center around a magnificent Spirit Willow.

Ori's skill kit is greatly enhanced with a variety of weapons to keep enemies at bay and other utilities to aid mobility and survival, allowing for greater variety in the character's build. The environment itself presents new mechanics as well, from bubbles that can be redirected with a gust of wind to sand that can be burrowed through. There are also new monsters and environmental hazards to encounter, extending upon the Ori universe's biodiversity and danger.

One standout feature the game provides that its predecessor does not is boss fighting, pushing the Ori universe's biodiversity and danger even further. Additionally, boss fights add more variety to completing quests when chase scenes used to define quest resolution. All boss fights serve importance to the story in both heartwarming and heartbreaking ways.

And the soundtrack? Gareth Coker takes his music to the next level and surpasses even his amazing soundtrack for the game's predecessor. His music breathes life into every corner of the Ori universe, from environmental tracks, to chase scenes, to boss fights, to every uplifting and heartbreaking moment. His composition and arrangement of percussion, strings, woodwinds, brass, and vocals never cease to amaze and are quintessentially "Ori".

[i]Ori and the Will of the Wisps[/i] is truly a masterwork. Are you ready to go on a moving journey and embrace the light?

Overall â€“ Blasphemous is a haunting blend of tough combat, stunning pixel art, and deeply atmospheric world-building. Playing as the Penitent One, you explore the bleak land of Cvstodia, an environment overflowing with twisted religious imagery and beautifully crafted, unsettling detail. The gameplay leans into deliberate, Souls-like combat. Every swing feels weighty, every enemy demands attention, and bosses are memorable, punishing, and incredibly satisfying to overcome. Youâ€™ll die often, but each attempt teaches you something, making progress feel genuinely earned. The story is delivered through cryptic dialogue and environmental clues rather than straightforward exposition, giving the game a mysterious, poetic tone. Itâ€™s the kind of world that invites you to piece it together rather than giving you answers outright. If you enjoy challenging Metroidvanias with rich atmosphere and art that sticks with you, Blasphemous is absolutely worth playing. Highly Recommended.

It took me a while to actually beat this game. I bought it near to 3 years before this review because it art. I am sucker for religious paintings or perhaps enjoy romantizing martyrdom, this game succeeds in bringing a captivating beauty through misery. 
Speaking of misery, the gameplay of course takes large inspiration for Metroid and Dark souls. The game does well in making the game feel tough during certain bosses, though after a point it does become easier (I say in better or for worse terms.) The gameplay admittedly didn't sway me, if I had never played a Mouls-like or a metroidvania, it would be completely fresh to me but only recycles these ideas and I am afraid to say doesn't bring much to table in terms of new ideas. The gameplay itself does feel almost like an IGN review of an indy game. BUT, the game's atmosphere, and story is where the game begins to shine and find it's identity. It's a fun (though maybe Blasphemous,) retelling of Christ. The Penitent One goes into world to free it from suffering. Though in this game it's done by violence and not by kindness. It's an interesting and grim retelling of my beliefs. It's hopeful enough to not feel like an edgy gorefest and bleak enough to feel impactful. There is some gripes I do have with the story, but since I haven't played the sequel, I think it is best if I bite my tounge for now. I would give it probably a 7.5/10.

This is a *real*, officially licensed, completely free dating sim where your main objective is to:

* Attend culinary school
* Make life-changing choices
* And romantically pursue a bishonen anime version of Colonel Sanders, who has more abs than menu items.

Not a parody *of* KFC.
A parody dating sim **by** KFC.

---

### Pros

* 100% free, which is good, because youâ€™ll need that money for actual chicken afterward.
* Genuinely gorgeous anime art. Everyone looks like they escaped from Ouran Host Club and fell into a deep fryer.
* Youâ€™re a culinary student at the â€œUniversity of Cooking School: Academy for Learning,â€ which is the most legally safe fake school name ever written.
* Cast includes:

  * Hot Sanders
  * Your supportive bestie
  * Evil rivals Aeshleigh & Van Van the Man Man (yes thatâ€™s his name)
  * Professor Dog, who is an actual dog in a little chefâ€™s hat
* Thereâ€™s a secret ending, â€œsecret recipes,â€ and dramatic â€œcooking battlesâ€ that feel like Iron Chef on a marketing budget.

---

### Cons

* Steam tags say things like â€œSouls-like,â€ â€œFPS,â€ and â€œWorld War Iâ€ because the community is unhinged. Please ignore them.
* Choices â€œhave consequences,â€ but most of the time the real consequence is Colonel Sanders being slightly disappointed in you, which honestly hurts more than a game over.
* Actual dating content is pretty tame; itâ€™s less â€œthirst simâ€ and more â€œbranding exercise with sparkles.â€ Critics wereâ€¦ not impressed. Players, on the other hand, are just vibing.
* You *will* finish it and realize you just emotionally invested in a man whose primary character trait is â€œ11 herbs and spices.â€

---

### Peak Colonel Experience

* Trying to give a sincere answer in class and being out-performed by a literal cooking robot named Clank.
* Getting genuinely nervous about impressing Sanders with your mashed potatoes.
* Replaying scenes to optimize dialogue like: â€œIf I pick the wrong line, will he *not* franchise with me?â€
* Credits roll and you close the gameâ€¦ then immediately google if anyone has actually cosplayed this version of Sanders. (They have. Of course they have.)

---

9/10
Itâ€™s dumb, itâ€™s pretty, itâ€™s a walking ad, and it knows *exactly* what it is.
Came for the meme, stayed for the anime colonel calling my mashed potatoes â€œexquisite.â€

Donâ€™t Starve surprised me with how well it blends whimsical art with grounded survival mechanics. The atmosphere is incredible, the survival loop is addictive, and the game still holds up after all these years. Combat is the weakest part, but everything else pulled me in. For the price, itâ€™s absolutely worth it.

The Good:
â€¢ Amazing Tim Burton-style art and quirky tone
â€¢ Strong survival loop with great early-game pacing
â€¢ Realistic mechanics that actually matter (fire spreading, sanity, sleep)
â€¢ Weather, darkness, and nightfall create genuine tension
â€¢ Lots to discover and experiment with
â€¢ Time flies, easy to get absorbed

The Not-So-Good:
â€¢ Combat feels basic and predictable
â€¢ Early sanity confusion until you understand the system
â€¢ Building in a 2.5D space can feel a little awkward
â€¢ Requires trial-and-error before things start to really click

Final Verdict: 7.5/10

One of the better survival games out there if you like creepy whimsy and grounded mechanics. Combat needs work, but the atmosphere and loop are excellent.

Today I finished this masterpiece and the greatest game I have ever played.
Cyberpunk 2077 delivers an unforgettable mix of rich storytelling, stunning visuals, and deep, emotional character arcs. You can choose from a variety of different builds. Night City feels alive in every corner, and the choices you make truly shape your experience. After all the updates, the game runs smoothly and feels more immersive than ever.
And Phantom Liberty takes the game to another level, with a gripping spy-thriller story and some of the best characters in the entire game. Dogtown feels intense and alive, adding fresh gameplay, new weapons, and some unforgettable missions. The expansionâ€™s writing and atmosphere are phenomenal, making every choice feel meaningful and heavy. If Cyberpunk 2077 is a masterpiece, Phantom Liberty is the perfect finishing touchâ€”a must-play for anyone diving into Night City.

If you want a world that pulls you in and a story that stays with you long after the credits roll, this is it.
A must-play.

Inquisition still holds up 11 years later. It's a pain to get approval for Iron Bull and I didn't miss that. I'm 50 hours in at the time of writing this review and Demands of the Qun still has not been made available on my save file for...seemingly no reason. Although, I am not romancing Bull.

[h1][b] TLDR: A solid 40-hour RPG wrapped up in an 80-hour game. Good story and characters, but suffers greatly from quantity over quality and RPG mechanic streamlining. [/b] [/h1]

[h1]PROS: [/h1]
â•Dragon Age Keep - carry your choices from DA1/DA2
â•Open world
â•Story and characters


[h1]NEUTRALS: [/h1]
ğŸ”¹War room - while a neat thought, real-time missions can be a turn-off
ğŸ”¹Requires EA launcher, but I found this largely unintrusive

[h1]CONS: [/h1]
â–Speech volume is absurdly low
â–No stat-based speech options
â–30 FPS-locked cutscenes
â–Overly-simplified character building
â–Can feel very â€œQuantity over qualityâ€ at times
â–Crash to desktop count = 4


My reviews for: 
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Synikx/recommended/47810?snr=1_5_9__402]Dragon Age Origins (DA1)[/url]
[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/Synikx/recommended/1238040?snr=1_5_9__402]Dragon Age 2 (DA2)[/url]

[h1] [b] Content (Game world/Narrative) â€“ [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
The game world can be quite spectacular to behold. Inquisition takes the foundation of DA1 and DA2 and expands it immensely. The locations you visit are varied, from ancient Elven forests to sandy deserts to stormy coasts, the locations are different enough to where the biomes donâ€™t get repetitive and even have some throwbacks to DA1. Furthermore, the exploration and interaction are good. Each area has tons of collectables and lore entries that teach the player about the area and where it fits into the history of Thedas. 
Perhaps the big negative thing to point out here is quantity over quality. I would have preferred if there were actually [i]less[/i] zones with a greater emphasis on each zone being deeper and more meaningfully designed. Because while they are beautiful to behold and can be fun to explore, fatigue is very real and remembering the nuances of each area can be more difficult than it should be. 

The narrative is okay. Itâ€™s a typical â€œBig bad trying to destroy the worldâ€ type thing, but I think the setting and characters elevate the narrative to greater heights. 
As for the DLCs, Jaws of Hakkon is forgettable, The Decent is better, and Trespasser is probably the best bit of story content in the game, shame the best parts only last ~20 minutes. 

[h1][b] Gameplay (Mechanics/Difficulty) â€“ [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
The mechanics are decent, but I feel that largely it is a step back in depth from DA1 and more inline with the gradual streamlining of DA2. The prior games had a unique take on Dungeons & Dragons, while DA:I feels much more shallow. Itâ€™s kind of like going from something like Final Fantasy X to FF XV - yes, it's prettier and faster and cooler, but the RPG mechanics suffer. Gone are any sort of stat-based conversation options, the character progression is simplified, and even abilities can feel very boring and shallow. The game does open up a bit when you unlock your classes' specialization, as some of those kits are fun and work very well with the base classes, but I still canâ€™t help but feel an overall theme of having less RPG mechanics in an RPG game, which is a big negative for me. 
New to DA entirely (I think) is the crafting. This can help to customize your character's gear, especially if you donâ€™t know where the best drops are or if you are simply unlucky. 

The difficulty is generally fairly easy, especially as you level up and unlock better gear and more talents. I played on Normal, and it was a tad difficult in the beginning, but by the time I unlocked my Knight Enchanter specialization after about ~12 hours, I was blowing things up.
One thing I did enjoy is the addition of â€œTrialsâ€ which are optional difficulty increases. You can choose to add elective difficulty increases for some small increased awards like additional loot. Things like having enemies level with you (which is how it naturally was in DA1/DA2) or even an option to turn bears into mini-boss gods. 

[h1] [b] Graphics (Quality/Technical) â€“ [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
The graphics are very PS4-era, and while they do age pretty well for a ~11 year old game, certain things like animations can be very stiff and reflections on metal surfaces appear just awful. Still, I think this is a great looking game for its age. 
Probably the worst area graphically is the menu UI. It definitely feels like the focus is on the console versions because the UI is just awful to use with a mouse and keyboard. You have to constantly do things like move your mouse off and then back onto an item to get the tooltip to display. 

On the technical side, the game is not good. I experienced multiple crash to desktops and many bugs when my game simply wouldnâ€™t load, and I had to alt+F4 to the last save. Even aside from technical issues, I ran into gameplay bugs where my characters would stop using abilities, or I couldnâ€™t pick up items on the ground. I had to reload often to fix them. I even ran into bugs where essential characters seemed to have fallen through the ground and was missing all their dialog, essentially ruining the quest.  
i9-13900KF | RTX 4090 | 64GB RAM | 1440p @ 240hz | Windows 11 installed on SSD 

[h1] [b] Audio â€“ [7/10] [/b] [/h1]
I found the audio to be good. The music is largely forgettable, but there were a few iconic songs that are great. 
Voice acting is top-notch and awesome. 
I did encounter many cases where the audio simply stopped working. From combat to dialog, no sound. 

[h1] [b] Replay Factor (Longevity) â€“ [5/10] [/b] [/h1]
I think there is some decent replay value here - you can choose male or female, different races, different classes, and different romances as well as a few quests that have some slightly different outcomes. The game is pretty linear, but the choices can definitely warrant multiple runs. 

[h1] [b] Final Verdict â€“ [6/10] [/b] [/h1]
Dragon Age Inquisition (DAI) is the THIRD game in the Dragon Age series. I highly recommend you go and play the first and second, as they have aged fairly well and are great experiences. Now that youâ€™re here and thinking of diving into DAI what can you expect and how does it compare to DA1/DA2? 

DA1 has a very dark setting full of intrigue. Itâ€™s full of solid RPG gameplay that is parallel to Dungeons & Dragons. DAI does not largely have that. DA2 seemed like a step-down from many of the things that made DA1 so great, but itâ€™s still a good RPG. I feel like DAI is on par with DA2 in that it's decent, but streamlined so much that player choice suffers. 

What DAI offers is a massive open world within the Dragon Age universe, like youâ€™ve never seen it before. I want to make it clear that massive does not mean good. DAI has a clear problem of quantity over quality. You can easily burn dozens of hours doing fetch quests and other random pointless crap that serves no narrative purpose other than to increase your â€œPointsâ€ that you can then spend on unlocking more zones to do more pointless things that give more pointsâ€¦DAI is a nice 40-hour RPG adventure wrapped up in an 80-hour game. 

Itâ€™s not all bad, though. I would say the best part is the story. That 40 hour story is pretty good for about 20 of those hours. Especially the DLC, Trespasser. If Mass Effectâ€™s sendoff was anything to go by, BioWare is very good at doing epilogues for their games and where it ends immediately makes you want more. Also, I have to do a shoutout to the great characters. Itâ€™s a pretty great cast of characters with their own personalities. Sera is my elfy wife. 

Overall, yes, I would recommend DAI. I think it's an okay game. Fans of DA1 and DA2 probably shouldnâ€™t miss it.

[h1]A vast, beautiful RPG with rewarding progression and deep lore, though overwhelming for newcomers.[/h1]
[i](This review contains no story spoilers btw!!)[/i]

[b]-Overview-[/b]
Developed by BioWare, Dragon Age: Inquisition is a massive fantasy RPG that blends real-time combat with tactical strategy. Players take command of the Inquisition, leading a diverse group of companions to restore order to a fractured world. With hundreds of quests, beautiful environments, and meaningful choices, it delivers an epic adventure, but it is also heavily built on the foundations of the previous two Dragon Age games, and newcomers may feel theyâ€™ve missed major pieces of context.

[b]-Story & Characters-[/b]
[i]A strong, engaging story, best experienced after playing the first two games.[/i]
 Inquisitionâ€™s narrative is well-crafted, emotionally resonant, and packed with political drama, divine conflict, and moral decisions. However, the game relies heavily on world events, character arcs, and choices established in Dragon Age: Origins and Dragon Age II. Returning characters make cameos, past decisions impact present events, and major story threads continue directly from earlier titles.

For players who havenâ€™t experienced the prior games, much of this depth risks feeling distant or incomplete. The Dragon Keep system, which lets you import or manually reconstruct past choices, helps fill the gaps mechanically,  but not emotionally. Reading about choices you never made or characters you never met is a poor substitute for having lived those stories yourself. This is one of the few RPGs where your personal history with the series genuinely matters, and missing that history can lessen the impact of major scenes.

As a first-time Dragon Age player, itâ€™s easy to feel like youâ€™re walking into the third act of a trilogy without having seen the first two. The story is still very good, but youâ€™ll constantly sense that youâ€™ve missed meaningful context, relationships, and payoffs. If anything: I wish someone had told me to play the first two games first. I would have enjoyed this story far more if Iâ€™d brought my own choices and experiences into it instead of relying on presets.

Companions are well-written and offer solid banter and personal quests. Their level of involvement is similar to Fallout 4: theyâ€™re memorable and distinct, but their presence has less influence on the core story than companions in Mass Effect or Dragon Age: Veilguard.

[b]-Gameplay-[/b]
[i]A complex combat system that becomes satisfying once mastered.[/i]
 Combat can be overwhelming early on, especially for players new to managing AI tactics and switching between party members. Over time, though, it becomes one of the gameâ€™s strengths. The mix of real-time action and tactical pausing allows for careful planning or fast-paced brawling, depending on your build. However, people who arenâ€™t new to this type of combat system will find themselves bored with the lack of builds you can make with your character. Still, I found it to be quite enjoyable, regardless.

Character progression is exceptionally well-paced: you begin fragile and unsure, but grow steadily stronger through skill trees, specialization classes, and improved gear. You cannot brute-force enemies above your level, they will flatten you, but the game fairly challenges you within your tier.

Exploration is vast, and each region feels alive with wildlife, secrets, side quests, and collectibles. The sheer amount of optional content is impressive, though some zones can feel bloated with minor objectives.

[b]-World Design & Visuals-[/b]
[i]One of the most visually striking RPGs of its era.[/i]
 The landscapes are vibrant, diverse, and grounded in strong artistic direction. From snowy fortresses to lush jungles and windswept deserts, each region is detailed and atmospheric. The world feels alive and lived-in, and the lighting and environment design remain a standout even today.

[b]-Music & Sound-[/b]
[i]A solid soundtrack that shines in key moments.[/i]
 While the score is not consistently memorable on its own, it elevates major scenes beautifully. Music swells during emotional peaks and blends seamlessly into exploration. Voice acting is strong across the board.

[b]-Length & Value-[/b]
[i]A colossal RPG with well over 90 hours of content.[/i]
 Even a focused run takes dozens of hours, and completionists can expect significantly more,  especially with story DLC. At its frequent sale price, itâ€™s excellent value. However, this isnâ€™t necessarily a good thing, as by the end of the game, you start to get bored exploring all these different zones and doing all these different fetch quests, and at some point, you just wish for the game to end.

[b]-Replayability-[/b]
[i]Worth replaying only if you want to see major branching outcomes.[/i]
 The game offers multiple endings and many impactful choices, but each playthrough is a major time investment. Most players will likely complete it once and revisit it after a long break.

[b]-Summary-[/b]
Dragon Age: Inquisition is a richly developed RPG with excellent world-building, strong narrative arcs, and satisfying character progression. Its size can be overwhelming, but its story and environments are worth the time, provided you play the first two Dragon Age games first.

For newcomers, the Dragon Keep system cannot replicate the emotional weight of decisions you never made or relationships you never formed. The game is filled with callbacks, cameos, and payoffs designed for long-time fans, and much of that will be lost without experiencing the earlier titles.

[b]Highly recommended, especially after completing Dragon Age: Origins and Dragon Age II, which will greatly enhance the story and make Inquisition feel like the true saga finale it was designed to be. 9/10 game, not surprised itâ€™s won game of the year before.[/b]

How early weâ€™re forced to grow up when the whole world is falling into the abyss.
This story is about the coming-of-age of Clementine, an 11-year-old girl who had the misfortune of growing up far too soon, just like everyone else in these harsh times. Even as a child, she directly influences the course of events.

In this world, there are no â€œgoodâ€ or â€œbadâ€ people. You simply do what feels honest to yourself in order to survive in a cruel and unforgiving environment. Every character here is neither a hero nor a villain, but a person making choicesâ€”each with its own price.

From chapter to chapter, you realize that the walkers are only a predictable threat. The real danger comes from the people beside you. You barely know them, yet you must survive together. Will they stab you in the back? You can never be certain. And that uncertainty makes every decision heavy.

This story reflects your inner struggleâ€”your desire to choose â€œthe right thing,â€ even though there is no objectively right choice. Only consequences. The plot moves forward, and you are an unwilling passenger in it, wanting only one thing: to survive.

And then the main question arises: what are you surviving for?
You might want to hide in a corner and do nothing, but the walkers wonâ€™t allow it. You may hope to survive alone while the world burns, but people are far more dangerous than the deadâ€”you never know what theyâ€™ll do or whether theyâ€™ll stay on your side. Only time will tell.

Everyone wants choices to be simple and clearâ€¦ but when the world collapses, they never are.
Then againâ€”were they ever?

Whew where to begin with this one? I am an author by trade among other things, games is just a passion of mine. The game itself has a survival horror/science fiction angle, the story is very well done, it keeps you on the edge of your seat the entire time.

Can you be you without a body ('soma' in Greek)? Does our self need a biological form? How much can you alter it while still preserve its humanity? What if consciousness could be scanned and digitized to run on a computer?

[i]SOMA[/i] is a first person horror game with clever philosophical depth and profoundness. This is achieved with a few trivial yet somehow awfully meaningful choices along a gripping journey through a bleak underwater research facility. Splendidly voice-acted protagonist Simon ([b]Jared Zeus[/b]) and his acquaintance Catherine ([b]Nell Mooney[/b]) provide their own opinions but leave room for the player to think.

SOMA's weakness is the lack of gameplay mechanics: it is a walking simulator with slight puzzle and stealth elements. Replayability is almost nonexistent due to that. But for one playthrough, the game does provide an immensely immersive 10-hour experience. The physical interactivity of objects -- pushing and pulling doors, grabbing and throwing stuff -- makes the game world feel tangible.

Certain sections with a monster can become frustrating if you get stuck on repeating them. Fortunately, in a post-release update, [b]Frictional Games[/b] added a Safe Mode option that stops the monsters from hindering your progress. The mode does reduce tension considerably -- since no actual threats -- but doesn't affect the overall gloomy atmosphere that much.

Incredible game and story. Leaves you thinking about the implications of all the decisions well after it is over and the outcome. So much to unpack. Easily a game I could see myself wanting to forget to replay all over again.

Some parts of the stealth were frustrating, but I might just be bad. I would also love an option to have changed to pacifist difficulty during the playthrough, but so glad I powered through and finished the game.
This shit made me cry

Soma makes great use of the first person horror medium to provoke ethical and other philosophical questions in the player. There's enough quiet time to ponder these themes in between the monster encounters, most of which I found genuinely scary. The challenge of the game is basically to keep your nerve and figure out the monster's behaviour - short puzzles under emotional pressure. I think you'll be missing out if you use safe mode. 

There are also several more relaxed puzzles without any monster stalking you, which I found interesting and well-judged in terms of difficulty. I felt like I really could be the protagonist, trying this and that until something works. I also really appreciated that the game felt like a real environment, with lots of spaces and objects that aren't relevant to the player. I find this adds a lot to immersion. Furthermore, there are no stupid easter eggs or steam achievements for exploring every inch of the map. You can actually behave like you would if you were really in this world, instead of running around like a maniac looking for dopamine.
 
The story is excellent and very original. Not only that, I'd call it anti-formulaic.
[spoiler]Terry Akers isn't some final "big bad" boss, and the last human alive isn't Catherine Chun, instead it's an ordinary woman who's a stranger to the player and to the protagonist[/spoiler]. The major decisions in the game are also left as instrinsically rewarding - they are for asking yourself what you'd do in an extreme situation. Not for thinking how you can get some achievement or alternate ending. 
The creators clearly thought a lot about what a game could, and should be. Strongly recommended to anyone into sci-fi, horror or philosophy.
BEST HORROR SCI-FI!!! Loved every second of it, the story of this game is way better than many movies with the same vibes.
The ending caused psychological damage that lasts to this day.

DEVOUR â€” Chaotic Co-Op Horror With Heart-Pounding Tension

DEVOUR plunges players into a frantic co-op horror experience where teamwork, panic, and quick thinking are the only things standing between your group and a terrifying cult entity. Each map feels like a self-contained nightmare, requiring coordination and courage as the tension escalates with every ritual item you collect.

The game shines in its simple yet effective co-op design. Working together to find items, manage resources, and dodge the ever-growing aggression of the possessed leader turns every match into a chaotic thrill ride. Communication is keyâ€”splitting up can mean faster progress, but also guarantees hilariously horrifying moments as someone gets dragged into the dark.

Atmosphere and pacing are major strengths. Each locationâ€”from haunted farmhouses to burning asylumsâ€”offers distinct threats, secrets, and environmental storytelling. The sound design ramps up fear at all the right moments, building suspense as the demonâ€™s behavior evolves and the stakes rise.

Progression and replayability keep players coming back. Difficulty settings, unlockable cosmetics, and new maps with unique mechanics ensure that each run stays fresh. The unpredictability of enemy behavior and the frantic scramble near the end of each round make DEVOUR consistently exciting with friends.

Final Verdict:
DEVOUR is a fast, frightening, and wildly entertaining co-op horror experience. Its escalating tension, distinct maps, and teamwork-focused gameplay make it a must-play for fans of multiplayer scares and chaos-filled sessions with friends.

â€œTerrifying, frantic, and endlessly funâ€”horror co-op at its most chaotic.â€

Farthest Frontier is a carefully designed city-building survival game that combines strategic decision-making with a persistent sense of vulnerability. Set on the outskirts of untamed wilderness, it places you in charge of a small group of settlers striving to build a successful community in a harsh and demanding environment.

A major highlight of the game is its remarkable attention to detail. Every resourceâ€”firewood, crops, iron, and even manpowerâ€”feeds into a tightly connected system that requires thoughtful management. The depth of the farming mechanics, including crop rotation, soil health, and disease prevention, makes agriculture feel both authentic and engaging. Seeing your settlement grow from a handful of simple huts into a lively town is genuinely satisfying.

Visually, the game stands out as well. Its art style blends rugged realism with inviting warmth, while the shifting seasons, handcrafted building designs, and immersive environmental sounds work together to create a compelling atmosphere.

However, Farthest Frontier does not shy away from difficulty. Unpredictable events such as illness, severe weather, or enemy raids can easily erase significant progress if youâ€™re caught off guard. Some players may also find the early game slow-paced and the interface overwhelming once the town reaches a larger scale. Still, these hurdles contribute to the gameâ€™s identityâ€”survival is meant to be challenging.

In the end, Farthest Frontier delivers a highly rewarding experience for those who enjoy deep city-building and survival strategy games. It values patience, foresight, and adaptability, offering a strong sense of achievement each time your settlement endures another brutal winter. For players who appreciate games where every choice has weight, this title is definitely worth playing.

Centuries ago, humanity invented games in the form of cards, dice or just simple little pieces used to represent something else. Ever since then, we built upon that to make them more complex, make more intricate rules, promote competition, even use techonology to increase their complexity to the extent that a human arbiter couldn't be bothered to keep up with. Somewhere among those creations, we lost our way, turning games into intricate skinner boxes with a long list of simulated chores. A series of buttons to press to progress to a predetermined end.

I thank Jim Balatro from returning us to the original form of play. To the drunkards in bars playing dominoes on the table. To the loners playing Solitaire. For instead of using technology to add more layers, to enhancing the core of playing with cards. For stripping us of the layers of vestige and falsehood we've put on play for decades, and laying it bare for us to see it fully for what it truly is. Its true beauty, for all to see.

Brotato is an absolute blast. I went in expecting a simple little arena shooter to kill some time, and it quickly became one of my go-to "just one more run" games. The gameplay loop is fast, chaotic, and super satisfyingâ€”exactly the kind of fun that hooks you without feeling overwhelming.

What I love most is how easy it is to pick up. You can jump into a run within seconds, but thereâ€™s an impressive amount of depth once you start combining weapons, items, and character abilities. Every run feels different, and even the failures are fun because you immediately see what you want to try next.

The humor and style are great too. The little potato characters are surprisingly charming, and the variety of builds makes experimenting genuinely enjoyable. Plus, the game runs smoothly, loads instantly, and never gets in the way of the action.

If you like roguelikes, horde shooters, or just want something fast and ridiculously fun, Brotato is absolutely worth it. Itâ€™s one of those games that feels good from the first minute and keeps getting better the more you play.

You learned game mechanics and easily defeat final boss? Developer hands you Cruciball - hardcore mode, 20 negative modifiers stacking on top of each other each run you won.

The Good: Monster Train HURLS your demonic ass onto a PYRE-POWERED TRAIN TO HELL, roguelike deckbuilder where you STACK FLOORS OF MONSTERS to MULCH heaven's winged wankers! Clans? INSANE VARIETYâ€”Hellhorned berserkers, Umbra vamp-sucks, Wurm poison orgies, EACH a combo-exploding fever dream of synergies! Runs CRACK ADDICTION, brisk 45-min blasts with positioning mindfucks, artifacts twisting decks into OP apocalypse machines. Covenants ramp to masochistic nirvana (25 levels!), dailies, Hell Rush multiplayerâ€”Slay the Spire? This pyre-roasts it! Replayability eternal, unlocks jank heaven. BRAIN-MELT BLISS!

The Bad: Learning curve SPIKIER than Lucifer's buttplugâ€”clan math, floor tactics? Trial-by-fire or rage-quit! RNG cackles like a imp orgy, swingy runs YEET your god-deck on one bad draw. Early misplay? Key unit pops, run derails faster than a drunk conductor. Locked into early picks, less STS-style deck surgeryâ€”git gud or cry brimstone! Boss order repetitive, grinding covenants feels like eternal damnation lite.

The Ugly: Pyre SNIPE vulnerability = ULTIMATE RAGE-BAIT, one seraphim laser and your epic run EXPLODES in clown tears! UI BUSY AS HELL'S DMVâ€”tiny icons, overlapping helltext, art bland as boiled demon balls. Rare crashes lurk like tutorial poltergeists, story thinner than angel wings. Clan balance wobblesâ€”some combos trash-tier turdsâ€”but patches mostly exorcised the bullshit!

The Verdict: 9.5/10, Pyre-Defending Roguelike Deckbuilder

Monster train 1 can't be called perfect game, even great one, it is indeed fiiles with many cards with different mechanics, good visuals and pleaseant music, but at the same time it lashes at you with catastrophicslly low roster of enemies, outrageously long meta progression and nevertheless limited number of combinations, which leads to limited unusual gameplay situations.

P.S. BUT Monster train 2 is wonderful, much more cards and mechanics, more enemies and bosses, and even more music (and sometimes it rocks!). So there is really no reason to buy first game, when sequel is already on board, including the fact, that they both cost the same 25 dollars/euro.

I picked this up on sale for $1.99, and I'm glad I did. While roguelikes/lites aren't usually my preferred type of long-term game, I enjoyed this one.

I really dug the gameplay loop during the six hours I played. The core mechanic involves testing out different combinations with the deck-building cards, removing weaker ones, and growing stronger to be able to face the final boss. Doing a run usually takes about 15â€“30 minutes, making it quick and fun. A unique aspect of Monster Train is that you must defend your pyre at the top of a train on three different floors while the enemies ascend.

There is no real story. And the graphical style is decent. It has a very Flash/mobile aesthetic, which isn't something I usually prefer.

But for two bucks, I got some solid enjoyment out of the main story and beating it. I can definitely see myself going back to use the different clan combinations (you choose a primary and an allied clan for each run) and other mechanics to have some fun here and there.

A 7 out of 10.

This is going to function as my review of every 2k game since I have played many of them and they are mostly the same. When this franchise began, it completely revolutionized not only basketball games, but sports games in general. The first 2k I played was 2k11 not because I really liked NBA basketball, but because I heard it was a really good video game. It was instant love. It felt like I was a professional athlete, with the most intuitive and perfect environment I had ever experienced in a sports game. It took my fandom of basketball to the next level and to this day, it's really the only sport I care about. But more than that, 2k is my ultimate comfort game. I've put thousands of hours into them collectively, from my career, to online, to just doing random play nows. If I don't know what to do or want to relax as easily as possible, I play 2k. Now we could get into how the franchise has changed over time and even I, a super fan, recognize it has gotten worse over time, but I still fundamentally feel it is as good a basketball game as one could exist, and the tiny things around it may change but that core experience doesn't. I do not think your enjoyment of this game is dependent on your love of basketball or even sports- it is perfectly executed and for anyone just diving in, it will likely become a comfort game for you too. All hail the king. 10/10
