I remember the game used to be wayyyyyy more balanced and fair. I love all the updates, but balancing is much, much, much needed. Please, this premise is too good to be left for dead. I hope it is fixed, but until then, I cannot recommend this game in it's current state.

This was a tough one for me. I really wanted to give it a positive review... The Idea is great and the game play shows a lot of promise. The downside is the frustration around several encounter types and the navigation of the board. I would have liked a choice for navigation where I could just pick the route I want to go rather than having to shoot a ball and hope I get to go the right way. At least a choice where If I pick the path I don't get any extra money or healing provided by the relics and orbs. The encounters with the Wall (second stage boss) which even if you played perfectly up till that point is too big of a hurdle as about I lose about 80 percent of the time. I find many play styles would just fail outright at it. The other encounter with the long line of exploding goblins always ends my run. Doesn't seem to matter what orbs or relics I have they win. They do 40 damage a hit and have more health combined that most bosses. I'm at the point where I just close the game and start over at this encounter.  With these issues which pop up way to often I just cant' recommend it.

It's OK. Pretty braindead, to be honest. I mostly played it while I was too hungover to think.

Music was fine, one or two songs were memorable, the rest are what is best described as "serviceable." I also thought the aesthetics of the game were really dumb, which didn't help my impression of it.

The gameplay can give you this sense that you're doing something at first, but after a while you realize that your creatures and spells rarely synergize in any interesting way. Too much focus was put on the board, maybe. What's left is a game that feels half-deckbuilder, half-tower defense, and isn't very good at either.

It's certainly an overrated game, and I'm not sure why. Whenever I see someone name drop it as "one of the greatest deckbuilders ever" it kind of makes me question the validity of everything they say after.

Solid for about 20 hrs. But the scaling is pretty terrible compared to other roguelike deck builders.

Compared to other better roguelike deckbuilders this is by far inferior to some of the top names in this category like Slay the Spire or Across the Obelisk. Simply put the enemies will get stronger as you play more and unlock higher challenges. But the game fails to give you LITERALLY any actual upgrades. Now most roguelikes don't give you direct upgrades, but the best of them give you ways to reduce variance with your starting hands and loadouts. Without those in place you really wind up rerolling starting setups until you get a set that has the specific things you want for a good run.
Its all right. I don't think I would recommend to people tho.
rank 9 is unbalanced af. needs to be steam deck optimized.

The idea is interesting and learning the game is fun, but the deckbuilding options feel VERY limited. You just pick a strategy at the start (normally based around your champion choice) and then you exclusively pick cards to support that strategy. The choices are pretty limited and you can skip when you don't like the card selection. It doesn't require enough variance or improvisation to make it much more interesting. The secondary clan option is a cool idea on paper but most combinations just don't work together meaningfully enough to be preferable to sticking strictly to your main clan. If you're looking for a deckbuilder with this mix and match concept done well, just get the Packmaster mod for Slay the Spire - lots more fun to be had there.

If you want to try the game, I recommend getting it only on HEAVY discount like I did.

These have to be bot/paid reviews. This is such a shallow game that masquerades as having depth. Anyone comparing this to Slay the Spire is like comparing Halo to Skyrim, oh but aren't they both first person fantasy games where you kill enemies? This game is NOTHING like Slay the Spire except you have cards and you start with 3 mana/energy each turn. That's it.

Damage is the ONLY thing that matters in this game. Sure, the different mechanics can have great use against all the normal enemies, but when it comes to bosses pure damage is the only way to win. And you know what works just as good as all that strategy you used against regular enemies? PURE DAMAGE!

Look, I wanted to like this game as I feel MTG has lost its mind in recent set designs and you have to be rich just to have a *decent* deck. I saw reviews about how awesome this game is and thought hey I could sink my teeth into some nice deck building content right now. But there is no strategy that is going to prepare you for a boss fight that has 1300 HP when most enemies have around 5 to 50 HP and oh you can't play any spells once the boss round starts, so no strategy there, you just have to hope your monsters can somehow deal 20 to 30 times the amount of damage they did when you were taking care of the normal enemies. Oh, and all enemies move first so your monsters will be nice and weakened before the boss starts fighting. I had hope for this game when I had bosses around 300 HP, seemed fair with multiple strategies to make use of, but when you need 4 times the time/damage to kill the boss and your cards aren't 4 times stronger AND you can't even play any healing or damage spells once they start fighting the boss it really just makes all your other cards worthless! Oh, thank you SO much for these 1 mana 2 damage cards! And don't forget about these amazing healing cards to heal ANY single monster for a whole 3 HP all for only 1 mana! They will help SO FUCKING MUCH AGAINST 1300 HP bosses!  Oh and you start with 5 copies each of these worthless cards! Two entire hands that just won't do anything meaningful. Sure, you can upgrade your cards but what is 25HP on my monster going to do against a boss that hits for 18 damage? Oh sure 1 maybe two extra rounds to deal my 30 - 50 damage against a 1300 HP boss, awesome now they have 1200 HP and now they are on the second floor which is already full of monsters I've put there in previous turns so any extra monster cards are deadweight in your hand, but don't worry you get 1 turn to play these junk spell cards that you didn't have time to get rid of or enough money to upgrade and make "useful" (but seriously what is 12 damage gonna do vs 2 damage when, again, there is 1300 HP to get rid of)

I'm going to try this game again sometime after I forget how bad it was. I know I only played one run, but honestly I don't care what else this game has to offer. Apparantly the devs have changed cards multiple time because they know how worthless they were and yet they still keep these worthless starter cards that aren't even useful after the first 2 battles! Slay the Spire was different. I wanted to get farther in the game. I wanted to unlock more stuff. I wanted to try different strategies because they all had depth in that game. Challenging but still fair. Hell, even the starter cards had use in the late game, they were never truly worthless. My suggestion is just don't waste your time with this shallow mobile game garbage.

Oh, and I thought this would be good for steam deck but the battery life is TERRIBLE. I get 7+ hours playing Slay the Spire 90fps and after 2 hours of this garbage game I'm down by 60% battery life! But hey, what do you need optimizations for when mobile devices rival desktop machines from just a few years ago? Just power thru all that terrible code like you have to power thru this terrible game!

The game is less strategy, more grind..
its okay game if cheap, not worth full price
"all of your spells get *consume*" oh wow. great balancing. right. the boss gets to take away all of your spells. no spell deck is viable. u can only rely on creature cards.

Monster Train is close to being good. 

The gameplay loop is simple, you have a starter deck with spells and monster cards that you can incrementally improve between rounds of combat. There are also items you can collect that affect either the board state or your cards. The game plays like a mix of slay the spire and Hearthstone Battlegrounds.

The sad thing is that whilst the game likely has as much content as either of the aforementioned due to the way the macro game has been set up it always feels like your run is just getting started before it ends. The deck building aspect of the game is just too short to enjoy fully. For the rest, it plays like a typical rogue-like with a progression system (you unlock cards/card sets/difficulty levels), just without the enemy variety.  And that is not me being hyperbolic, you will see all the enemies within one run. 

Wouldn't recommend, especially not at full price. Good time waster, music isn't bad, looks like a phone game.

Picked up Monster Train on sale thinking I scored a gem. Visually slick, fast-paced, and packed with roguelike deckbuilding chaosâ€”but it burns out quick. Repetitive runs, bloated mechanics, and balance issues make it more grind than thrill. If you're curious, grab it cheapâ€¦ just donâ€™t expect lasting magic.

Less than the sum of its parts. And frankly speaking, the parts are not great to begin with. 

You should consider directing your Slay the Spire withdrawals elsewhere, else yet a new regret might join your impulse purchases on your Steam library.

There is no way to make any of your cards stronger to start with and just the 1st fight the enemies are strong enough to wipe out your whole team. It's just one big RNG fest to get a good run and waste of time!

I'd like the start this with saying I'm a very competitive player, As a casual gamer I'm sure this game will be a unforgettable experience, The art for the game is truly incredible, the music and audio are some of the best I've heard in any game, The story is one of a kind. However I can't get pass just how truly AFWUL the platforming is, as of writing this I have done everything but the moon berry and collect all golden strawberries and the hitboxes and pure hatred I feel to the late 2 chapters are unmatched. Chapter 8 is easily the worse level in the game not a single hitbox even closely matches anything the fireballs, ice balls, the bumpers, either I clip almost fully inside and don't die, or not even touch the object and die, with no in-between, Every chapter has this issue with the different elements added to each, with not every chapter having issues, the red and blue spikes scattered across the whole game are also poorly implemented citing the same hitbox issues, Something I'd like to say is when the game Isn't railing me from poor hitboxes a lot of the later levels are insanely fun, with chapter 5 c-side being easily my favorite level, but all the hitbox issues and general frustrations, I have with the game that feel out of my control push it to a negative review, but if you actually enjoy playing games without needing challenge and the what not, complete ignore this review, this is a good game, with flaws I can't forgive

This game has too many good reviews, which is why I'm giving it a negative rating. Btw, this game is absolute BANGER.

This game reminded me why I hate precision platformers.

I really wanted to love Celeste. Everyone raves about it... the touching story about mental health, the beautiful pixel art, the soundtrack that's supposedly transcendent. I can see why people connect with Madeline's journey. The anxiety metaphors are thoughtful, the presentation is polished, and there's clearly a lot of heart poured into this game. But no amount of narrative depth can make me enjoy dying 47 times on the same screen because I mistimed a dash by 0.2 seconds.

Precision platformers demand a very specific kind of patience and muscle memory that I simply don't find enjoyable. Every death in Celeste is supposedly a "lesson," and yes, the respawns are lightning-fast, but that doesn't change the fundamental loop: attempt, fail, repeat ad nauseam until your fingers finally cooperate with your brain. It's not that the game is unfair - the controls are tight, the mechanics are clear - it's that this style of gameplay brings out the worst in me. The mounting frustration. The clenched jaw. The "just one more try" that turns into an hour of my life I'll never get back.

The game keeps telling me to "just breathe" while simultaneously designing situations that make me want to throw my controller through a window. There's something almost patronizing about a game that says "you can do this!" while putting strawberries just out of reach, taunting you with collectibles that require frame-perfect execution.

I understand why Celeste resonates with so many people. The metaphor of climbing a mountain as overcoming your inner demons is powerful. But sometimes a mountain is just a mountain, and sometimes I just want to enjoy a game without feeling like I'm studying for a reflex exam.

If you love precision platformers, you'll probably adore this. If you're like me and this genre makes you question your life choices, maybe skip this one.

This game is undoubtedly visually stunning, and I have nothing but respect for the amount of effort that went into creating all of the artwork in this game. I wish I had the same amount of praise for the actual video game itself. For a game that prides itself on it's artwork, it seems obsessed with hiding the character off-screen as much as possible, making simple jumps into leaps of faith. The game also seems to want to be as  Ì¶dÌ¶iÌ¶fÌ¶fÌ¶iÌ¶cÌ¶uÌ¶lÌ¶tÌ¶  annoying as possible: the platforming is unnecessarily pixel perfect in some places, some fights are full of RNG, the two gun options at the start of the game are the only useful ones, the super moves are only useful during the flying sections, just to name a few.

It is with a bit of a heavy heart I am writing this review and it comes with a bit of a specific caveat: 

If you run a Linux system (I guess it'll be the same for Mac users), then rather watch a playthrough than buy this. 

I'll explain, but there will be some spoilers:
The game runs on Proton if you force 10.0-3 or 8.0-5, but that is, unfortunitely, only half the story. 

The game is recommended to be run in Windows mode. [spoiler]This is on purpouse as the game is supposed to add things, launch things and interact with your pc, such as popping a fullscreen background behind the windowed game, or creating a txt file with necessary info for you to look for in a specific folder. [/spoiler]
This all is based on Windows as an OS and none of this works as intended on Linux and completely ruins the intended experience. 
You can hack through it with a guide but you will never experience the game properly - thus the suggestion to watch a playthrough. 

I get that it is an indi developer and generally, I am more sympathetic to indi's, only in this case, the steam page should warn that the game is specifcally for Windows and using any other OS will ruin the experience, but instead you will only find this: 

MINIMUM:
OS: Your favorite Linux distribution
MEMORY: 4 GB RAM
GRAPHICS: OpenGL 2.1 compatible

I was hyped up for something similar to the likes of Undertale/Deltarune. I did not expect it to be Undertale/Deltarune. I tried my best to give it as much space as possible to develop a narrative and tell a compelling story without comparing it to anything. 

The concept and scenario is neat, and it could have been developed much deeper. Instead, it's sadly a drag of a walking simulator where NPCs feel like they have two lines of meaningful dialogue at most before being reduced to pixelated parrots.

The characters do not feel very compelling to me. Most of them feel one-dimensional, serving one purpose and then immediately becoming useless. Niko is alright, but I cannot justify the amount of love they get from the fanbase. May update this if the endings feel more compelling, but as of now it just feels way too forced and even a bit annoying. 

The puzzles were a letdown. The 'meta puzzles' that used the meta narrative of the world being a simulation were maybe a bit easy but also technically fun or unexpected. I didn't enjoy being jeered at by the computer when a file failed to initialize until a restart or when the background puzzle just straight up didn't function. (had to look that one up) The in-world puzzles like crafting or showing items to NPCs was time consuming, and a lot of item interactions you'd expect to give some kind of dialogue just end up doing nothing. 

Small gripes:
- Water pill felt really dumb. 
- Not being able to backtrack sections is annoying but an acceptable design decision. I guess it just makes you play again if you want achievements and don't already know what to do in the next section before you even see it. 
- PLEASE let me skip repeat dialogue. 
- Why can't we fast travel between upper and lower city?

TL;DR: Tedious walking simulator without much character or mechanical depth. Neat-ish at best, annoying at worst.

(Edit: view the review by user d3sirio, they got pretty much exactly how I felt about the game in a much more eloquent way.)

Some more OneShot rage bait: When I bought OneShot I thought I was going to get the next Undertale, but instead I got the diet off-brand coke version of Undertale with a "messing with your computer" gimmick that locks from being able to play the game on Linux. 

But in all seriousness, although the game was interesting, I wouldn't recommend it. Maybe my bar was too high, but the puzzles were awful, the music was mid, the characters felt two-dimensional (but are cute which is probably why people obsess over them), and the story was okay, I mean I didn't dislike the story but I also forgot most of it so that might just be me. This could very well be the result of overly high expectations, since I was expecting something with great music, a great story etc. but it really just felt superficial if that makes sense? I was also expecting a much longer and detailed story. which yeah to be fair, there are some shorter masterpieces out there like Chrono Trigger, but the story in this game felt cut off in an odd way. 

Anyway, I know people love this game and will probably clown on this review, but it's my very subjective opinion based on my experience of the game, and might help someone get an idea as to what to expect (while comparing and contrasting other reviews to get a more objective view of what to expect)

Hmm, I'm not really sure what the big deal is about this game. There are some clever, but slightly gimmicky game mechanics that break the 4th wall, not going to say more than that... but overall it was a meh game. I wanted to like it but I think it left a lot to be desired. I feel like there were some elements of the game that once you move on to another map, you can't go back and try and complete the previous sections which feel annoying. Also I generally like games where there's a kind of meta-story going on, about the player, about control, about the consequences of the player's decisions, but this didn't really have the impact and pay-off that I was looking forward to. game literally doesn't work, files that you need to look at to solve puzzles don't generate. tried uninstalling, reinstalling, viewing hidden files, verifying the game files, literally everything that I can think of. Nothing works, so the game is actually softlocked. I've looked up guides one where it's supposed to be, videos, which led to forum posts and there were no solutions to be found. I closed the game to see if that would cause the files to populate, not only did that not work, it didn't save, and sent me back about half an hour.
If you're going to do fourth wall breaks and make me dig in game files to get the game to progress. Make sure it works. This is a problem that goes back all the way to when the game first released and despite multiple forum posts from the Dev that they are looking into it, and that it will be fixed, it hasn't after almost ten years.

I probably would have liked the game a lot better had I not gone in with so much expectation. I mean it was among the highest rated games on Steam, so I was expecting to be blown away. What I got was a completely fine and serviceable game, but nowhere near phenomenal like I thought it would be. The characters in this world feels so shallow and one dimensional, and even Niko the protagonist isn't all that interesting. Supposedly it should make me feel emotional, but how could I when I couldn't form any real connection to any of the characters? The plot is predictable and just breaks its rules whenever it wants. [spoiler]The Entity spent the entire game convinced (rightfully so) that it's just a piece of code and cannot grow beyond its own programming, that the entire world is just a simulation generated each time I boot up the game. Then at the true ending, it suddenly becomes convinced that no actually, it might have free will after all because this true ending session is some path that was not in the original code. But then I, as the player, know that at the end of the day, this is still code and 0 and 1 and is just another game session like any previous game session. So does the game want to be meta or not?[/spoiler]

My biggest gripe yet though, is the size of the map of the game. The map a lot of the time is just a giant repetitive pattern with a few interactable NPCs scattered here and there, and they all say the same things just worded a bit differently. Some areas are connected by long walkways with, again, nothing to look at. Just cut out those walkway altogether and have them be connected directly, please, or have the walkway shorter, I dunno. Exploring doesn't really reward you with anything. You would think they would utilize some of those space for world building.

If you hate your friends, then this is the gift that keeps on giving. Heed the warning: Play with emotional vigilance and mental patience.

[b] disclaimer: i did not finish this game (because i didn't have fun) [/b]

that being said, i don't think that invalidates my opinion. i've spent enough time on this game to know if its worth any more or not. i also want to say that i didn't get mad playing this game! i just genuinely have problems with how the game actually plays out, not issues with my own skill (?). i am only judging the game by the base content.

[h1] why do i not like this game? [/h1]

i typically enjoy games like this. i enjoyed beating getting over it, peaks of yore was a lot of fun (until the final mountain), and i have over 2000 hours tracked on geometry dash, i've spent easily hundreds of hours aim-training. i enjoy the struggle of improving at games.

so why's this one different for me?

well, i think that it (mainly) comes down to one big difference separating this game from all of the others: you can't react to your gameplay. what do i mean by that?

well, all of the games i mentioned (except jump king) all have the ability to react to your gameplay; you are in complete control. 
[list]
[*] your crosshair misses the target (aim training)? micro-adjust onto the head before shooting.
[*] you mistimed your jump off of a rock (peaks of yore)? you could use crampons to break your falling momentum and grab back onto something to fix your mistake.
[*] even in getting over it--you could make a mistake, but if you know what you're doing, you could find something to latch your hammer onto instead of watching your progress crash and burn in front of your eyes.
[*] geometry dash, for the most part, has pretty one-dimensional gameplay, but it has something great that makes it actually enjoyable! visual indication of when to click--it allows you to not rely [b] solely [/b] on muscle memory, and instead, look at the screen. even then, when flying with the ship gamemode, if you can tell that you're lower than you should be, you could hold click for a split-second longer to course-correct. being able to set checkpoints is also amazing; it makes games feel so much more fair.
[/list]
in jump king, if you fuck up, you can't save yourself. it's awfully punishing for a game that has NO indication of how far/high you're actually jumping. that essentially means that i didn't find jump king skillful.

when i was playing, i found that, yes, jumps got easier after a few falls, but my consistency with them would eventually plateau. why? well, because it's entirely muscle memory. obviously, for new jumps, you don't use muscle memory, but for any others, you could not be focused on the game, and be just as likely to clear a difficult jump as if you were focused.

i (also) found the game mind-numbingly boring to play. because the game doesn't actually require any focus, it doesn't use any of my attention. for probably about 3 of my 4.3 hours, i was listening to music; i could be completely unfocused on the game and be just as consistent as if i paused my music to focus more.

all you do in jump king is memorise positions to jump from and let your muscle memory work on how long to hold the spacebar down for. then, you hope that your brain was feeling generous enough that you jumped the right amount.

yes, i'm sure that this game gets more consistent, people wouldn't play it if it didn't. but, at the same time, i don't care! the game isn't fun to play, and the idea of sitting through just one more hour of this game makes me dread existing entirely. this game, essentially, feels less about mastery, and more about mindlessly playing until things click--i get that these two typically go hand-in-hand, but, to me, 'mastery' feels more like working hard and dedicating yourself to something, when jump king is more like a slog of sitting at your desk and staring at a screen until your eyes gloss over.

that being said, there's no way to improve the game without compromising the actual difficulty of it (if there is any real challenge). a visual indication, like a jump strength bar, would be amazing, and make the game FAR more consistent and enjoyable to play. however, it would also definitely make the game easier. the intention of the game was to be 'difficult', with the thought of fun gameplay coming far behind.

i know i'm reiterating, but i very much dislike calling the game 'difficult'. anyone could beat this just by playing it a lot, without really thinking about what they're doing; you can't do that with an actual skill, like piano, which would take a lot more focus and thought in your playing.

[h1] what do i like out of this game? [/h1]

i'm not going to deny that the art style is fantastic--it looks really good, and isn't too obtrusive to how the game plays. i think it's really good, and i can tell that there's thought behind the colouring to make sure that the next place to jump to stands out from the rest of the environment.

that's about it for my praise of the game though; at the end of the day, there really isn't much to pick apart about a game as simplistic as this. 

[h2] tl;dr: [/h2] i don't want to dislike this game; i like the art style, but the enjoyability of it unfortunately feels like an afterthought, behind the desire to make as 'difficult' of a game as possible. the actual jumping mechanic feels too much like muscle memory and not enough like skill to pass off as a truly challenging and fair game to me.

at the end of the day, it's a personal gripe that i'm sure other people won't mind as much. but, as it stands, i wouldn't recommend this game.

[h2] edit: [/h2] i just recompleted getting over it; god, it was a lot more fun than this game. i've come to realise that it's not only the lack of complete control in your gameplay that makes jump king worse, but also the fact that the movement is so incredibly un-dynamic. getting over it feels different every single time you play it (up to a certain point obviously), where there are multiple ways you can tackle each jump. it's a lot more fun compared to the simplicity of jump king, and allows for not only a fun first experience, but a more replayable one as well.

as well as that, i realised that this game feels far too punishing. getting over it is actually very fair, and it chooses to teach new mechanics in a safe environment without a large risk of falling; jump king doesn't do this at all. in fact, for the wind section, i would say that the few screens just under it (which you fall to a lot), are the hardest screens in the game up to that point.

recommend the game even less now.
this game gave me suicidal thoughts

Altough Foddian games can often look like the're designed to be hated, they don't have to be. 

Just like in Getting Over It, you get the streamer/youtuber rage and frustration moments in Jump King that contribute to its popularity. However, Getting Over It also rewards the player for their efforts by allowing them to really utilise what they learn. The part in the beginning of the game that you struggled with for so long will suddenly feel like a brease. You'll make quicker and quicker movement with your hammer, and seeing how far you've come is the motivation that pushes you towards completing the game.

Jump King doesn't have this. The whole gameplay relies on memorizing which spots you jump from and how long you'll need to hold space bar for each spot. The only difficulty is how long you hold the space bar. As a big fan of Geometry Dash, it is impressive how dull this feels to me. Your skill isn't rewarded by cooler more complex movement. It is all just consistency in doing the exakt thing over and over, and it is always the same two outcomes: you fall or you make it. Compare this to Getting Over It, which has a lot more unpredictability and forces you to do quick problem solving in panic, which often can lead to many cool and unique moments.

How fun the gameplay is can often be seen in its speedruns (Celeste, Mario Oddesey, Hollow Knight). Getting Over It has some of the coolest runs I've seen in speedrunning, while Jump King's speedruns look the same as any run, except they don't fall. The few shortcuts that are made and the absence of standing still are the only things that reminds you that it is an actual speedrun.

Jump King is beautiful and the story is funny, but it doesn't have the self awereness and humour that made Getting Over It such a good introduction to these types of games. Bennet will constantly talk in a calm voice in Getting over it, especially after a large fall, since he's awere of how frustrating and stupid the game can feel. He talks as if he's discussing a fine art piece, which only adds to the comedy.

Maybe it all comes down to the fact that I beat Getting Over It and didn't beat this game, but since I ralely give negative reviews and tend to like all games I play, I thought I'd elaborate. Although I'm sure the feeling of finally beating the game probably feels fantastic, I personally don't think it is worth it if the journey feels so bad. And I think that that is probably the hardest challange to get over in the entirety of Jump King. There's no motivation. I'd rather work towards other Steam achivments.

[quote][b]For Kids games are asset flips [/b][/quote]

[b]But what is an asset flip and why is it so important or even bad?[/b]

[quote=Wikipedia] An [url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_flip]asset flip[/url] is a type of shovelware in which a video game developer purchases pre-made assets and uses them to create numerous permutations of generic games to sell at low prices. Such games tend to be viewed by gamers as uncreative, and as diverting attention from less popular high-quality titles. Asset flips have been noted to be a problem on many online distribution platforms, especially Steam. The Nintendo Switch eShop has also been accused of allowing the sale of asset flips. [/quote]

Asset flipping is a term applied to the practice of buying or using basic, pre-made/pre-rendered assets in video game development, without changing them or adding original assets around them. Often used as a pejorative term, and generally consider games made using poorly considered, flipped assets to be shovelware.
For example, say you're a beginner who wants to develop a game in Unity or a similar development engine. If you're a novice, you might buy some assets or a demo game from the Unity Asset Store to use as a foundation for building your first game. Assets like this can also help you have a pre-made world, so you can focus on other areas of expertise, like game physics or enemy AI.

Using assets in this way is fine. In fact, using pre-made assets to make your game is also fine, as long as your game is actually playable. If you've ironed out any glitches, created some nice atmospheric effects, and your characters and NPCs work in harmony, then there's no reason you shouldn't market your game.
However, just throwing a bunch of assets together that don't work, or simply renaming a demo intended as a foundation, in order to just make a game quickly and then market it with no thought, is when asset flipping becomes a nefarious practice.

Basically, there is nothing wrong with using or buying a pre-built asset to use in games.

[b]But if it is offered 1:1 or barely changed as a new game, then it is definitely an asset flip or, in other words, a fake game that only serves to take money out of people's pockets.

And if I'm honest, in this case it really annoys me. On the one hand, because I enjoyed playing some of the games myself as simple games for in between and, on the other hand, because I have recommended many of these games to other parents in order to introduce younger children to the medium of computers and the Internet. It's a shame that the small children's sector is also shamelessly exploited to make money.[/b]

In this case, or as far as all "My Coloring Book" games are concerned, For Kids has the Unity [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/paint-book-unity-complete-project-90736 ]Paint Book Unity Complete Project[/url] and simply gave the whole thing a new name.

[b]This also applies to the following, for example:[/b]

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/763760/My_Coloring_Book_Food_and_Beverage/]My Coloring Book: Food and Beverage[/url]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/739210/My_Coloring_Book_Transport/]My Coloring Book: Transport[/url]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/721430/My_Coloring_Book_Animals/]My Coloring Book: Animals[/url]

Since these games sell well and at ~$4 cannot be described as cheap like many other asset flips, you can calculate how much money For Kids makes here without doing anything for it.

[b]And For Kids almost takes it to the extreme in this regard.[/b]

Here are a few more examples where For Kids used Unity assets and shamelessly copied and published them 1:1:

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/884770/Astro_Bouncer/]Astro Bouncer[/url] and the associated [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/astro- bouncer-game-template-27260]Asset[/url]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/722250/Feeding_The_Monster/]Feeding The Monster[/url] and the associated [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/feeding-the -monster-97892]Asset[/url]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/698300/Find_this/]Find this![/url] and the associated [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/systems/hidden -object-game-template-19394]Asset[/url]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/696460/Pixel_Traffic_Circle_Rush/]Pixel Traffic: Circle Rush[/url] and the associated [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs /circle-crash-88702]Asset[/url]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/712380/Temple_Escape/]Temple Escape[/url] and the associated [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/temple- escape-95339]Asset[/url]

And there would be more examples ...

Of course, it's up to everyone whether you buy such games or not.

However, it is and remains unethical because it is theft of intellectual property and is essentially nothing more than a cash grab, which also violates the license agreements and terms of use.

In addition, it is simply harmful for the entire games industry and especially for all the indie game developers who often get lost in the mass of such asset flips, which is really a shame.

Review date: January 18, 2024

[b][quote][url=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asset_flip]Warning: Asset Flip![/url][/quote][/b]

My Coloring Book: Professions is a Unity Asset flip, what Valve calls a "fake game".  The "developer", For Kids, took the [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/paint-book-unity-complete-project-90736]Paint Book Complete Project[/url] Unity Store tutorial/demo/game asset pack from the real developers, Digi Smile Limited, changed the name, and dumped the result onto Steam.  They're attempting to scam people into buying this, so they can get your money for someone else's work.

It gets worse... "Paint Book Complete Project" has also been shamelessly dumped on Steam by For Kids, with different stolen artwork:
[list]
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/763760]My Coloring Book: Food and Beverage[/url]"
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/739210]My Coloring Book: Transport[/url]"
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/721430]My Coloring Book: Animals[/url]"
[/list]
Take a look for yourself... these are all [i]exactly the same stolen asset![/i]

For Kids has shown a repeat pattern of unethically dumping other people's work onto Steam as a cheap, nasty cash grab. Here's some examples so you can see for yourself:
[list]
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/884770]Astro Bouncer[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/astro-bouncer-game-template-27260]Astro Bouncer Game Template[/url] developed by Puppeteer
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/722250]Feeding The Monster[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/feeding-the-monster-97892]Feeding The Monster[/url] developed by Sasha Gorec
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/698300]Find This![/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/systems/hidden-object-game-template-19394]Hidden Object Game Template[/url] developed by Puppeteer
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/721430]My Coloring Book: Animals[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/paint-book-unity-complete-project-90736]Paint Book Complete Project[/url] developed by Digi Smile Limited
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/763760]My Coloring Book: Food and Beverage[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/paint-book-unity-complete-project-90736]Paint Book Complete Project[/url] developed by Digi Smile Limited
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/739210]My Coloring Book: Transport[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/paint-book-unity-complete-project-90736]Paint Book Complete Project[/url] developed by Digi Smile Limited
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/703210]My Little Worms[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/dashy-worm-multi-touch-mobile-arcade-93511]Dashy Worms[/url] developed by SgLib Games
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/704440]Nimble Fish[/url]" = [url=https://forum.unity.com/threads/released-2d-endless-fish-runner-2d-endless-runner-game-with-increasing-difficulty.399458/]2D Endless Fish Runner[/url] developed by 1RadMan
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/696460]Pixel Traffic: Circle Rush[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/circle-crash-88702]Circle Crash[/url] developed by SgLib Games
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/867730]Pixel Traffic: Highway Racing[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/crashy-racing-115748]Crashy Racing full game pack[/url] developed by SgLib games
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/699750]Pixel Traffic: Risky Bridge[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/crossy-bridge-79760]Crossy Bridge Game Template[/url] developed by SgLib Games
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/763770]Space Stories: Darth Star[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/planetary-defence-104099]Planetary Defence game pack[/url] developed by Daniel Buckley
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/712380]Temple Escape[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/temple-escape-95339]Temple Escape[/url] developed by SgLib games
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/885240]Tower Stacker[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/systems/tower-stacker-game-template-57257]Tower Stacker Game Template[/url] developed by Puppeteer
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/713050]Vampires![/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/thirsty-vampire-97767]Thirsty Vampire[/url] developed by Code Master Studio
    [*] "[url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/698330]Z Runaway[/url]" = [url=https://assetstore.unity.com/packages/templates/packs/zigzag-infinite-runner-game-100035]ZigZag Infinite Runner Game[/url] developed by Puppeteer
[/list]

Because this is an almost exact 1:1 copy + paste of the original Unity asset, it's in violation of the [url=https://unity.com/legal/as-terms]Unity Asset Store Terms of Service and EULA[/url].  Specifically, Section 2, Subsection 2.2.1a:

[quote][i]Subject to the restrictions set forth in this EULA, Licensor hereby grants to the END-USER a non-exclusive, non-transferable, worldwide, and perpetual license to the Asset solely:(a) to incorporate the Asset, [b]together with substantial, original content not obtained through the Unity Asset Store[/b], into an electronic application or digital media that has a purpose, features, and functions beyond the display, performance, distribution, or use of Assets ("Licensed Product") as an embedded component of that Licensed Product, [b]such that the Asset does not comprise a substantial portion of the Licensed Product[/b][/i][/quote]

Because the developer misused the asset pack such that it comprises the vast majority of this "game", the developer has unethically and deliberately breached the license agreement.  Worse, this intellectual property violation was done in an attempt to profit from their illicit actions.  Why is this permitted on Steam?

The products that result from asset flips aren't "real" games.  They lack depth and content, because they're just simplistic copies of demos or tutorials.  In this case, "Paint Book Complete Project" is just a simple click-to-colour virtual colouring book template for mobile apps, and doesn't have any merit as a proper, fully fledged PC game, so this copy+paste of it can't be recommended.

Asset flips don't involve any professional game development.  Sure, sometimes they may change a few cosmetic things, swap out different assets etc, but at heart it's functionally identical to the asset they're ripping off.

Asset flips like this are harmful to the gaming industry and to Steam because they reduce the visibility that sincerely made indie games should have, and make it harder for gamers to find real games from genuine developers.

Another important Note: For Kids have been caught using fake reviews on their games in an attempt to mislead gamers by creating a fake positive review score.  The reviews are all from known/compromised pay-per-review accounts, all in Russian or broken English, and show as Steam purchasers (to make the fake reviews count).  The fake reviews are all posted within roughly 24 hours of each other, and usually shortly after the game launch.  There's no evidence of fake reviews on this game, but that may change in future.  Gamers have a right to know when developers act in a highly unethical manner.

Don't reward this morally bankrupt, unethical behaviour from For Kids.

The most overrated roguelite of all time and it's not even close. I'm not sure what it is, I don't understand why, but I feel like this game gets tons of praise that I just don't get. I won't deny visually the game is definitely pretty to look at, but it doesn't really stand out much to me. Not much in this game stands out to me. Tons of cosmetics, tons of weapons, tons of utilities, tons of unlocks, tons of additional things you can get too like bombs or traps; it almost feels, dare I say, bloated. To me personally. But I wonder, why do I love having a ton of unlocks in games like Tboi or Ror2, but with this game I don't care for some reason? I think there may just be something in the core of this game that I don't like.

Some things I just straight up don't like: Level progression. This game's progression across levels feels so, so painfully muddled, and nonlinear. This could be something that very well might be fixed after playing the game for long enough, but dude, it's been 29, almost 30 hours of playtime as of right now. Why do I still not understand how I'm getting to like 70% of the levels I'm in. You start at level 1, then there's the two different level 2's, and then around each of those there's like 5 more levels that, I'm gonna be real, I can't even tell if they're actual main levels or just alternate areas. What the fuck is happening. I've probably been to like 10 different areas in the game so far. If you put a million dollars on the line, and put me in 7 of those areas and asked me "Where are you in the game right now?", I still could not give you a straight answer. It's just very needlessly over complicated.

I never cared too much for the combat either. I try to block enemies, but parry timing doesn't feel right that often. This could very well be a me thing but combat just feels very clunky, ESPECIALLY in the later levels when there's more enemies that have more complex and unpredictable attacks that are additionally sometimes stacked on top of each other. It's not the type of thing where enemies take turns either, shit will just attack you and that makes parrying so much harder. On top of this at the end of each level you have one mutation to pick, from a list of like 50+. It's just numbers. It's just a bunch of numbers, more damage when you do this, blocking does this, this ranged stuff is a little better, nothing stands out. It just all feels so lame and not unique or impactful enough at all. That's how a lot of stuff in this game feels for me, just a lot of Quantity > Quality, honestly.

If it sounds like I'm hating just to hate, I definitely get that don't get me wrong, but believe me, I'm not. I am STILL, from time and time again, coming back to this game and playing it for a bit, just to see if something sticks. As of right now though nothing has really grabbed my attention too much from this game. Nothing specific from it has made me truly yearn to come back to it, like a really cool weapon or gimmick or something. I'm just trying to find SOMETHING here, okay? I'm really trying, I promise. I see this game get a lot of positive reception, I want to understand it. This game's probably a better metroidvania than a roguelite honestly, and if that's your jam then that's awesome, dude. I may just not be that big of a fan of metroidvanias. As a big roguelite guy I wouldn't personally recommend it but that's just from my own personal taste.

What the game wants you to do (explore, listen, reflect, ponder) and what the actual game forces you to do (run around like a headless chicken because you only have a literal minute to interact with whatever the random number gods grant you and hope THIS time it will be enough to let you proceed to the next unskippable cutscene) are very different things and at odds with each other. Neither is enough.

Despite what others have said about how much of an immersive experience this might be, I was simply not compelled to play this for more than I did. Deeply disappointed seeing as this would be a scenario I would love to explore deeply on a game like this. Its an interesting concept, but as a game? Not fun. And I really wanted to like this game too...

(Edit: I may come back to this game at some point and give it another chance. If this happens I hope this changes my view on this game into a positive one.)

Continue?9876543210 is literally the most depressing game I've ever played. I don't mean it's just sad, or disheartening, or bad, or deep. It's one of the only pieces of media I've ever experienced that, without fail, makes me feel worse every time I play it. I can read tragic stuff, I can watch sad movies, whatever- occasionally I might even feel teary-eyed- but only Continue? actually makes me feel actually mentally distressed.

In Continue?, you play as the data ghost of one of several failed video game characters, destined for deletion by some sort of cyberspace garbage compactor. In order to survive, you must flee through these strange recycled realms, where everybody talks in an eerie, vaguely poetic dialect of english, mixing terms of faith and hope with computer and video game terminology. Your currency is "Foo" (or possibly "fod", given the somewhat ambiguous font); your extra lives are "Spare Parts". And, most importantly, you are frequently given the choice between two options- "Lightning" and "Prayer". Every time you choose to take Prayer, you create an extra layer of defence at your next gateway town, meaning Prayer is vital to your success in the game. Every time you choose to take Lightning, you randomly destroy some of the barriers blocking your progress to the next level, making Lightning vital to your success in the game.

The game actually has a really great atmosphere- of inevitable doom and the futility of struggling further. I presume this is the intended effect, because it's actually pretty haunting. Some of the "lore", barely comprehensible as it is, actually sticks with you after playing it, the poems and the "prayers" of the NPCs you speak to genuinely some impressive alternative writing. The sound and level design also puts forward this idea, especially in the zones between certain levels.

The other thing that contributes to the feeling of dread and nihilistic despair, however, is the gameplay. In order to survive, you must collect Lightning and Prayer, and the game is utterly unforgiving. If you die without a Spare Part to revive yourself, then the game gives you a "second chance" by consuming some of the shelters you earned with Prayer. This is, essentially, just a way of making you suffer more. Losing even a few shelters will result in a game over once the storm comes. The rest of the game is a mixture of slightly janky minigames (which punish you harshly for losing, making taking part in the encounters a tense gamble) and a race against the clock to find NPCs to talk to to gain resources from. Several of the NPC interactions are basically just random chance- there are temples, for instance, which reward you for providing the right answer to an abstract and unknowable riddle. If one of the NPCs you met in this run told you the answer, then, so long as you remember it, you can pass the test and gain a large amount of Lightning or Prayer. If, however, you weren't fortunate enough to run into that NPC yet, then you have to either guess or leave, having wasted some of your very limited amount of time in the overworld before it begins randomly collapsing again. 

If you're feeling charitable, you could argue that the clunky gameplay is part of the metaphor- the challenges we face are random because our lives are not designed for us to succeed in. The controls are imprecise because really, how much control do we have over our lives? Or something like that. Alternatively, your character just handles really badly because the game's a bit shoddily programmed.

As an artistic endeavour, Continue? is actually pretty impressive. It's also the most insidiously soul-destroying experience available to you on Steam, which is why I can't really recommend it. Continue? never gives you any answer or comfort about the existential dread it wields- your character is doomed, just as you are doomed, to be erased and become nothing. Some people describe something similar about Dark Souls- sorry for bringing it up- but at least in Dark Souls it's possible to at least kind of achieve something. Continue? presents a world where the player is utterly alone and totally abandoned, faced with an unfair challenge to extend their miserable existence by approximately a couple of hours if they succeed.

But it sucks to play. As countless people have said youll die a lot. Because its designed that way. There is no - "oops i got hit here, aw darn i got hit there, aw shoot i got hit a third time i died. Ill do better next time" Every enemy and damage scaling is 99% all instakills. Theres practically no iframes or nonexistent. Every enemy except for the first bandit you meet shoots enough bullets to instakill you. Most enemies spam a barrage of bullets. 
It doesnt matter how "good" you are. Enemies and explosive objects can and will spawn within melee range of you the second you load into a new map. 

You can go untouched for half the game only to spawn on the next level with an enemy configuration that is impossible to avoid instadeath. 

Christ. The boss will spawn in the same 3x3 room you spawn in two seconds after starting the level.
I like challenging content. But the map can spawn in any possibly way with no filter. I dont find that fun or challenging. Most of my deaths i load into the next map and gasp because i just got instakilled and dont know why.  Thats not fun or challenging. Its nonsense. 

How does someone improve or get better? 

I spawned and three shotgun snipers were shooting at me and two salamanders were shooting their cone of fire - instakill

I spawn in a 3x3 with two dozen enemies outside already shooting me, boss spawns in my 3x3 before i even walk out - instakilled

I spawn in an corner and theres an explosive barrel next to me, and 5 enemies already shooting me - instakilled

I spawn in the sewer in a 3x3 with a toxic barrel in front of the walkway, and enemy shoots it 2 seconds after spawning - instakilled

[h1]Hades 2 is a "good game". Hades 2 is a horrible sequel[/h1]

I waited a long time to write up my review of Hades 2. I went to play on launch and it just didn't feel right. So I slept on it. It's a Supergiant game, they've earned the benefit of my doubt.
So I play Hades 2 again, made a little more progress and still just...wasn't enjoying the game. Now, I've played every Supergiant game, I've bought Bastion on more platforms than I can remember, I [i]even played Pyre[/i] but Hades 2...it just left a terrible taste in my mouth when I played it. Factually Hades 2 deserves more than 14.4 hours of a review but I just can't wrap my head around the hype and accolades around this game. Did I play the same game everyone else did? Did everyone play Hades 1? Hades 2 goes out of its way to spit in my cereal for liking Hades 1.

[h2]Hades 2 has nowhere to be and hopes you don't either[/h2]
God this game is [i]SO SLOW[/i]. [b]First[/b] and most noticeably the combat has been slowed to a crawl. You get a singular dash now. Forever. No upgrade no boons to give you more. You also have no ranged cast as you would in the first game, now you have an AoE cast* that traps enemies in its area and that means you are either standing where your cast was dropped or you have crowd controlled a group with it and will have to come back and finish that group. Imo, the first Hades was an edge of your seat, frenetic wonderland of fast runs. The only thing stopping you from exiting a room was how fast you could clear the enemies. You could kill bosses before they entered invulnerability! Here in Hades 2 you wait. You wait patiently for your turn, get some attacks in and then get back to waiting. God help you when you get to the Fields of Mourning! *yes I know you can upgrade your cast with boons and change it slightly but never in a way as dynamic as your casts in H1.

[b]Secondly[/b] they added more dialogue. Isn't that good? Yes! and no. In previous games the stellar interactions were a cherry on top between the excellent gameplay stretches. They felt like a reward for making it wherever you were.  I'm unsure when SPG started being known for the writing/VO first and gameplay second (it was Hades 1. Hades 1 had great dialogue AND gameplay and the fanbase just coming in to Hades latched onto the dialogue) but why is the camera panning up and Artemis is singing to me and telling Mel to join in?? Do you know when you got a song in Hades 1? When you earned it by god damn bringing your Mother back to the Underworld, not because you died in the second room of the first area and you just pet your frog. Someone wished for more conversations and boy that monkey paw curled up. Everyone is SO VERBOSE, there's this shade who replaces Hypnos when you die (jk you never die in H2 ;) return to shadow~) and honest to god I've never read an entire conversation from her. I'll walk over to start a new run and [u]dread[/u] seeing a '!' above Nemesis because I know she's going to bend my ear for the next 7 minutes calling me a dumbass shithead for trying to fight Chronos. Simple solution then, don't talk to NPCs, but talking to NPCs and seeing interactions has always been fun in SPG games- there is just SO. MUCH. here. 
And tying the two points together: [b]Bosses are SO quirky and have so much witty dialogue they just HAVE to share BEFORE the fight[/b]. You just want to play the game you bought and have fun but Scylla just won't shuttt uppp and you hover over the refund button but the game deserves a fair shot and aaaaHHHHHHH

[h2]The Field of Mourning[/h2]
Are you serious? This whole level just blows plain and simple. You have an open map, not many discerning features, colors are basically the same everywhere and you have to [u]find[/u] the boons scattered around the [u]empty map[/u] which will then open the exit you must then find in the empty map. Wasn't Hades 1 a fast rip roaring good time? Time to SLOW DOWN. This game has no respect for your time, it is just so slow all the time. Yes, you get a ritual spell that shows you a guide light that *kind of* works (maybe im colorblind i just cant see it) to lead you around the Field of Mourning, but you won't have that spell the first time you go there, and you might not for a few runs!

[h2]Melinoe is a pimp, fuck Zagreus, fuck Hades and fuck Cerberus[/h2]
Okay so this section is going from "I do not enjoy this game" to "I have been called a fool by a studio I've supported for 15 years." Famously, Supergiant hasn't ever made a sequel. They wrap a game and start up a new project that feels seperate from their other works with it's own ideas. Hades 2 straight up does not feel like a sequel to Hades. It feels like they took whatever project they had in line next (slow, methodical gameplay) and took the name recognition, shuffled some characters around in the background to appeal to veteran players and if you happened to prefer those other characters to these new shiny ones, you are an asshole.
When I play a game I tend to put myself in the shoes of the protagonist, many people do I'd wager, and this game tells you to your face: "everything you did was for nothing. The family and kingdom you brought back together has fallen asunder to a character you never even knew was a player- your time was a waste." That doesn't sit well with me personally, but the BIGGEST disrepect SPG has done to their player base involves the third boss. IYKYK but [spoiler]are you fucking kidding me? It's Cerberus, it really actually is Cerberus. Not a shade or some magic whatever or totally unrelated creature but fucking CERBERUS. Zagreus' dog, that you were LITERALLY UNABLE TO INJURE every single run in Hades, you had to go out of your way and find treats to make him move, now HAS to be killed in every single run of Hades 2. And guess what, when you beat the game and everything is asspulled back together, you STILL have to kill Cerberus in every single run post story[/spoiler]. Honestly whoever made that call can go right to hell, that genuinely feels like a slap in the face. And gotta be honest, I didn't beat Chronos! I read a comment detailing the absolutely ridiculous wet fart of an ending that they're already patching out as the true ending and just felt fully deflated.
I give up, for the first time I will not finish a Supergiant game. I will not buy the next Supergiant game no questions asked as I have since Bastion. And (almost) in closing, I've ridden the company Supergiant Games quite unfairly in my review and that just comes from a place of disappointment. I'm truly grateful for all the good years I've spent playing Supergiant Games and I hope their next project is out of this world.

Hades 2 is a good game. I cannot sit here and tell you it's bad. Mechanically it shines, the gameplay is tight and fluid; truly if this was called Melinoe and wasn't [i]directly tied[/i] I wouldn't view it with such vitriol. But it is. This is Hades 2 so it must be compared to Hades 1. There is so much [b]MORE[/b] in Hades 2, the scope is so much more [u]IMMENSE[/u], everything is much [i]RICHER[/i] and sadly, it is inferior in every way to the less of the original.
[h3]The best part about Hades 2 is that I can go play Hades[/h3]

unfortunately still not that good, and infrequent updates aren't helping. most recent update has a note regarding fireteam ai using new pathfinding and reducing instances of friendly ai stepping in front of you. now not only do they still step in front of you and get in your way, they do it while facing the wrong way, allowing themselves to be shot by friend and foe alike. they also just don't clear rooms anymore. i had several ai teammates die on the sniper mission because they simply chose to stand in a spot the sniper could shoot them, and ignored commands to move. aside from ai, shooting is really inconsistent and doesn't feel very good, which is kind of the point of the game. great concept, hell of a miss.

For some reason they completely changed how commanding the AI team works and it's more frustrating and cumbersome than the previous implementation. Instead of just quickly looking in a general area and pressing the individual button for your team to "Clear" or "Suppress", you now have to hold a button down, look around for the specific command that's floating near where you're looking, make sure you hover over the exact spot until it turns green, and then release it. The majority of the time the option "Clear Room" doesn't come up and only says "Suppress", so instead of having my team go and clear a room I'm stuck fidgeting with the controls for 10 seconds figuring out the exact spot to stand to make "Clear Room" pop up. The locations of the options are also frustrating, making me take my focus off something I want to focus on, to then "I Spy" a floating command somewhere in the environment. Very frustrating, I don't understand why they even made the change in the first place. 
The entirety of the new control mechanism for the team AI makes it feel like I'm micromanaging them instead of efficiently leading them, they don't function autonomously and have to wait for you to give them every command. Incredibly frustrating

Edit: I'd say around 99% of the time the option I want to choose doesn't even pop up. Please let us revert to the old method, it was so much better.

I'd hold off and buy it on a big sale. It's ambitious and in the past it's been a blast, but it really just feels like a tech demo passed off as an early access at this point, as the devs are radio silent for months at a time only to deliver sub par updates missing promised features and noticeably degrading performance and experience.

The last update, for example, while improving AI pathfinding navigating rooms and finding firing angles, now causes the AI to enter rooms by walking in backwards. 

"Breach and clear!" I shout, watching in confusion as my Marines about face and waddle backwards into the small Iraqi bedroom occupied by three guys with pkms aimed at the door. And that's if I'm lucky enough to have them move at all instead of just staring at me like I spoke Chinese to them as the AI tries and fails to find a path that it likes.

Fun game, and the procedural generation can carry it for at least 20 hours of solid gameplay, but I can't recommend buying it at full price until the devs get their shit together.

This isn't terrible by any stretch, yet the general blandness of the color palette, lackluster enemy variety, and generally uninspired nature of the maps hurts the replay value. If you're of the mind to unlock everything, the gameplay and aesthetic quickly turns the game into a chore. I don't know how many times I've looked at the clock, not excited to be close to clearing the map, but rather regretting to see how many more minutes of playtime I had left to march through. That phenomenon never happened in Vampire Survivors.
          The aiming and reloading mechanics just remind me that I could be playing Crimsonland. The upgrade paths are underwhelming compared to some other games of this style I've played, and don't lend a great deal of satisfaction as you get deeper into a stage.
           I'm sure I've sounded harsh up 'till now, though ultimately this is a game with some promise that just doesn't deliver on its potential. Different characters with different quirks, weapon variety and some variation on approach are all here, though they just don't hold up for those marathon sessions.
           Then again, it didn't cost me an arm and a leg and I don't feel scalding regret over trying it, so always look on the bright side of life!

I'm torn because I'm writing some good things in a negative review. I liked this game, and I think it had great potential, but in the end, the "1.0" really wasn't a "1.0" release. It is only $5, which makes it a fair price, but after deliberation, I ultimately had to give it a negative review on the grounds that, once you play through it, you'll see that it is lacking content, is unpolished, and did not deliver on promises made.

This is one of the early popular roguelikes that showed lots of promise and ultimately failed to deliver on it. There is some value here, but in comparison to most games in the genre today, it feels unpolished. A lot of QoL is missing and the balance needs refining to make more gameplay styles viable. Unlike other older games that remain popular, the dev has largely stopped support on this one.

This game really isn't for me. I wouldn't even leave a review if I didn't make it a point to review every game I buy. I only got this because it was on a very steep sale and I loved the art style.

There just isn't enough gameplay here to keep me hooked. It feels too much like a visual novel and not enough like a video game even though I was hoping for more of a balance based on the trailer and the fact this game brands itself as an RPG before it does a visual novel. Most of the game is just text and relatively shallow decision making, with fantasy-coded football thrown in as an occasional minigame.

The story and characters are good, but not good enough to the point where I'll get invested in a genre I normally don't care for like with a game like Policenauts. The art style also didn't disappoint, but that alone won't save a game for me.

If you are into visual novels, then I would recommend this game. But if you're someone like me who thought the gameplay would matter more here than it actually does, heed this review.
