Have you ever played an old SNES JRPG like Final Fantasy 5 and thought to yourself "boy, I sure wish this game had awkward platforming that I had to use a keyboard to do" ?

Yeah me either. And I don't think any other human being on the planet ever had that thought either with the exception of this game's creator. He felt platforming with the same isometric awkwardness of Super Mario RPG would've been a great addition to the genre. He was wrong.

But once you get past that, the rest of the game plays about how you'd expect a JRPG to play from that era. Lots of classes, class switching, and sub-classes along with learning passives you can use with any class, etc. Very Final Fantasy 5, which presumably is why they called it Crystal Project because you unlock classes from crystals just as you do in Final Fantasy 5.

My only real complaints (aside from the forced inclusion of isometric platforming) are that the game feels "open" enough that you can get utterly confused about where you're supposed to go next while also not being an open world at all and having each stage of the game be gated by unlocking everything in each area before moving on. When this game was originally pitched to me, I was under the impression it was more open world, explore as you wish, maybe even randomly generated world every time you play it, but no. None of that. It's the same old world every time and you must do things in a particular order, but there's just enough freedom to move around that you can be unsure of where to go.

Reaching new areas often involves platforming that you may not even realize is an option because it's very unintuitive. For example, I couldn't get into the part of the sewer I needed to be in until I realized that you can jump on top of the flag bannisters while running down the stairs leaving the city to jump up on the wall. There is nothing to indicate that is possible, and if I hadn't toggled on the "auto jump" feature, i'd never have smacked into one, prompting me to consider trying to jump on top of one.

But despite how unintuitive all this is, the basic gameplay loop is fun if you enjoy JRPG style games, which I do. I also like that the combat uses threat in the way MMORPGs do, so attacks aren't randomly targeted, they are either AOE or target the highest target on their individual threat lists, so you can have a true dedicated tank for your team. I thoroughly enjoy that. And there are walkthroughs available if you are unsure what to do next.

I give it a solid 7/10. Would've been 10 out of 10 if there was no platforming. I'm still at a loss why anyone thought that would make the game more enjoyable. The only positive thing I can say about the platforming is at least most of the time you straight up fall to your death if you miss a jump, which resets you right back where you were before jumping and there is no "cost" associated, like you don't lose HP or whatever, so it's more annoying rather than punishing generally.

Edit: Just got to the desert area. Changed my mind. This game is awful. Isometric platforming is cancer, having to start all over every time is awful, have no option to skip it or make it easier is awful, having to do it all on a keyboard is awful, enemies firing at you like bullets out of a gun CONSTANTLY with fight after fight after fight just trying to do the stupid platforming.

No. This game COULD HAVE been good, but isometric platforming ruined it utterly.
Maybe I didn't get to the part where the game is "good" but I felt as though I wandered aimlessly, cleared a dungeon for no reason, and fought boring battles for boring upgrades.

It's hard to write a review about a game I feel so mixed on.

Crystal Project knows what it wants to be. For better or worse.

Playing it felt like playing a Pokemon fan-game: 
+ The game is very transparent about its mechanics. It will straight up tell you that there's "an NPC later on" that can help you with something stat-related, for instance. No digging around online for obscure equations necessary!
* Everything feels overtuned. Not even a quarter of the way into the game, everything you encounter will start having some level of resistance to status damage. About a third of the way in, the difficulty starts spiking, and this is probably where most people who are turned off by this game get turned off. By the end of the game, everything will wreck you unless you do some proper metagaming.
- The writing feels at worst rancid and at best nonexistant, with the exception of a single late-game scene that I thought was nicely written. The story is that you're collecting crystals for the sake of collecting crystals. That's not hyperbole, that's [i]literally it.[/i] Which is fine, I guess? The game clearly isn't trying to have a good story. But it's at its worst when the game tries to be funny. Normally I hate being the "that's not funny" guy, but it's kind of hard not to be when you can steal milk from every woman and nuts from every enemy that, if you turn off censorship, has it hanging out in the open for some reason? (And this isn't even bringing up the child abuse questline)

The overworld gameplay is... Minecraft parkour map. Your mileage may vary on this, but I for one, only really like this kind of gameplay when it feels like I'm doing something that wasn't intended. Like climbing the side of a steep mountain instead of taking the flat path in front of me. This game... rarely lets you do this (and in fact, most mountains in the game are designed [i]specifically so that this is never possible[/i]), and instead you're subject to a bunch of awkward protrusions that you need to jump between to climb a hypothetical tower. To me, this doesn't look pretty, and it doesn't feel like it flows well. For the most part, this is what the bulk of the overworld gameplay is, and unfortunately, it's probably for the best. Other mechanics get utilized at times, but they don't feel good to play. There's ice block pushing, and as a Sokoban fan, I generally really like these kinds of puzzles, but the absolute lightest nudges will send a block careening in a direction, so you pretty much have to give all ice blocks a wide berth until you know what you're doing with them, because it's [i]very[/i] easy to accidentally send one in the wrong direction. There's also a part of the game that has a stealth mechanic, and it may very well be the single worst stealth section I have ever played in a video game. Enemies will come after you if you make sound, but otherwise ignore you. That's fine. What's not fine is that there is ABSOLUTELY NO LENIENCY TO THIS. The single lightest tap on the controls will alert an enemy. Literally any input. You can wait after moving a tiny bit and the enemies will return to their patrol before they reach you, but this makes for excruciating boredom: Lightly tap a direction, move an inch, wait five seconds, repeat. It feels like you're not actually expected to be stealthy and just fight everything, yet the NPCs keep talking about moving quietly.

The battle mechanics are interesting. Especially the threat mechanic. I think that in particular is a really neat element, but I also think the game would greatly benefit from a means of lowering one's on threat level beyond just waiting it out. Thief, for instance, can barely do anything if their threat level is not the lowest in your party.

Unfortunately, there's also a lot of very questionable decisions with battle mechanics as well. Want to use healing items in battle? Sorry, that's relegated to a specific class's skills. If you don't have someone with that class currently fighting, you can't use them. This means that you ABSOLUTELY CANNOT LET YOUR HEALERS DIE. If you have nobody left standing who can revive, then unless you're already about to win, it's time to resign yourself to your fate, and just watch the rest of your party die. Fleeing? No, that's also a class skill. And not only that, but you normally can't even do it on the first turn. It costs AP, which charges between turns, and it costs two turns of it. It also has a chance of failure. And if it fails, you still lose the AP. And this is in a game where the regular encounters are explicitly designed to give you a tough time.

The worst mechanic of the battles though, I'd say, is the multiclassing system. You'd [i]think[/i] that would be the best part, letting you combine classes in creative ways to optimize your power, and finding synergies that open up entire realms of possibilities. Unfortunately, the game [i]really[/i] doesn't want you to do that, and as such, all weapon skills are locked to one or two specific weapons types, in a game where there's... I want to say at least twelve different weapon types, and your character is only allowed to equip one weapon. This means that there are very few non-magic class combinations that don't leave you with one class of completely unusable skills. Which in turn, severely deterred me from trying new classes. About halfway through the game, I installed a mod to just let me use any skill with any weapon and that alone [i]dramatically[/i] improved my experience. I think this game could've taken a page out of Octopath Traveler's book and let you equip your party with multiple weapons, and they'd switch between them as needed mid-battle.

I get that this is supposed to be a "hard" RPG, and, this may just be my own personal taste, but, I'm going to take a moment to compare this to an RPG series that people like to call hard: Shin Megami Tensei. I call SMT a "Bull**** RPG", and hear me out here because I say this with not a hint of malice. SMT will steal your bicycle, punch your teeth out, kick you to the curb, and steal your lunch money, all while making yo mama jokes. It's mean, and it games its own system to kick your ass and prevent you from even fighting back. This is [i]why[/i] SMT is called a "hard" RPG. HOWEVER, you are given access to the very same tools the game uses to destroy you. You just need to learn them. Once you do, [i]you[/i] will be the one stealing [i]SMT's[/i] bicycle, punching their teeth out, kicking them to the curb, and stealing their lunch money, all while making yo mama jokes. And this is why I call it a "Bull**** RPG": The game throws bull**** at you, but you can throw that bull**** right back at it. And once your bull**** throwing outpaces the game's, you feel brilliant, you feel powerful, and before long, you will be laughing maniacally, knowing not even God can stop you. That, and a good story, are the payoffs I look for in an RPG. Since this game has basically no story to lean on, I looked to becoming powerful as a payoff. This never happened. The game is balanced around you hitting the level cap before you beat it, and the game provided no explanation about the final boss, because apparently that gets skipped over entirely in the "true" ending. By the end I didn't feel powerful, I just felt tired.

Despite all my complaining, and scathing criticisms, I don't think this game is [i]bad[/i]. I think it just does a lot of things I don't like, in a genre I normally do like. And some of you out there will no doubt love this game to pieces. But I look back on my experience in this game and the word that keeps coming to my mind is "irritating." Which, I really hate saying, because I can [i]feel[/i] the developer's passion. They had a vision for a video game, and they saw it through to completion, and I respect the ever-loving hell out of that. I don't feel great giving this game a negative review, but I genuinely cannot see myself recommending it.

The game gets its praise for the class combos and strategy that comes from building a character.
I've also seen other people appreciate the game for its exploration and open endedness and the ability to skip around areas.

I'm 20 hours into the game and I have yet to experience any of those joys or strongpoints of the game. I have not seen a class combo that works well yet and have had to get where I got through grinding. And this is coming from an Octopath Traveler, and Shin Megami tensei(highest difficulty) and FE player.
As for exploration, yes there is quite a lot to explore, but there are barely any "wonder" to keep me engage.
The minecraft like art isn't that charming, and there just aren't any unique enemy encounters to keep the grind play.
The platforming is just cumbersome and doesn't really add to the game. The rewards for how much time it takes is just obnoxious.

I think this game was extremely balanced at normal difficulty and I'm not meant to stay in any area for that long (which might be required because of grinding if you are on the hard difficulty)

I get the idea that the things other people love about this game is what I love about Octopath Traveler - cool class combos and skill builds, nooks and crannies to explore. I really really just don't see it in this game. Things kill you in 1-2 hits. You cannot run away from fights. Monster fights are a bit mandatory. You cant use items you've collected. and you run out of MP really really really fast. Like really fast. 

This is definitely a me thing, I also don't like difficulty settings in an RPG - I like to play it on the hardest setting - and hard just means more grinding. If you want - put the setting on hard - and go to the assist mode - and turn up the 3x experience and job points. I've only encountered 2 out of like 10 bosses that were kind of fun to fight. Most bosses will just outright kill you with AOE even with debuff - technical play. I'm not sure what thats about.

If you want a more indepth negative review - checkout Casual Player's review. All the negative points this person listed were my own. And then the glaring issue, is the mediocre game play isn't even anchored by any story. (which I actually don't mind, except that the game play is just below average).

Gave me mixed feelings, I wish I could vote something in the middle. 

TLDR: It's a game with a lot of QoL (but some of it not by default) and many weird or annoying design choices that you may or may not enjoy.

Exploration is the best and worst part at the same time:
Â·You need to explore whole areas blind before you can obtain the map. Sometimes you have to do weird things to get them and might not realise until too late. 
Â·You can't directly get the maps for some big transition and late game areas and have to build them from parts you find instead, so you are blind until late game because you need to find the mounts and fully explore them first to get them.
Â·You need to unlock different mounts to fully explore the map or advance the story but it's a pain in the butt having to change them so often for basic travel.
Â·There is a late game mount that combines some but not all of them and you have to do a ridiculously long and annoying side quest to unlock it.
Â·To start battle enemies run at you very fast and you have to somehow dodge them if you don't want to fight, unless you are many levels above them (way too many to be a useful feature). They can also jump so you can't really use the environment to your advantage.
Â·You can't run from battle unless you have an specific skill equipped in one of your characters that by default needs another one to be used the first turn.
Â·Platforming can be too finicky and precise and the fixed camera works against you all the time.
Â·There is an auto-jump option that can help with that but you need to be constantly turning it on and off in the settings, as there is no key-bind and in some places it hurts more than helps.

Combat and character building:
Â·There is no defend command, but you can pass turn, and see what the enemies are going to do next.
Â·You can't use items mid fight.
Â·There is an aggro system that makes it hard for your DPS characters to not die quickly because they get focused first, and the aggro changes on the fly makes it sometimes unpredictable.
Â·You can use aggro manipulation skills that some tank classes have but 80% of enemies kill you in 1 or 2 hits. Stat scaling is weird.
Â·For most casters the spells are delayed and the turn order also changes on the fly so you have to keep that in mind too. It also makes aggro manipulation harder.
Â·Enemies can crit you and will make you cry :_)
Â·Difficulty option feels like it doesn't change much?
Â·There are many classes and combinations available but the skills that they can use are limited by equipped weapon so you can't really combine most of them. This leaves you with only a handful of viable class combinations and half disabled skill lists.
Â·Lack of item variety. No accessories for half the status effects and stats.

Other things:
Â·Story is basically non existent, so you better enjoy the gameplay.
Â·Post-game content that lets you enjoy your completed characters is very limited.
Â·There are many quality of life options available in the settings, which is fantastic, but the game feels like a chore if you play without them enabled. By default you can't teleport between save points for example.
Â·It has official mod tools and support which is very nice.
One of the worst experiences i have ever had.

Pretty quickly every fight becomes "nuke them down before they nuke you down". There's not much in the way of long-term decision making that is essential for a JRPG to be interesting. 

I do respect the developer for making the game hard, but it falls into the "every battle is the same" problem that is shared by games that are too easy.

Too easy: Mash attack every battle
Too hard: Pick the exact same options every battle to grind for resources until you can pick the exact same options for enough battles in a row to get past the area.

It's telling that all the recommended mods are basically cheats.

So what makes a hard JRPG fun? Lets take Final Fantasy 1: Origins for example (not to be confused with the very easy Anniversary Edition).

In FF1, most battles could be easily won in isolation, but you can't try to wipe the floor with every encounter without running out of resources, so you hold back. It's a constant balancing act between how much power you're willing to burn vs how close to death you're willing to take your characters.

That feeling is absent from Crystal Project. It's always burn, rinse, repeat. Or go get a cheat mod and save yourself the time.

This is a real fun JRPG but it has very little direction other than to mindlessly walk around. I get the concept of exploration for side stuff but the main-quest line isn't very neatly packed together so you end up lost easily.  Past JRPGs solved this by having NPCs with general directions or bars/taverns where you could talk to NPCs about rumors.  The Map isn't really any help because it is just an overview of the area without landmarks or paths detailed. If I could pull up the map and see that there is some general path to go to the next town or dungeon I wouldn't have an issue with it. 

If You're fine with grinding and wandering around a lot, this is probably very fun for you. I enjoy my JRPGs to have a lot of direction from NPCs or a useful map so I know where I am going.

------

Since my Last comments, I just don't know. It manages to be so fun to grind, find crystals and work with the job system. Could easily see myself spending much more time aimlessly killing mobs. I can't recommend this to people who are looking for story but if you just want a JRPG you can mess around in for a couple hours, this is it.

------
While I really enjoy the game I can't recommend it to other people because it's difficulty is so superficial. I'm not annoyed that everything I do just isn't working but more so it feels like there is a very narrow amount of possibilities that will work at times. You don't get very much direction on what to do in the game, which becomes an annoying realm of wandering around in big empty spaces looking for any mystery or clue to a crystal. The Classes are good but none of them feel very complete as your reward for mastering so many isn't even the ability to use the class specific ability with other classes. You absolutely need a mage as much as you need healing as much as you need items but the game is dense in cheap elements of difficulty. 

Can't run from fights unless I have a specific ability to do that. Can't use Items in battle with the same class unless it is unlocked. More annoyingly is you can't exactly attach these necessary parts of the combat to give you at least some edge to overturn a battle that's going particularly bad. Items are so expensive early game, if you don't grind and late game if you want good ones. however, you can't use items during battle unless you are the class with access to items or have the item ability sub command. You end up having to fight so hard to do big damage but all of the enemies are geared up with full party nukes. Its not even in a fair way where you can use a tank to pull the attention from a enemy to do single attacks. Nope, everyone gets smacked to almost 0 health and some KO on every few turns. If you're losing a fight, there is no way to swing the momentum back in your favor and enemies seem to have unlimited amounts of AP and MP to use any kind of extremely devastating attack they want. It just isn't much fun to deal with the combat at all so I end up avoiding nearly every enemy in the game and trying to not fight bosses. I want to take this game as far as it will go because it is such a brilliant concept. Just some balancing and this becomes a really fun game.
Meh ... the trailer is more fun than the game itself.

The most overrated game of all time.

Let me be clear: I donâ€™t mind difficulty. In fact, Iâ€™ve loved challenging games since childhood. I enjoy learning from my mistakes, improving, dying, trying again, and beating bosses. I defeated 30â€“40 bosses in Elden Ring without giving up, raging, or complaining about the difficulty.

My issue is not difficulty, itâ€™s everything else.

Story & Worldbuilding

Yes, the world of Elden Ring can be huge, rich, and deep. But a world that big shouldnâ€™t be this vague. The â€œstoryâ€ basically consists of a guy shouting at the beginning and a handful of cryptic NPCs who talk like theyâ€™re solving riddles. Thatâ€™s simply not for me.

I want to engage with a story.
I want an actual script, a main quest that makes sense, something to pull me into the world.
I shouldnâ€™t have to check item descriptions or chase random weird NPCs across a massive map just to understand the basics of the lore. (Lore of the world, not the story)

Some players enjoy that style and thatâ€™s completely fine, but I donâ€™t.

Gameplay.....

This is where the game completely loses me.

Elden Ring still uses the same old formula from 2007: slow, clunky, rollâ€“dodgeâ€“hit combat that becomes extremely repetitive after a while. After a masterpiece like Sekiro, I genuinely thought FromSoftware would push their combat systems forward. Instead, they went backward.

Sure, there are tons of builds and creative options. But at the end of the day, every boss fight ends up feeling like you're just a rolling PokÃ©mon waiting for openings. Itâ€™s uninteresting and dull.

Visuals & Exploration

Iâ€™ll give credit where itâ€™s due: visually and structurally, the world is stunning. I normally hate getting lost in video games, but Elden Ringâ€™s worldbuilding makes exploration rewarding, every corner has something to discover, and thatâ€™s a huge positive.

But in the end, amazing exploration doesnâ€™t mean much when:

1)The story gives you nothing to hold onto, and

2)The combat system feels boring and outdated.

Conclusion

I respect people who love this game, everyone has different tastes. But I genuinely cannot see the appeal. After 42 hours of boredom, I have to drop it midway.

A generous 5/10.

A cosplay simulator, dressing the same fights in different skins. What feels like turn-based movement and camera mechanics masquerading as a real-time action rpg. An insult to developers that have actually continued to develop over the decades. Fight mechanics that feel like chess taking ballroom dancing lessons. Same boring yet beautiful animations over and over and over. Incredible lore with an almost absent story. Repetitive and Empty, a Sprawling Wasteland that mocks you as you put up with the same boring content, always suggesting there's something exciting just a few sites of grace further, always delivering the exact same thing in a different skin. Its only redemption is its incredibly abstract facade, allowing the player to invent their own stories for The (extraordinarily few) Tarnished the player gets to meet.

Elden Ring is a stunning, marvelous contradiction. The Lands Between look gorgeous; the character designs and scale take your breath away. The signature challenge feels genuinely nice and rewards you when you overcome it. However, the game actively fights you every step of the way. It truly feels like the developers threw you into the ocean on a raft. The game explains nothing. The deep lore is so unclear you must read external guidelines to grasp basic quests. Also, the game menus and overall UI are the worst I have ever seen. This design wastes your time. While I appreciate the artistry, I simply lack the patience for this unintuitive design and guidance.

This game is currently too unreasonably priced, and a it is total price gouge.  I've own this game since 2020 when I bought the deluxe edition for $15.  It is time now for me to come out and to review this game.  Why?  I want to speak out against you readers for paying $40 (50% off) for this software rental.  My recommendation is for you to buy a cheap PS5 or PS4 and just play a used copy you can get.
As for why I've only played 50 or so hours, I have devoted more time for other games, including Elden ring, Dark Souls 1 remake,  Bloodborne game of the year edition, and to my two all time favourites:  Demon Souls and Dark souls 2.    
Dark Souls 1 and 2 had connected worlds.  This was a huge draw for me.  Dark souls 3's worlds are smaller and better designed. However, I was disapointed to find that you must go to the bondfire to go between worlds.  Sure, Demon Souls and Bloodborne are the same, but those are first installments of the game.  Here, we're talking Dark SOuls 3, where 1 and 2 had interconnected worlds.  No excuse.   If you must really praise this game for smoother combat, I would recommend that you dont' your time here, and just go play Bloodborne.  Cheers mate. Don't pay the sucker price.

Fromsoft once again fails to demonstrate improvement in areas where they struggle.

There is little reason that a studio like Fromsoft should struggle with displaying the correct button prompts for controllers in a game so clearly primarily designed for consoles.  The first bossfight is also poorly timed, with it clearly intending the player to use mechanics that are not explained until tutorials are accessed after the bossfight is successfully completed.  I suspect this second failure is due to poor planning on Fromsoft's part, with the introductory mission and boss being designed and implemented after the rest of the game was a finished piece - the studio has a history of such directorial blunders.

The game also seems to fall into the trap of attempting to display simplified stats for things like weapons while at the same time hiding useful information, leaving players relying on dataminers and extensive, laborious in-game testing to establish what *exactly* weapons do.

Additional features are poorly implemented.  The store system is unnecessary, providing no true limit on player builds past the very early game.  Engine load and weight already provide the necessary tools for balance.  Since you can buy and sell for the same price, in practice you simply buy, sell, buy, sell, buy, sell...it interrupts the flow of building, making the act of customizing your mecha a gigantic chore.

The story, as far as I have gotten, is poorly written and full of dull, unlikable characters with far too much dialogue for what they actually have to say.

Important missions are designed to be played halfway, failed, and restarted once the player has had a chance to tune their gear.  This is due to how the bossfights work, which are dependant on you having certain equipment to make them go by quickly enough to not drag on forever.  It's clear the devs are desperate for you to take a blade with you, but they only give you one blade for an extended period of time and it's kind of miserable to use.  It takes up a hand slot despite being  a wrist-mounted device.  You don't get any money for a failed mission, so it's just a way to waste player time.  

The "voice in your ear" characters are annoying to listen to, and only rarely have something useful to say.  Most of the commentary they give is cliche, and not in a funny way.  Just in a dull, unimaginative, hacky way.  Remember in Halo 2, how annoying it was to hear Cortana repeat the same voice line four or five times while trying to beat the game on higher difficulties?  It's that, but the character speaking never has any good lines to make up for it.  At least Cortana's lines in these situations tended to be more than "Don't let him bait you.  Focus."  

(Side Rant: He's not baiting ME you dumb fuck, he's baiting YOU.  I don't know who he is, I don't know who he's talking about, I don't give a single flying fuck about any of it.  Shut the hell up and let me do my job.  Like, at least do something useful and jam his comms so I don't have to hear his smug-ass dialogue)

Unfortunately, major mech games are rare and so it's still likely worth playing this game if you like mechs and can roll with the punches.  DO NOT pay full price for this title.  Fromsoft needs to be held to a standard appropriate for a professional, well-funded AAA studio.  If they put out a 30 dollar game that they take a loss on if they sell it for less than 50, that's not your problem.  That's their problem, and they can go bankrupt over it.

Man, I really want to like this one. The core idea is so good, but the game just isn't good. It starts great with some cool boss fights, but then the game runs out of ideas and each boss fight is less interesting than the previous one. It's a bit of a classic FromSoft problem, where the game is front-loaded and the latter parts of the game feel cobbled together to get the game out the door. 

The story is just awful. It's not even a fun kind of bad, it's just not good, worse, it's boring.

It's just a shame. I really want to like this game. I just don't have the energy to finish it though. It's not good enough and the competition if fierce.

I played AC2 back on the PS2 and was thinking about it recently. I decided to pick up AC6 more than 2 years after it came out. Beat the game and got all the endings. put over 100 hours into it, very fun single player experience. Went and tried my hand in PVP and quickly found that the net code is pretty terrible. reacting to projectiles is meaningless because they end up hitting you anyway. I travel for work, so i was playing on a slightly unstable connection, and I had a few DC's. couple that with the net code and you get a very unfun experience. After the 7th match in a row against the same person, who was using a weapon that was literally impossible to dodge under the circumstances, I Alt F4'd out of the game and went to lay down. went back the next day and I spent 20 minutes in the matchmaking queue with no games found. Come to find out, Fromsoftware had instituted a separate queue for people who frequently leave matches...I havent been able to get a game since. how long does it last? well also come to find out that it can last for months...great way to kill all the interest i had left in the game, and honestly pretty annoying. if someone DC's or quits a match...give them a loss. thats it. why make your own game unplayable?

Unfortunately, after DS1's difficulty craze, it seems FromSoft's primary goal has been to shit out absolute stinkers. Anyone who has skid marks and sits in their gaming chair all day will tell you to git gud, that it's a skill issue, as if we all aren't aware that they achieve nothing but sinking thousands of hours into a game that rewards their lack of employment. And don't raise your pitchforks, because I'm one of em. 

Sekiro is another title that has been plagued. It's manageable for a while - through all the perilous deflects, the prosthetic arms, and the filter mini-bosses. It's immersive, it does stealth mostly right, and the exploration is peak. But at some point along the line, Sekiro becomes less of a fun learning curve and more of an annoyance; with repetitive enemies and bosses that have some bullshit gimmick, a tracking windup, ridiculous attack speeds & aggro ranges, or homing projectiles. And that's what makes it another load of waste born from the FromSoft sewage pipe.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
There are definitely mechanics you can enjoy, but personally they missed the mark.

Movement is a little too floaty, feeling similar to ARK.
The skill tree feels like it should be split up so basic survival skills (e.g mining/chop speed) are not taking away from the more fun skills.
At least early on, the game does not feel great in terms of scaling to a larger group. We tried with 6 people  and there is a constant blast of information as people unlock things or talk to NPCs, and it feels silly just whacking every enemy in a 6v1 fight.
And the biggest problem was performance stability, for most of our group even with low settings FPS would regularly dip below 30.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
The start felt too much like Fortnite the survival game, in the worst way...I wanted to enjoy this game but I feel like there is not enough there to grab you at the start and I didn't want to keep the game to find out if it would grow on me so i refunded it.
I also feel like this game suffers a lot if you try and play it with too many players, I felt overwhelmed with pop-ups and didn't really know if I should be focusing on questing, exploring or survival.
Also my friends were struggling with performance a lot even after trying to make the game look like a fogged up mirror, so that is something to consider if you don't have a high end PC.

This game might become great when you progress but it's an expensive game to keep with hopes of enjoying it later.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text: too early, no novelty, wish I could get a refund

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
Not worth it in it's current state. I know it's Early Access, but holy moly is this ever rough around the edges. A lot of basic tutorials that you'd expect to get are simply not there, and the AI is pretty much "run in straight line and attack, repeat" for every enemy- which can still be difficult because enemies are often just spammed at you from spawners you can barely see and any attacks from behind count as backstab, even for enemies. So an enemy you didn't even know had spawned behind you can one shot you.

Which brings me to my next major gripe:  Darksouls style artificial difficulty.  Some traps and even simply existing in some areas will INSTANTLY KILL YOU. With no warning or indication whatsoever. The worst being the Shroud itself. The game doesn't tell you there are multiple "levels" of shroud, which to the player just looks like fog. There is no distinction between levels apparently. So you can be walking through shroud and be fine, then simply touch a higher level shroud and just instantly die. Insult to injury is that the game flashes a message on your screen warning you that you're IN a harder shroud area. *After* you are dead.

Being a caster is kind of a joke, as staffs require mana AND ammo, which is a huge pain in the ass to get mats for early on. Then there's the game's automatic target locking. You can't freely aim, you are stuck locking onto enemies and it can seriously screw you over if you're trying to shoot a barrel next to an enemy because. While I only found out later you can hold T and it will cancel target lock but only while holding T. There's permanent toggle.

The game has promise, but in it's current state, it is more frustrating than fun to play. Way too many annoying "choices" that bring the game down.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
The performance optimization is still painfully garbage almost a year after I bought the game. I keep dropping it and telling myself "they'll probably fix it in a couple months", but at this point I don't know if that's ever going to happen. There's no reason this game should be running at sub 60FPS using medium to medium-high settings (With DLSS on performance), on a device with a core ultra 9, RTX 4080, and 32GB RAM. 

If these issues ever do get addressed, I can easily see myself putting in over a hundred hours in this game, but at it's present state, it just gives me a headache.

I'd say hold off on buying until the game is finished.

[h1][b]Neither here nor there:[/b] Golden Light[/h1]

While working through my games backlog, I like to pace myself by playing one fairly "normal" game and following that up with something weird as hell. [b]Golden Light[/b] falls firmly in the latter category; however, what started as a very intriguing premise would turn out to be a bit of a disappointment.

In Golden Light, our unnamed protagonist descends into the depths of the Gut searching for She, his lost lady love. Here, the Gut serves as both the environment and the antagonist, becoming angrier and more hostile the more enemies you kill. And if you find it all too much to bear, you can always appease it by hurting yourself or making offeringsâ€¦

From what I saw, the story in Golden Light closely follows the Silent Hill "formula" (or at least, what's been accepted as the Silent Hill Formula over the years): our protagonist is lost and trapped in a purgatory-like place, searching for a loved one. This fairly well-worn base is then topped with a generous smattering of meat and weirdness (with a sprinkle of Cronenberg and Lynch), giving Golden Light a unique and genuinely unsettling vibe.

Look, I'ma be real - I'm not a huge fan of games whose idea of horror is enemies barrelling down towards me, screaming bloody murder. And since this is basically Golden Light's main shtick, I think you'll understand why I dropped it so quickly.

If you're OK with constant, annoying jump scares, I think there's actually something to Golden Light. The meat aesthetic alone is unique enough to merit at least giving it a try, and for all I know, the story might go deeper than the surface-level stuff I saw would suggest.

If Elden Ring had gone robotic/sci-fi versus fantasy, this is the game. I don't mean that in a good way. It's like they took Elden Ring's price-point and made worse gaming mechanics, while making it impossible to feel like you're gaining ground in the story line without dying and losing any power-up progress you've finally felt like you've gotten under your belt. The main-character to weakest-enemy power balance doesn't help in making you feel like your making story progression. I tried really hard to like this game, but they really need to either include more Vestule's so you don't have to go through the same 20-minute fighting sequence multiple times (either this or running past every minor robot to reach "boss-bots") or give you the opportunity to save game progress without the vestule's.

Could have been pretty decent but it had one major flaw. There is no substance.

Souls-Like games really arent just combat, thats just ARPG stuff... There is a lot that goes into the genre and world building, lore and most.importently NPCs are really vital for an impactful experience.

If you took the NPCs and or the way theyre set up out of the souls series or elden ring, they would feel exactly how this feels. Empty, lifeless, forgettable.

The way the game handles character interactions is the reason people are saying that they dont feel connected to it.

Take this advice, learn from it and apply it.

Also, please consider short cuts that actually make sense.

Overall id give it a 6.5/10 what it has is pretty good, but what it doesnt have hurts it.

2. The maps all look similar especially the first 3-4 big regions so it is too monotonous for my taste. Got a bit better to the end of the game but the start was too equal looking.

3. Mob recycling is crazy in this game... Holy shit there are actually only like 5 types of enemie which get recycled throughout the whole game by getting a different weapon or element but basically still being the same enemy.

4. As mentioned earlyier its too pricey for what it brings to the table. I would say a fair price would be 20â‚¬ but would strongly advise against buying it for everything above that price.

So much for my review, i still had fun playing it though even if not as much as i did in other soulslike.

[h1]The More, The Worse[/h1]

[b]Among Us[/b]. You know it, you love it. Or do you? The more they added to this game, the less fun it became to play. The simplistic nature of the older versions was what was so charming about it. The newer roles actually make the game less fun. This game is stuck in a rare limbo where adding more content actively makes it worse...hide and seek is good, though.

On top of that, the playerbase and culture you remember has completely changed, the heights of COVID, which I have great memories of, may never be replicated again.

Overall, game can be fun still with the right people with classic rules. I just think it's about time Innersloth make something new rather than keep updating a game where its peak period can never be replicated.

Before you buy :)

Can I play this while having a job

Yes. The game does not really keep long term progression. When you log out the only things that stay are your gold and the ship you purchased. All loot like cannonballs and food disappears. Good for players who cannot commit every day.

Are you a PVP player

If you enjoy PVP this game is very fun. Everyone has the same gear so skill is what matters. No pay to win and no advantage for older players. Just get good.

Can I play this every day

You can but expect the game to feel repetitive.
After reaching Pirate Legend you have basically completed the main goal. Everything after that is for cosmetics titles and achievements. These do not help in combat. Flexing on hoes is what matter at this point.

PVP Experience

Outside Hourglass fights a normal ship battle can last 30 minutes to 1 hour depending on the players and the ship sizes. Sometimes you will fight two players or even four players while you are alone or with one friend. This can be exciting or frustrating. Just get good.

PVE Experience

Megalodon is scary the first time but after a few encounters it becomes simple. Just sail to the nearest island and it will disappear. Kraken is not really threatening. The water becomes dark you cant sail just fight not really hard. Skeleton ships and storms annoying you can sail around the storm just annoying since you delaying going to your destination for skeleton ship the loot is okay but not amazing. World events are a mix of PVP and PVE but nothing too special after a while.

My Thoughts

Sea of Thieves is very fun with friends but boring alone unless you want cosmetics or achievements.

Traveling takes most of the play time. You will sail for around five minutes or more for every island. A single quest can take two to three hours and more than 60% of that is just sailing with nothing happening.

Crew limit is four players. You can form alliances to make groups. I myself played with 8 people you can do this by sever hopping and spawning with a galleon until at least 2 play from your team find a match on the same server. This is fun when you are part of it but not fun for everyone else.

Pets

Pets look nice but they do nothing helpful.
It would be better if monkeys fed you or if dogs helped you find treasure faster. Right now pets are only for looks and nothing else.

Battle Pass

You can earn Ancient Coins without buying the pass but it is very rare.

Final Verdict

Sea of Thieves is amazing with friends but becomes repetitive fast.
Great for players who enjoy PVP and want a relaxed sailing adventure.
Not great for players who want strong progression or deep PVE.

review_text:
TLDR: A few years ago I would have recommended Vrchat as I was naive. Now after the things I have witnessed and heard in this game I dont recommend it to anyone. I'm even going out of my way to write this review and scare children away.

-PARENTS BE WARNED-

Vrchat is NOT a game for children under the age of 16/18 (depending on their country) It is a Lalaland without authority which is full of degenerate/mentally ill/lost to addiction adults who will not care for your childs well being. If anything a great amount will do them harm mentally or expose them to addiction and other 18+ content. A small group will even try to extort them or physically harm them. If you thought the stories coming from roblox are bad, its been like this on vrchat for quite some time now.
 
I started playing this game years ago when I was in my early 20's, the majority of poeple did not own a vrheadset. Seeing anyone with one let a lone with full body tracking was rare and special. If anything they where consideret expensive. its wild to me that children get gifted a vrheadset with unsupervised acces to certain games. 

Eitherway, in the beginning it was great when I did not own a vrheadset/full body tracking. I met a  decent amount of good poeple and had loads of fun with them exploring the world of vrchat. After a year or so I got my first vrheadset and shortly after full body tracking as well, by this time a decent amount of the good poeple had moved on with their life as they did not invest in a headset. After buying the vrheadset it all went down hill as I felt obligated and excited to play vrchat for as long as a I could even sleeping in it ocasionally. 
Owning a vrheadset and full body tracking opens acces to certain activities and poeple that otherwise would not interact with you if you didn't have tracking. It became a feeding source of various addictions and eventually leading to mental illnes. I would say the pandemic did a great number on that front as a lot of things you where not allowed to do in the real world anymore, you could still do on vrchat (for example partying/clubbing) Besides who you meet on vrchat will never only stay on vrchat, it will move on to discord, snapchat ect.

Vrchats community simply makes and breaks the game. Its a great thing that there is so much space for creative outlet, creating worlds and your own characters. But without authority and management it turns into a toxic lalaland where poeple can do as they please. 
There are safety opptions the player can take themselfs but how realistic is it that easily influenced children will actually make use of that...

Although vrchat implemented age verification it doesn't solve anything since its up to whoever creates the world instence to implement the age verification. That makes it so that adults who don't want to interact with minors create a safe space for themselfs away from minors. What ever is done by players in public lobbies or private lobbies is not moderated what so ever. They can regulate to some extent the content that gets released on the game but they can't regulate what poeple say/do in that virtual world.

I haven't played much since I got it. But recently I wanted to try the CodZ maps ported into Pavlov. The performance is terrible. I have a Ryzen 5 3600XT, RTX 3060 12gb, 32gb of DDR4, and the game is installed on an Gen 4 NVMe. My game has unplayable stuttering that makes me sick after a just few minutes.

It was an amazing game in its prime, fun people, great gamemodes, and just overall a game that you can play for hours on end. Sadly, it is no longer that game that I fell in love with years ago. The game is full of annoying little kids, micro transactions, and the mods that were actually fun have been removed for some reason. Don't get me wrong, the game was amazing before the mods but people only really play with mods these days and if you are going to have mods why get rid of the good ones? I wish I could recommend this game but what it was VS what it is now is too different and makes the game not even close to the fun that me and my friends would have.

The playerbase swings between people who "ragebait" you and people who look like they installed the game five minutes ago. When you queue alone, youâ€™re basically praying the matchmaking gives you at least one teammate who actually knows whatâ€™s going on.

And speaking of matchmakingâ€¦ itâ€™s awful. Youâ€™ll get teammates who throw, afk, leave mid-match, or blame everyone but themselves. While the enemy team somehow looks like they were hand-picked from the Top 500 leaderboard.. It never feels even or fair.

Then thereâ€™s the whole EOMM thing.  Youâ€™ll win a few matches, feel like youâ€™re finally on a rollâ€¦ and then boom, the game slams you into a long losing streak that feels completely manufactured. Itâ€™s like the game is trying to keep you on this emotional rollercoaster so you keep playing â€œjust for one good match.â€

Awful balance, community, monetization, company, and reception. It is a joke this game is on a "redemption arc" when most of the problems from OW1->2 are still present, like tank being the most miserable experience possible - yes, I love the match being dictated around one player and winning or losing based on the tank. 6s are also back but it doesn't mean much, considering the tanks are bloated due to the balance changes they received to function as solo tanks in 5v5. Stadium is another problem, isn't it wonderful to run into a hard counter and just feel useless for the whole match?

This is a continuation on the balance problems, but stadium's shop and the perk system in both also suck, the changes are of wildly different quality, some characters get really good horizontal progression and new abilities, some just get a slight vertical improvement, and some (Lifeweaver lifegrip minor perk) get what should be base kit. The balance is also factoring these in too, balancing the perks and base kits around them, which is dumb. The "choice" doesn't amount to much when one perk is significantly better than the other, and Stadium suffers a similar fate. Why try experimenting if you can just play the meta?

OW1 died for this garbage.

Overwatch has great core gameplay, but everything around it holds the experience back. Matchmaking feels all over the place, hero balance shifts too wildly, and the monetization system constantly gets in the way of having fun. Queue times jump from fast to painfully long, and the progression system barely rewards you for your time. Itâ€™s a game with huge potential, but the current systems make it frustrating to stay committed.

I have thousands of hours in this game and like many before me, and many after me, you come to realize that the Dark Patterns being used in this game is the driving force that causes many people to log into this game. The other content is intentionally made painfully difficult to get involved with, and all events are set up to ensure that you never get close to end game content. This is to make you spend money in game, allowing the dark patterns to take hold of you. If you are unsure of what dark patterns are, you can refer to Chris Wilson recent video. He was a CEO of path of exile that is opening the gaming communities eye to the tactics being employed by these predatory companies. 

This is no on AGS specifically, as the core component of the design if by smilegate, I could not recommend this game, and actively encourage people not to play. Maybe one day, in the future, enough people will quit to make this game a good game to play, as the raid conent is peak. Unfortunately.. so is the their free to play structure, and not in a good way.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
This is a game that I did love, but It has no freedom or creativity at all. It is a Game that in every moment you will encounter a constant go to this website and follow this build guide, even getting help from other players amounts to a simple, Forget your gear forget your Gems and i dont care what your current passive skill tree choices are, Wear these Items i Crafted for you, Use this Weapon I have for you, And Follow this Strategy and you will succeed. 

I am just tired of games that boast as having a massive level of freedom and endless possibilities but actually have 0 of anything that is not mitigated by the caveat of Umm Actually you have the freedom to choose which guide to follow but if you want to just experiment then you will not be able to finish the game nor will you be able to do anything endgame because the Enemies will just kill you outright and you will just come away from your sessions feeling Pissed off and Tired of the fact that you if you Did screw up your skill tree then You have to wait until the next season for a free reset, Which is another retarded bit in its own right. 

Personal Aside Passive Tree Full Reset: So they dont bother to tell you when you use their free reset that not only does it reset your main passive tree but it also resets your endgame atlas tree, so if you ground out your passive tree like i did then you now are told Hehe do it again. Like Im SORRY BUT GRINDING GEAR GAMES SHOULD STAND FOR GANGBANG GRAPE AND GREPEAT. now that that is out of my system

SO if you dont have this full skill tree wipe how can you undo your mistaken or wrong choices on the tree, well i will tell you that Unless you have been grinding every single map killing every thing for 10 hours a day the likelyhood aside from buying gold from a website selling it is squat. It costs about 4-5k gold to gain a skill removal token, at endgame your looking at around 100 skills you have spent. if your thinking to yourself that thats not too bad sure if you didnt get gold at a rate of 20-50% drop chance for each monster you kill granting you less than 20 per drop in act 1, less than 30 in act 2 and up to 50 in act 3. so looking at the math each point you need to undo is gonna be ground out at 80-300 drops of gold at the 50% or less drop chance while in act 3. So better pay for the gold online which is questionable but hey I wont play this game anymore so i dont care.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text: Great game and continues to get better but there are definitely issues that are incredibly frustrating. Tier 17 maps are awful. Not because they're hard, but what makes them hard. These modifiers are unbelievably strong. They create incredibly small niches that allow certain builds to thrive and leave everything else to die... literally. In a game that is all about builds and build-crafting, you get punished extremely heavily for attempting to step outside of meta builds. The other issue with endgame is 95% of deaths are to insane 1-shots. Most of the time it's very hard to know what you died to. This leads to deaths being even more frustrating due to not being able to improve your character in a more concrete way. Most upgrades to my character after a few deaths tend to be more broad defensive upgrades based on stats. Mostly feels like meaningless gameplay that only leads to frustration.

review_text:
Was having a load of fun until today when I clicked a box in a safehouse and it automatically opened my UI and had my mouse held down directly over my ring that had 35d of minions on it, deleting all of them. Sorry, kind of a deal breaker, I'm not farming for a week to compensate for what is essentially an obscene quality of life issue. Add a menagerie for spectres that allows you to 1 for 1 save slots or something, really just do anything, anything that would allow you to save a spectre into a certain slot would solve this problem easily and not cause any balance issues, even given the fact that you only want 1 ritual corpse to = 1 spectre. 
I've been playing this game since 2013 on and off and had only good things to say about it, but this issue effectively just destroyed my build in a single missclick, and I'm not some hyper efficient grinder that can eat a 35d loss and make it back in a couple hours, it took every bit of my time played to scrape together just enough to get my build online and I have no possible way to come back from this, nor would I really want to if this could just happen again.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
This game has great potential ... but ...
Game is very difficult to learn. The tutorial system is worthless, doesn't help you learn combat, doesn't help with gem sockets in gear and what the different color sockets are for. I am unable to find any gems that will work in the armor or shield slots. (All the gems I have found or seen from vendors are for weapons only and the descriptions are lacking in how the gems will interact with each other. Everything is guess work and I am unable to tell certain gems even do anything).

You get an arm that you need to graft to your body ... but how to do that? Fortunately the steam community told me how to equip it (it was hidden box on the left side of the inventory screen). Updating this arm is also confusing and complicated. 

Items tale up way to much space in the inventory which is very limited and you can't increase the size of you backpack. I read that this is due to the designers wanting players to carefully choose what items to pick up. Problem with this ... you need to be able to sell items in your inventory to gain trade currency so you can buy stuff. You also need to sell stuff from inventory so you can get wisdom scrolls so you can identify items.

There is no way reliable way to return to towns/camps to sell inventory. Portal scrolls are few and far between. Way points are also few and far between. If you run back to town, then everything resets and you have to start exploring the area(s) again.

The game doesn't save area progress and if you leave an area you have completed the area resets and you have to do the whole area again.

If you fail a quest, that is it. You can't get the quest back, restart it, and if it is a quest that you need to progress the story ... well, the only option I found is to delete the character and start all over again.

Items that you need to use (scroll of wisdom to identify items, town portals, and other items to improve gear) is also currency to buy/upgrade gear. The gold you find is basically useless because you can only gamble it for unknown items.

I bought the map board. (Spent real money on this). After I bought it, I found out that it was worthless because you can only use it after you finish the campaign. (I believe this is a scam for me to spend money on an item I would not need because after I complete the campaign then what use will this be? (The campaign is done).

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, RPG, Free To Play
review_text:
Path of Exile 1 is a great game trapped inside a technical framework that feels like it was built without long-term thinking or real engineering discipline.

The developers keep stacking new systems, new calculations, and massive on-screen load without ever proving they can handle the fundamentals. If you canâ€™t design scalable systems or maintain server stability, you shouldnâ€™t keep piling more complexity on top â€” it only exposes the weaknesses even more.

The result is the same: lag spikes, server stutter, desync, and performance issues that follow you no matter your hardware. Once high pack size, multiple league mechanics, or heavy monster density appear, the game stops feeling like an ARPG and starts feeling like a stress test for bad infrastructure.

Whatâ€™s most painful is that it feels like the team doesnâ€™t understand their own engine anymore. The systems donâ€™t work together, the servers canâ€™t keep up, and the technical debt is so obvious that players can predict exactly when the game will break. That kind of failure doesnâ€™t come from lack of resources â€” it comes from lack of direction.

And to make it worse, thereâ€™s the long-standing issue that regular players constantly struggle with lag while certain streamers seem to enjoy perfectly smooth performance. Whether itâ€™s priority servers, special queue placement, or some form of backend favoritism, the outcome is the same: one group gets flawless gameplay while everyone else suffers. That disparity alone speaks volumes about where the attention goes â€” and where it doesnâ€™t.

If the people responsible for these core systems truly believe this level of performance is acceptable, then that alone says everything. Sometimes the hardest truth is this: when a team refuses to improve the basics, itâ€™s a sign theyâ€™ve reached the limits of what they can do.

The game is brilliant at its core, but the technical foundation is so poorly handled it overshadows everything good about it.

review_text: Annoying if you play it alone. Boring if in company.

It was great while it lasted- but if you're a new player: this game is a shadow of its former self. What used to be the highlight of my day turned into over bloated, poorly optimized, festering money pit. I don't regret my time: the Final Shape was a great way to end my career as a guardian. But after an embarrassing amount of hours and money- its just not worth it anymore. 

One of my favorite parts looking back would prob- ERROR CODE: WEASEL. VISIT help.bungie.net

This game straight up suffers from repetition. Most activities recycle the same encounters, which makes the experience feel routine instead of exciting. Thereâ€™s also no commitment to story as new expansions retire earlier missions and locations, which makes the world constantly feel like youâ€™ve missed out on something. 

Powerful gear either takes too long to earn or is always locked behind strict weekly limits that designed to slow progression. When you do earn these unlocks, balance changes make certain weapons or subclasses feel weaker just after you have invested time to master them.

The live service nature of Destiny 2 brings additional criticism. Communication from the developers is not always clear or timely. Delays, seasonal story pacing, and technical issues during major updates strain la playerâ€™s patience. The cost of expansions, seasons, cosmetic items, and additional features becomes overwhelming when combined.

I donâ€™t recommend this game unless youâ€™re into slop treadmills.
I miss how this game used to be, it was so much fun now its just horrid. It sucks but its just how the cookie crumbles.

The new player experience is the worst I've ever seen. I've tried to play this game at least 2 different times. I always tend to give up and get bored around the 4 hour mark of the tutorial missions. When you compare the tutorial mission a guardian rises from Destiny 1 and Destiny 2 there really is a night and day difference. One cutscene dumping a decade of Destiny lore in a minute is not really the play in terms of good story telling. It's unfortunately out of necessity since they "vaulted"/deleted half of the story rather than having the story unfold as the player experiences it.

Additionally the vaulting of content is the dumbest thing ever. It's 2025 and they haven't figured out how to add content without needing to subtract content. Meanwhile look at other free to play games like Warframe which continue to improve on the new player experience and add new content while keeping old content completely 100% playable. Every change is either an addition or something that genuinely was better for the game.

Destiny 1 was the better game and it's a shame we never got a PC port. Destiny 2 needs to improve the new player experience and return the vaulted content. If it did that it would be a genuinely good game. The gameplay is solid and the story has a lot of potential, but until those things are fixed this is not a good game and it is not worth giving this company your money or your time. I hope Bungie gets their act together but I'm not gonna hold my breath for that.
played since Fall 2014, Yuppies ruin entertainment, Star Wars cringe reddit :(
Bungie please give all the money I spent/spend on this game to the art team. They are the only reason I open this game every week.

After the sunsetting, Destiny went downhill. Most of us stuck around to see the end of the saga. With ups and downs, when they launched The Final Shape, we tought they would come back and be what the players wanted. We were very wrong.

Destiny used to be a unique game. "Planets" to visit, amazing campaign, well written villains and characters in general. With some teaks here and there, some QoL changes (like Lfg, loadouts and subclasses 3.0), legendary campaign for the old ones (Red War, CoO, Wm and Forsaken) and also, some changes of bosses mechanics would make Destiny a desirable game to play. Now it's just menus and cards (Portal), content we paid for is gone for good, new locations are not that interesting and not worth visiting. When Destiny was "not so good", even Mercury were packed with players. 

Now i feel that i don't even need locations to go and that's one of the reasons that made me quit Destiny. You could just chill in IO, Titan, Mercury or Mars. You could chase the meta or just play the game the way you want. We had fun, now Bungie is a generic company.

I felt robbed when they sunsetted the content we paid for but i stuck cuz the narrative was good and we still had some uniqueness to the game. Now we don't.

Maybe i will come back one day and edit this, saying that they gave us back what we paid for, but i highly doubt and that just makes me sad, because i really miss the "Journey" that Destiny used to be (yeah, the feeling of the game and the best music they made)

If somehow they come back with what we deserve, i will be the first to be around. Until then, i will just reminisce on the good times i had and how used to be fun to just be playing Destiny outside the menus.

This game was magnificent once, you know. Bungie should have walked away in 2020, while people were still applauding. But they insisted on milking it dry for profits and Pete Parsons very basic taste in classic cars.
I discovered Destiny in those years when Borderlands 2 had grown stale as yesterday's bread. And one boring day in school,  before me opened a pure greatness of game universe, that is a cathedral of a game design. A space western without tacky laser cowboys. Futuristic industrial design â€“ sublime, functional, memorable â€“ fused with magic that felt real and harked back to magic lore and mythology of our real world.
The first cracks on facade and mold in the basement appeared in Season 8. Patchnotes. "Shake up the meta," they proclaimed, as if a hurricane in a china shop constitutes strategy. Massive damage nerfs to weapons and unique traits of armor.
Sunsetting... that was the moment when the roof caved in and walls began to bulge. They took our weapons â€“ not just items, you see, but time made tangible. Hours of our lives, god rolls we treasured like family heirlooms... all discarded with a corporate smile about "player experience."
And then â€“ slow rot. Content became faceless. Witch Queen briefly lit the old light in the windows, Final Shape reminded us what this building could have been... but the foundation was eaten through. No weapon felt meaningful. No activity â€“ irreplaceable. Class building? A lick of a fresh paint on a bumpy hardwood floor and a new layer of a plaster on a bulged walls, that was carried out for too long, and amounted in too little result.
In 2018-2020 they gave us a cathedral. Magnificent. Singular. Then they buried that potential under layers of corporate incompetence and the paranoid fear of giving players too much.
Thank you for the memories, Bungie. Shame I am witness to decay of one of your greatest creations.

Cyberpunk 2077 is fine, I think. Probably one of the most 6/10 games I have ever played. It has a lot of side content, and there is definitely fun to be had, but it is more so in the Fallout 3 way of making your own fun. The cyberware feels half-baked, the perk system still feels like a first draft, melee feels basically unusable at higher difficulties, the writing is either pretty decent or just abysmal, a lot of the quest design is pretty boring and underdeveloped, the main quest ends right as it seems like it is about to get really interesting, and the city itself feels flat. It's got a lot of pretty buildings to look up at, but there is basically no meaningful verticality that the game plays with. At full price, I can not in good faith recommend the game. 

Phantom Liberty is a little better, I would probably rank it independently at around a 7/10 or maybe an 8/10, but that is mainly just because the writing and quest design is better and a lot tighter than the main game. The fundamental gameplay just does not feel good. Still pretty buggy, still a pretty bad "roleplaying game", and still a very superficial exploration of the themes of cyberpunk.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
There are definitely mechanics you can enjoy, but personally they missed the mark.

Movement is a little too floaty, feeling similar to ARK.
The skill tree feels like it should be split up so basic survival skills (e.g mining/chop speed) are not taking away from the more fun skills.
At least early on, the game does not feel great in terms of scaling to a larger group. We tried with 6 people  and there is a constant blast of information as people unlock things or talk to NPCs, and it feels silly just whacking every enemy in a 6v1 fight.
And the biggest problem was performance stability, for most of our group even with low settings FPS would regularly dip below 30.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
The start felt too much like Fortnite the survival game, in the worst way...I wanted to enjoy this game but I feel like there is not enough there to grab you at the start and I didn't want to keep the game to find out if it would grow on me so i refunded it.
I also feel like this game suffers a lot if you try and play it with too many players, I felt overwhelmed with pop-ups and didn't really know if I should be focusing on questing, exploring or survival.
Also my friends were struggling with performance a lot even after trying to make the game look like a fogged up mirror, so that is something to consider if you don't have a high end PC.

This game might become great when you progress but it's an expensive game to keep with hopes of enjoying it later.

genres: Action, Adventure, Indie, RPG, Early Access
review_text:
Not worth it in it's current state. I know it's Early Access, but holy moly is this ever rough around the edges. A lot of basic tutorials that you'd expect to get are simply not there, and the AI is pretty much "run in straight line and attack, repeat" for every enemy- which can still be difficult because enemies are often just spammed at you from spawners you can barely see and any attacks from behind count as backstab, even for enemies. So an enemy you didn't even know had spawned behind you can one shot you.

Which brings me to my next major gripe:  Darksouls style artificial difficulty.  Some traps and even simply existing in some areas will INSTANTLY KILL YOU. With no warning or indication whatsoever. The worst being the Shroud itself. The game doesn't tell you there are multiple "levels" of shroud, which to the player just looks like fog. There is no distinction between levels apparently. So you can be walking through shroud and be fine, then simply touch a higher level shroud and just instantly die. Insult to injury is that the game flashes a message on your screen warning you that you're IN a harder shroud area. *After* you are dead.

Being a caster is kind of a joke, as staffs require mana AND ammo, which is a huge pain in the ass to get mats for early on. Then there's the game's automatic target locking. You can't freely aim, you are stuck locking onto enemies and it can seriously screw you over if you're trying to shoot a barrel next to an enemy because. While I only found out later you can hold T and it will cancel target lock but only while holding T. There's permanent toggle.

The game has promise, but in it's current state, it is more frustrating than fun to play. Way too many annoying "choices" that bring the game down.

The performance optimization is still painfully garbage almost a year after I bought the game. I keep dropping it and telling myself "they'll probably fix it in a couple months", but at this point I don't know if that's ever going to happen. There's no reason this game should be running at sub 60FPS using medium to medium-high settings (With DLSS on performance), on a device with a core ultra 9, RTX 4080, and 32GB RAM. 

If these issues ever do get addressed, I can easily see myself putting in over a hundred hours in this game, but at it's present state, it just gives me a headache.

I'd say hold off on buying until the game is finished.

I actually loved this game. It's not as Dark Soul's like as I initial had thought, but that's not a bad thing in this case. Any Elden Ring/Dark Souls players will have an easy time with this game. I beat the last 4 bosses without a single death and that made me feel just as powerful as you should in a game where you're essentially the perfect automaton fighting a mass produced army.

Also I'd like to say that the story is A-Tier for me, the world is unique being in France during the reign of King Louie XVI and Marie Antoinette, and the addition clock work robots as the main character and enemies made this a unique experience. But as I said the story was pretty fun, no crazy plot twists or crazy revelations but just straightforward plot development which is not always in action heavy games.

This game is tagged as souls-like, but if it is, then it' a very generous souls-like. Can you imagine souls-like with infinite stamina (if built right) and infinite usages per item(as many as you can buy/collect))?
Overall, recommended if in discount, since it was released a while ago, no point of buying it full-price unless it's masterpiece, which this one is not.

Pretty good game overall, I'd recommend if you are looking for a soulslike that is short, has a fun story, and decent combat. 
I will say, the story is by far the strongest part of this game. I also really like that the devs tried a new spin on the genre, by adding interesting movement abilities. However, the levels were a bit too simple to really let these shine (even when backtracking, these abilities were used in pretty simplistic ways). 
The combat was okay, there were only a couple of weapon types (though they came with different special attacks, they were largely the same). The enemy variety was good considering the short runtime. 
The combat overall was really easy even w/o the assist mode. The bosses were a letdown - they were incredibly easy, and didn't really have any moves or combos to worry about. Also, their attack hitboxes were *really* bad - a lot of them you could just hug and they'd not be able to hit you with most of their attacks.
As a complete package, this is a fun game for the ~15hr runtime (not incl DLC). However, get it on sale, it is far too expensive at full price for what you get. But at ~$10, this game is a pretty fun time.
good game. 7/10, french revoltion but with soul eating robots.

Very interesting story, beautiful graphics and generally good gameplay and battles. This idea of automatons being the real enemies in the french revolution is an interesting view.

It is typical of a dark souls type of game with steep learning curve and monsters that respawn after each death or interaction with saving point.

In other games, where monsters do not respawn after each death and saving point, I usually play on adventure mode, like the step above story mode, but never hard core mode. I get tired of the unending grinding of games like this, where your progress don't mean shit if you havent reached a saving point. Killing 50 monsters just to die to the boss, and then having to kill them all again, is not my idea of fun.

Big plus that they have added "assist" mode so you can play more as in a story mode or similar to enjoy the game more, avoiding the unending grinding and actually be able to finish the game, even as an average player.

This would make for a great intro to Soulslikes for anyone hesitant or afraid of them.  This  has a great mode where you can essentially play it as easy as you want (take zero damage, even!) And while that is tempting, I'd encourage newbies to maybe just play the tutorial that way to get the hang of the mechanics and then go back and start a new game on the default difficulty. The tutorial/first level of this is by far the most difficult part and if you can get by that on default difficulty, then you can beat the game easily.  (even on default difficulty, there are items that can just trivialize bosses.) 

In addition, this game has a pause button so it is better than all the FromSoft games combined.

If Elden Ring had gone robotic/sci-fi versus fantasy, this is the game. I don't mean that in a good way. It's like they took Elden Ring's price-point and made worse gaming mechanics, while making it impossible to feel like you're gaining ground in the story line without dying and losing any power-up progress you've finally felt like you've gotten under your belt. The main-character to weakest-enemy power balance doesn't help in making you feel like your making story progression. I tried really hard to like this game, but they really need to either include more Vestule's so you don't have to go through the same 20-minute fighting sequence multiple times (either this or running past every minor robot to reach "boss-bots") or give you the opportunity to save game progress without the vestule's.

Could have been pretty decent but it had one major flaw. There is no substance.

Souls-Like games really arent just combat, thats just ARPG stuff... There is a lot that goes into the genre and world building, lore and most.importently NPCs are really vital for an impactful experience.

If you took the NPCs and or the way theyre set up out of the souls series or elden ring, they would feel exactly how this feels. Empty, lifeless, forgettable.

The way the game handles character interactions is the reason people are saying that they dont feel connected to it.

Take this advice, learn from it and apply it.

Also, please consider short cuts that actually make sense.

Overall id give it a 6.5/10 what it has is pretty good, but what it doesnt have hurts it.

Maybe it gets better later on but I dont want to play this type of game for 10 Hours until it gets good.
