review_text:
TLDR: The moderation is HORRIBLE and enough of the condos are riddled with sexual content (even depicting minors...) for it to be an ongoing problem. Don't support this game's echo chamber and hive mind/mob mentality. 
Initially starting out on this game I was impressed by the creative capabilities with condos and the amount of activities you could do with friends, so much so that I purchased one of the supporter packs. I'm a pretty reserved person so I don't speak up too often but after playing for a while in the plaza with my friends I began to notice the same kinds of people coming on making inflammatory statements, sexual comments, and just downright degeneracy. Then you look at their Steam profiles and see that many of those who frequent this game are SEVERELY detached from society, mentally unwell, and/or promote unhealthy things (like "consensual" sexual content with those who are underage). They seem to go by a "we don't take care of things unless they're reported" mentality unless you're speaking out against their hypocrisy, THAT is when you get some kind of ban as I have seen and heard of from many players, friend and not. They claim to defend against things like bigotry and certain figures so they can use those things as a blanket statement to silence what they don't agree with. I had a friend having a proper cordial discussion with a trans individual about how we should help take care of the trans community's mental health when they're young instead of just thrusting them onto HRT when someone came up and started harassing my friend, yelling over them, making load noises with items, and acting like my friend was being transphobic (they certainly are not and stated such several times). Evidently, after those 2 individuals went off to "chat" my friend was banned the very next day for HARASSING after never receiving so much as a warning prior to this. I can go into even more detail on other instances of inappropriate moderation but this review is already long enough and I'm honestly done with this game.

Filed a lawsuit against PixelTail Games due to the unprofessional and poor moderation; muting over serious concerns which shows most likely they do not know how to answer. There's multiple reports of CSAM/CP in condos (in reviews on Steam here, and claims/reports of users encountering it) and it has also been reported to Valve to delist the game. 
For asking what will be done regarding this problem since there's multiple reports (on Steam reviews & others spoken with); me & others get permanetely voice/text banned in game and within the social media such as discord.

This is not how you moderate your own product. If you do not have enough staff to moderate it, that is the companies fault for not being prepared and or properly staffed. It is a similar situation as to what's happening with Roblox for harboring predators as they have been taken to court for similar/same reasons.
There are minors that play this game at times, if you can't have the proper moderation for your product when there's reports of CP, it needs to shut down & or you need to have many more moderators, especially in game. It may be said they take this seriously, but yet it's a problem that keeps happening when it shouldn't as people still report this as a serious problem.
There should not be a single claim and or report of any predators on the platform. That is the fault of the company. In this case PixelTail, who should know better. I did not know how much of a problem this game had until only recently, when I first started playing this game a few years ago I did not know about these serious problems. The developers are their own moderators from what I read, which is not enough. They need an active moderation team in game and on the socials.
It is very strange that the community itself treats this as a joke, marking this review as funny. That's not normal and it only makes PixelTail look worse. That raises suspicions. only ones who would joke about a serious issue like this, may be predators themselves. Other games like vrchat are part of this problem too (which they've been notified with evidence multiple times by users). Some people need to have common sense as well, just because you have not seen something doesn't mean it doesn't happen. There's multiple reports of these problems by users for a reason. 
After the Roblox investigation, I feel many more of these kinds of games will have an investigation of their own at some point.

genres: Action, Adventure, Casual, Indie, Massively Multiplayer, Racing
review_text:
[b]TL;DR

I love this game and I love the interactions and conversations I've had through it. Do I recommend this game? No. Do I regret buying it, and the supporter packs? No. I have not and do not support Pixeltail through their Patreon. [strike]I will probably continue playing it since I have friends I introduced to it and I do enjoy condo building.[/strike] After having thought about it for a while, I won't be. There's no fixing this.[/b]

[h1]Gaming Time[/h1]

I think this game is horribly mismanaged. I'm not a game dev, I don't have any experience managing a company or studio. I also don't believe that any dev should take their community suggestions one to one and implement them full stop, it's their game and I respect that, but this game doesn't respect your time. I play all sorts of games, and I enjoy a good grind. In a game like Tower Unite, isn't the focus suppose to be on hanging out with people and making memories?

If you don't know, as it is with the current Halloween event you get a coin every 5 minutes, if you're actively playing a game that's not in the Casino or Condo- you must be the Plaza playing an plaza minigame, the Arcade, one of the game worlds (these are rewarded upon completion, so example, 5 days of Zombie Massacre + Boss) or you can earn them through Fishing, which isn't on a timer but is a percentage chance to drop. The best way to grind these are by Fishing and playing one game every 5 minutes. You can get coins from other activities, such as the Remains or Trick or Treat buckets, but those are also a percentage chance and on their own event timers.

If you want one Potted Carnivorous Plant, it costs 25 Ghoul Coins, which is 125 minutes, or 2 hours, spent so long as you're actively getting coins every 5 minutes exactly. This doesn't take into consideration that as of writing the backend for rewarding coins and other drops is bugged and the timer can be skewed. That is one copy of this condo item, and you cannot duplicate it without having multiple. Going off someone else's math, which has been consistent for the past 6 years I have played this game, if you want to buy one of everything, you'll need 328 coins or a minimum of 27 hours of just coin grinding. But we'll be fair and say you don't want or need everything, not everyone does.

Thing is, this is not just a holiday event issue. Usually you think of holidays as fun and rewarding, a distraction for people to get together and celebrate, but this is how the game is normally. Zombie Massacre, considering that you're playing solo and the meta, will take 15-20 minutes to earn roughly 30k units based on performance. If I go to the Casino and I play the horse betting game called Silver Saddles, I can bet 100k and make a minimum profit of that same 30k in what, 3-5 minutes tops? That's on the low end, a minimum total of 130k every game. This is considered an exploit. If you're an active condo builder who likes building with detail, 1 mil units is a drop in the bucket. Everything in Tower Unite has and will be funneled to the condo, unless you treat it like a party game to occasionally play with friends, which is perfectly fine too. Problem is, it is treated and advertised as the latter when the game is built with the former in mind, and not equally.

[h1]Social Hour[/h1]

A lot of people have and will continue to (rightfully) complain about the community. Yes, you have a wide breadth of people from all kinds of creeds and origins that will join a social game. Why anyone is suprised by that is beyond me, an individuals actions is what should be judged, not the individual or a generalized group. My problem comes with the fact that moderation in Tower Unite is negligble at best, straight up absent at it's worse. I'm also of the belief that a more laxed approach should be taken, and more users should use the Ignore/Mute and Block options that exists in games. Does that mean I am okay with the slurs, bigotry, harassment, and many other vile hatred statements that are spewed in this game? No. I just think for the most part that a lot of arguments can be handled like adults and most, including myself, are quick to anger and hatred.

Recently, there has been someone with an extensive track record of getting muted and banned for all sorts of reasons spamming a Discord link in the Global chat which can be seen by everyone in plazas, minigames, and condos as well as the main menu. Normally that's just a rule break, no advertising and solicitation? My problem with it is that it was a Discord link being advertised with another url that leads to a website advertising said Discord which has a focus on NSFW/Porn/Adult themes and sharing. Am I some sort of pearl clutching prude who hates the idea of adults enjoying themselves? No. Take one look at my profile. My problem is that it was being advertised in the Global chat and that person only got a 24 hour text chat ban, in a game that is not explicitly for adults, that allows children, teenagers, and vulnernable adults amongst each other. Some might mention the existence of Mature condos that feature similar imagery and chatting, but you need to explicitly turn on a setting to view those and it is not enabled by default. Global chat is on by default. Take Roblox as a better example of this kind of behavior and where it's getting them.

I'm not asking for the devs who are also the moderation team to be awake 24/7 and constantly monitoring the chat, nor am I asking for them to setup some kind of age verification or AI chat tool that'll constantly scan the chat. My solution? Get a moderation team. Problem with it? It's been asked and people have actively stepped up to say they will be a moderator. This and along with repeated harassment reports is completely normal behavior for most. This game doesn't have thousands of players, you see the same faces. The punishment does not fit the crime.

That is one incident that I didn't even fully cover, there are plenty of others, its an iceberg. And before I get asked "did you report", yes, I have reported people. Problem is, despite reporting, should I rely on a report, which might not be seen for several hours, for someone advertising adult servers, someone else doxxing, another hosting CSAM content? Why isn't there an active moderation team for a game thats active at all hours and allow you to run free?

[h1]More Questions[/h1]

I'm not someone who underestimates the time and patience it takes to not only develop a game, especially with the scope and scale that this game has. I have defended Pixeltail in the past, just like I have defended other games and studios, when I think they deserve it. I don't expect updates to come weekly, I don't expect anyone on to cater to me or anyone else. I also can't say I don't hesitate to make suggestions I know will be ignored. I'm not going to villainize Pixeltail.

It still does put into question why 1.0 released as rushed as it did. Why the Cats and Dogs update had a pack of dogs from an asset store, that wasn't even the full package, but one you can get through a pirated direct download. Why do you still need to spend so many hours to buy one silly little background for your profile that will only ever been seen by someone opening the scoreboard. Why there is so much going against you trying to have fun, from the backend that keeps track of of your inventory being bugged, to the chugging of servers past at 32/64 players, why an ingame Casino is more worth your time grinding than playing a game with your friends. Why are so many people allowed to get away with a slap on the wrist for such disgusting words and actions?

I was not a GMT (Garrys Mod Tower/GM Tower) player. I'm only speaking on recent feelings as of this year and the past few I've played. There is an extensive enough history not only in these reviews but their forums, from people who have spent a lot more time in game and are way smarter than me. I love Tower Unite, but I dont think Pixeltail does.

Resident Evil 7: Biohazard marks a bold and terrifying return to the seriesâ€™ survival horror roots. By shifting to a first-person perspective, the game plunges players directly into the claustrophobic and unsettling world of the Baker family, delivering an intensity and immersion rarely seen in horror games.

The atmosphere is pitch-perfect: every creaking floorboard, shadowy hallway, and grotesque detail contributes to a constant sense of dread. The gameâ€™s visuals and sound design are exceptional, combining to make even familiar settings feel deeply menacing.

Gameplay emphasizes survival and careful strategy. Ammo and resources are scarce, forcing players to think before they act and heightening the tension of every encounter. Puzzles and exploration are intelligently designed, rewarding curiosity while maintaining a constant sense of vulnerability.

The story is gripping and horrifying, blending psychological terror with body horror in a way that feels fresh yet unmistakably Resident Evil. The Baker family, particularly Jack Baker, are unforgettable antagonists whose presence keeps players on edge throughout.

Overall, Resident Evil 7: Biohazard revitalizes the franchise with a terrifying, immersive experience that balances horror, story, and gameplay flawlessly. Itâ€™s a must-play for both longtime fans and newcomers seeking a true survival horror thrill.

Rating: 9.5/10

Overall, Resident Evil 7 is a pretty intense ride. Coming from Resident Evil 2 remake, this one definitely hits way harder in the scare department, even if the first-person view makes some of the boss fights feel a bit awkward. The DLCs are a mixed bag, some fun, some not really my thing, but theyâ€™re unique enough to keep things interesting. 

All in all, itâ€™s a solid horror experience thatâ€™s worth checking out.

ğŸŒŸ [b][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/45575657]Follow Ainsel Reviews - Curator for the weird & lovely[/url][/b] ğŸŒŸ

I didnâ€™t walk into that house to be a hero.
I just wanted her back.
That was my first mistake.

Nothing prepares you for the Bakers. No horror movie, no nightmare, no childhood fear. They donâ€™t just attack you â€” they claim you. Jack speaks to you like youâ€™re already family. Marguerite feeds you like she wants you to rot properly. Lucas watches you break and laughs because he knows heâ€™s already won.

Every time I healed, the pain returned differently.
Every time I lost part of myself, something else grew in its place.
The house learned me.
Room by room. Breath by breath.

And the worst part? A part of me understood it. The mold doesnâ€™t lie. It shows you exactly what youâ€™re made of â€” usually blood, panic, and very bad decisions.

The DLCs feel like the memories I tried hardest to bury. Fragments, regrets, things I didnâ€™t want to relive but kept resurfacing like the swamp water in my lungs. Some offered closure. Some reopened wounds that never had time to close.

I survived.
But survival feels like a technicality.

If you play this â€” and Iâ€™m not saying you should â€” just remember:
That house doesnâ€™t stay where you left it.
It follows.

Now that the dust settled on RE2, and more than half a decade passed since i last played RE7, i REALLY notice how all the fun moments of this game take place on a tightly scripted roller coaster. 7 years ago i was terrified and didn't notice at all, but now standing in the one spot that the game allows me to not be seen by "daddy" feels very boring and over-designed. Since RE7 came out about 3 years after Alien Isolation, i really expected there to be a much more open map, or options to fight back against anyone else than the molded. After all, the invincible family promote exactly the same gameplay as the Alien: stalk and hide. 
Amnesia: The Bunker clearly had the same aspirations, and took a tighter designed approach to its core loop with an algorithmically randomized bunker that prompts the player to figure it out on their own, instead of bombarding them with duller and duller chase sequences.

But everytime you are allowed roam around an area at your own pace you are either set up for the next jumpscare (eta <2 minutes), or you just fight molded. Large goo guys. They have big heads that burst open on headshots. They walk as if they have a stick up their ass. And they are veeeery boring, i even remember how dull i found them when i first played it. And unlike the first RE games, there is no real way to walk by them without wasting large amounts of ammo. sad.

I never made it to the ending since i heard that was where the molded stuff peaks, and i feel i've REALLY seen enough of it by now. All the best parts of this game are a tasteless and gory slasher film. Exactly what RE needed at the time, but not what i cherish about the series at all. 2/5

I really love Resident Evil series and I wanted to complete my collection with the new Resident Evil games, but Resident Evil 7 makes me angry, not because it's an FPS now or a new character or different story. IT'S BECAUSE THE CHARACTER CAN'T RUN! Everything is so slow, unlike the remakes, where everything works, but, RE7 makes you angry, not because of enemies, or the story, or a new perspective, because it wasn't built as it should. After 2 hours, the pacing feels off and the horror didnâ€™t land for me. Might appeal to fans of slow-burn tension, but I couldnâ€™t get into it.

Growing up in the early 2000's, Resident Evil was a series I was familiar with but never played. I didn't care for the horror genre, and the games seemed really creepy to me. Recently I decided to try something new and buy this game along with Resident Evil VIII in a combo package for $20. This game had good reviews, and I didn't want to spoil anything so I went in blind. Minor spoilers ahead.

The build up to this game was good, and the first 20mins set the scene well. You're looking for your fiance that disappeared 3yrs ago because she recently contacted you with her location. You drive to a desolate swamp in Louisiana and find an abandoned house and shack. At this point the game started getting really creepy, and I enjoyed how it was building up. It reminded me of Texas Chainsaw Massacre. You find your fiance locked up in the basement. Turns out she's been possessed by something. She attacks you with a knife and you defend yourself with your bare hands. She stabs right through your hand and I was like "oh shit...". About 10secs later your pour hydrogen peroxide on the wound and it magically heals up. Really? This immediately killed the immersion for me. 2mins later, your SAME hand gets stabbed again. Then it gets cut off by a chainsaw. At that point I was like "Oh SHIT!". You get a pistol and somehow reload the gun while holding the gun with your only hand. It made very little sense. I'm not kidding, about 2mins later, your hand gets stapled back on like nothing happened. This was like a slap in the face. I always thought these games were more realistic. Sure they have monsters and zombies, but I didn't know the main character was a fucking super human. To make things worse, I got stuck right after the dinner scene and didn't know where to go. I was already bored so I let the psycho kill me. He hit me about 10-15 times, and I'm playing on normal difficulty. I plan on finishing this game, but my expectations are pretty low at this point. Hopefully as I continue this play through my thoughts will change.

Got bored because of the resurrection S.... Finished RE4 remake before this and thought to finish 7 and 8 before starting 9. But I need to skip this part again. I'll prefer RE4 type game play rather than this.

So I know REs have always been goofy and I love them for it (played all of them multiple times all the way up to 6,) so imagine my surprise when this one is trying to do it like, seriously. 

And then boss gets into a car and starts drifting around in a tiny garage like he's channeling the spirit of Ken Block himself. Yep, never change RE, stay super goofy. Sadly I kinda stopped playing at that point because I couldn't stop laughing and I just didn't get invested in the story or anything.

Having gamed on a PC for most of my life, I find this game a bit bland for my taste. I can see how people that used to play FFX etc on PS2 see it as a polished version of what they used to play as kids, but I just can't seem to get immersed in it.

I've tried so much to like it, but I get bored and cannot come to terms with the limited gameplay, even though there's so much customization with different weapons, skills and attribute combinations.

The game world lacks soul, even though everybody says that there's a very engaging main story with plot twists, which I cannot find the courage to follow because of the boring gameplay.

I used to love old JRPGS on SNES and PSX, but there was the perceived freedom that you were in an open world. This game just throws you in a PS2-like linear minimap that you have to navigate and inevitably come across a minimap boss that looks like it's come from the Dark Souls series.

Anyway, I get the nostalgia some people may feel playing this game, but I just can't recommend it to anyone remotely interested in a game world that actually feels alive and your meaningful interaction with it.

no spoilers:  its a story heavy, turn based combat game with lots of evade/parry mechanics. if you hate dodging on a regular basis via button presses this game is not for you. also if you do not enjoy different modes of fighting for each character, or lack of exposition, give this one a miss.
 the world building is solid, the characters complex. the emotional beats had enough development to give real payoff.

  its a difficult game, you may die facing some of the big enemies (which can take over 10 minutes of fighting, dodging etc) which can be fustrating if you miss a single dodge which ruins that attempt- this is a rare occurence, but i did encounter from time to time.

I'm not a fan of this game. It's not a bad game, but to call it a "game" is stretching it.  I'll give it 7 out of 10.  The thing people love most about it is the concept and the story. It is amazing. The first 60 minutes or so of the prologue is great and it sucks you in. The direction and acting is fantastic. 

Where it falls short is the actual gameplay and mechanics. It's uninspired and boring. When you learn to dodge and parry, then every battle or confrontation becomes painfully mundane. I found myself only doing the battles I needed to just to move the story along so I could watch the movie. This could be a great movie when it comes out. 

This game is very linear. There isn't much deviation from the main storyline in terms of side-quests or other relatable characters. The world is not that open and explorable. 

Other games that have similar cult-like following are Elden Ring and Disco Elysium. Neither of them I particularly enjoyed.

Dear Devs,
I am high-functionally autistic, so I prefer turn-based games over real-time action because my reactions are kinda â€¦ slow.
I can manage to survive many real-time action games in â€storyâ€œ/â€easyâ€œ mode, so we are not talking about pathological impairments here.
I WILL keep the game, and I so much WANT to love it for its deep story and beautiful art design, but there is one complaint I need to state here as an official bug report or feature request - WHEN I SET EASIEST STORY MODE, I WANT A FAIR EASY STORY MODE!!!
LOWER THE DODGE/PARRYING TIMINGS ASAP! 
IF PLAYERS WANT CHALLENGING TIMINGS, THEY DONâ€˜T CHOOSE STORY MODE!

I am very much willing to totally twist around my review to thumbs up and praise if you are so kind to reach out to me and/or somehow reconsider your choice in quicktime timings and hardness to be more inclusive for those who are not just â€too lazy to get goodâ€œ, but at a weaker point at all. Why must games be so hard in general without including additional customers (more than you might think?) to also be served with a great game?
I am willing to practice and learn, but within my personal comfort zone and capabilities.
If there is a story mode, make it a fair story mode, not a 1% less super-hard-mode, in my very personal opinion, this is almost false advertising at its finest.
PLEASY, MAKE IT SUPER HARD FOR THOSE WHO CHOOSE HARD MODE, 
You can design achievements only for those playing harder modes, I am with you, or give more or less XP in-game for harder play styles, but please donâ€˜t exclude players that are just more casual or even have some limits. Your game is pretty, packed with story and emotion, why exclude such a wide range of players from enjoying it?

Occasionally there's a multimodal masterpiece that touches on all the softest and most bedraggled places inside you and makes demands of your fundamental humanity to be accountable for the state of the universe. 
That surveys the sum of the furthest reaches of where you have extended your thinking and makes all those years of feeling mushy minded into an actual shame because you may go there all the time on your own but other people are speaking it out into the world in ways that display such thoroughly grounded comprehension. It feels like love making of the sort you could've and should've been offering to the world if you'd just only been slightly less broken.
And you're left breathless and enthralled and so grateful that the handheld dimensions of which we're the inheritors are being used by visionaries to glorify the heart of the world.

This is far better than I realized it would be. It makes you feel like Sherlock Holmes, you need to be smart about who you talk to and what you mention. Everyone has opinions, everyone has a motive, and things are far more complicated than you thought. Only 5 hours in and I'm hooked!

RHETORIC â€“ Psst, hey, you!

YOU â€“ Who -- me?

RHETORIC â€“ Yes, you. Word on the street is you're ready to talk about what *ZA/UM* did again!

YOU â€“ 'Again'?

RHETORIC â€“ Yes -- you're ready to dig into ZA/UM drama *again*. You've talked about it before, *they've* talked about it before. Hasn't really worked out yet, but neither have all those *spiritual successors* -- should we just stop making them, too?

YOU â€“ Can't argue with that.

RHETORIC â€“ So, what about all that bitterness you've been carrying? Word on the street is you've woken up from a thousand years of slumber, ready to speak of the studio's controversy louder than ever attempted before. Is that true?

YOU â€“ How come there's *word on the street*?

RHETORIC â€“ You keep saying things like *down with the ZERO PARADES*, *eat the board of directors*, *sodomize the ip-owners*, *impale all people who have more than 25% of the shares*, *literally teabag all corpo clowns regardless of their involvement in pushing out the visionaries* -- that kind of stuff.

YOU â€“ Oh, right. That sounds like me.

RHETORIC â€“ Funky-style. Very funky. So tell me. Do you have any questions before we fire up the Big ZA/UM Cancellation, or do we get right down to it?

This game is terrible.

I'm quite confident I just didn't 'get it', but after playing for a few hours, I discovered there's a core mechanic that means if you failed a skill check (over which you have no control of course) the game ends... You loose... and must start again or reload until you DON'T fail the skill check.

The reason for this seems to be some kind of moral system whereby if you moral drops to zero it's as good as dying, only you can heal health and avoid fights, but you cannot avoid skill checks, unless you just want to remain in your hotel room and go nowhere and do nothing.

Like I say, perhaps I'm playing it wrong cos lots of other people give this good ratings and it did somewhat make me laugh a couple of times, but when I'm forced to sit in a chair so uncomfortable a single skill check failure looses me the game, but I cannot progress without having the conversation... Nah, pointless. Irritating and few other words for "Wish I'd had this experience before I'd played it for 2 hours and could no longer get a refund on this pointless waste of time".

TLDR: Don't play the game if you have self esteem issues or CPTSD. It WILL trigger you in a negative and harmful way. 

Full Review:
This isn't a game for people who've been through certain types of trauma. Namely, trauma having to do with your self esteem and value. First of all, you do NOT get to customize a character. One is given to you and he's already a psychological mess. If you have deep wells of empathy this game will trigger you in a way that is more harmful than good. The overall message is for people who haven't yet developed the skills or life experience to understand the illusion of choice is not freedom. It's a game with a very dark, nihilistic message. While Nihilism can be enlightening and even freeing for some people, this game doesn't really allow you to explore those aspects of it. It tends to repeatedly highlight only the worse parts of humanity in a context absent of hope or empathy. Why the devs would include an entire segment of dialogue that analyzes and breaks down racism in support of it, is a confusing and concerning choice. There are better ways of exposing how toxic racism is without glorifying at the same time. The game is definitely thought provoking but it does it in a very abusive manner that could be harmful to people who struggle with CPTSD, AuDHD and healthy emotional regulation. 
This game shook me because I've already learned the darker lessons and hard truths life ultimately teaches you. I didn't need a rerun of trauma and I think the lessons could be learned without it, but I understand why some people feel it's necessary. It might be a great game, but it's not for everybody and that's why I can't recommend it.

DO NOT PURCHASE FROM ZA/UM.

I decided to write this review since I see a lot of people have a rough time with the entry barrier into Master Duel. 

Master Duel is described by Konami as the place where you will duel at the highest level and when they say highest level they are not downplaying it. First things you need to be aware of is that yes there is a barrier when you start playing that at first might seem overwhelming, but you need to remember you are jumping at the deep-end of the Yu-Gi-Oh! dueling experience. Some people criticize Master Duel for not being beginner friendly, and although I do agree there is a curve to adapt to in terms of dueling, specially for people who are returning to Yu-Gi-Oh after many years away or people who have only watched the anime or who are experiencing the brand for the first time, I also think the game gives you the tools so that you are able to build a strong deck very early into the game. 

Chances are yes you are going to get whooped during your first couple of duels, but that is to be expected since you are at the first steps of your deck building but if you put your time to learn the ins and outs of the game, it is a great way to enjoy the franchise. 

Some useful things things for people willing to give it a shot:
- Master Duel is very very F2P friendly, the game gives you so many easy ways to get gems (the currency used for opening packs) and occasionally even give you full structure-decks through things like friend code referral and such. If you manage your gems correctly you can easily make a viable competitive deck in just a few minutes and can probably average a new deck every month or so.

- Do your tutorials (skip them if you have a basic understanding of the game) and after, when picking one of the 3 beginners decks, just pick the one that matches your latest understanding of Yu-Gi-Oh! 

- Before entering ranked matches, go to solo mode and there you will find many "missions" that reward you with cosmetics such as mates, duel fields, sleeves and even some actual card, but most importantly finishing the Duel Strategy missions reward you with a total of 2,400 gems. By doing solo mode not only can you unlock different rewards but you will also fulfill some of the challenges and missions that reward you with even more gems. 

- Now when it comes to currencies we have gems which are used to open card packs and just buy anything from the store and you also have crafting points (CP) ranging from Normal, Rare, Super Rare, and Ultra Rare points. These CP are used to craft cards individually which is helpful if the card you are looking for is not available on any dedicated pack or if you only need to craft 1 copy of that card. In principle crafting a card take 30 CP regardless of the rarity (and when crafting there is a random chance of it being one of three different types of foiling which basically just means how shiny the card will be). Then some cards you don't want can be dismantled into CP of the corresponding rarity of the card going from 10 - 30 CP depending on the foiling of the card dismantled. One thing to note with CP is that not all cards can be dismantled as some free cards you get wont be able to be dismantled, but every card from pack openings can be dismantled into CP (cards from structure decks can't be dismantled tho). Best tip is to spend your SR CP and UR CP wisely and only when you really want or need a card since they are the hardest points to gather at first.

- Now before building a deck, opening packs and crafting cards you need to ask yourself the most important question when joining Master Duel for the first time - Which deck do you want to play with? - This is the most important decision you will have to make since the deck you chose will be your partner for the first month or so, so more than a meta deck just go for the one you will have the most fun with.

- Once you know which deck you want to go with, the best thing to do is to just create a deck and add all the cards you will want in it, that way you will know which cards you have, which cards you are missing and their respective rarities. Then you have to best options, one of them is to take one SR or UR card from that archetype and craft it, in doing so you will unlock a secret pack from that archetype which then you can spend your gems opening packs to get cards from that archetype. You can also go into the store and look at the structure decks and see if the archetype you want is available there, that way by spending 500 gems you will get access to the core of the archetype and can be a shortcut to building your desired deck.

- 2 PRO TIPS when it comes to gems are NEVER SPEND GEMS on the MASTER PACK since the amount of cards in it makes it impossible to get anything you actually want (you are better sticking to secret packs) and also ALWAYS BUY THE DUEL PASS since this battle pass not only returns your gem investment if completed but also rewards you with limited-time accessories and tons of CP from all the rarities.

- If you really want to add a meta element to your deck you can also go to the shop special section and under bundle deals you will see bundles with 10 Master Packs and also a meta staple card. 

- With all of this said if you dismantle any and every card you dont need and if you claim your rewards and open more packs you will end up with a good deck to enter ranked as any cards you dont get can probably be crafted with the CP earned from the dismantle of cards. 

When it comes to dueling the game helps you flagging posible actions that can be taken or cards that can be played in case you are not fully experienced with your deck. As you climb through ranked you will earn more gems that can be used to make your deck stronger and such. 

Again, as this is a competitive TCG it does take time to settle in but the more time you put and as long as you are playing cards that are fun to you I really think this game has a lot to offer for Yu-Gi-Oh! fans. Ranked might be a tough pill to swallow at first but by making mistakes and losing duels is how you will learn.

As a avid TCG player who has been heavily invested in the game since 2005, I have to say this is nearly unplayable.

While naturally it shares every issue with normal gameplay of the real card game, it also goes much deeper then that. First point: The gatcha system (while theres certainly FAR worse ones out there) is terrible. Grinding gems takes forever and once you've cleared solo mode, say goodbye to ever getting anything new ever again, because the game will VERY slowly drip feed you a paultry sum of gems IF YOU WIN a ranked match and thats about it (GOOD LUCK winning without a tier 0 deck)

Second point: Cheaters. The game is FULL of them. Everything you can imagine. FTK bots, AFK bots, players who can see your hand at all times, people who manipulate the cards drawn on both sides, deck stacking, its awful and nearly unplayable.

Third point: The TERRIBLE and WILDLY inconsistent banlist. So...you're telling me that the current tier 0 (which has been tier 0 for nearly 3 months now) doesn't have a single card even so much as semi-limited, but secret village, card of demise, POT OF PROSPERITY are banned? Maxx C is at 2. Pot of duality is at 1. What.

Fourth point: It is VERY begginer hostile. The game just expects you to casually pay over 100 REAL LIFE dollars to MAYBE get a CHANCE at getting specific cards that are essential and you litterally CAN NOT win even in rookie without. 

Fifth point: Bugs. And lots of them. I get this is the most complex card game of all time so naturally, when in digital form, its not gurenteed to work properly every time, but this is absolutely ridiculous. Were getting nonsense like a card that does NOT have to be face-up to resolve somehow fizzeling after being MST'd, cards whos activation requirement is something like "Target 1 card you control" and somehow not being allowed to activate it despite the fact there is NOTHING preventing targeting anywhere, special summoning from the grave with necrovalley on the field, ect ect. FIX YOUR GAME KONAMI

From the start of the game to the credit roll, Nier is a pleasant and melancholic game that pours a lot of attention into its side quests to paint a picture of life in a dying world.  It's a game as much about loving the NPCs struggling day after day as it is about its character-driven main story.

However, you may be aware that Nier is a game with multiple endings.  Rather than a choice of parallel endings that you see in many RPGs, this game follows from Drakengard and VNs in having sequential endings that build upon each other.  Or at least, they try to.

The positive part of my review ends at the credit roll for Ending A.  (Or a little afterâ€”the backstory you get for KainÃ© just after is also easily worthwhile.)  To reach the other endings, you have to repeat sections of the game again and again and again.  The actual new content is minimalâ€”just a few extra cutscenes stretched thin across old bones.  What new content there is is rarely interesting, instead repeating or expanding emotional points that were already present in the original playthrough and could've been included the first time around.  The personality flaws of the main cast go unexplored, and the extra characterisation for your enemies changes the story from a tragedy into a tone-deaf farce.  Meanwhile, what emotional impact the story originally had is scrubbed off as you sit through the same scenes again and again, waiting for it to be over.

It should also be noted that combat itself is very shallow, and really doesn't stand up to replay.  By my final run of the ending boss gauntlet, I had figured out several points [i]during combat[/i] where I was free to scroll on my phone while button mashing or evading one-handed, barely glancing at the game screen.

There is at least some actual novel material when you get to the final ending, and it's quite sweet... but it's only enough to remind you that the first half of the game was actually good, and not enough to justify the crime against art that is the second half of the game.

NieR Replicant delivers a haunting story and beautiful atmosphereâ€”but itâ€™s buried under a grind-heavy, opaque design that disrespects your time. Key quests and materials can vanish without warning, and unlocking deeper endings requires repetitive tasks and hidden requirements that arenâ€™t explained in-game. Youâ€™re forced to consult guides just to avoid being locked out of content.

This shit ass

[b]"Nier Replicant" might have been a decent game back in 2010â€”with its deep lore (which laid the foundation for the "Nier Automata" masterpiece), eerie atmosphere, philosophical writing, compelling characters, and fantastic music. But its 2021 remaster assumes it still fits the modern gaming landscape and has something fresh to offer. Unfortunately, it falls short.
The world feels empty and generic, the visuals are mediocre, and the gameplay mechanics are datedâ€”reduced to following dots on a map and completing trivial fetch quests. Combat is shallow, with limited abilities and builds, repetitive enemies, problematic camera angles, and virtually no environmental sound design. Long, tiring walks and constant backtracking through the same locations make the experience feel like a chore. Worst of all, the game forces players to replay the same content up to five times to see the full story.
Had I played it back in 2010, I might have felt differently. I'm not sure because some thing would still bother me. But releasing it at full AAA price in 2021 invites comparison to modern titlesâ€”and by todayâ€™s standards, it simply doesnâ€™t deserve your time or money.


Manometer: 4/10[/b]  


The good
- Interesting concept: The lore is rich and later became the backbone of "Nier Automata". The writing explores philosophical themes and occasionally becomes poetic. The text-adventure-style segments are especially beautiful.
- Well-crafted characters: Though a bit stereotypical, the main cast has vivid personalities that are easy to love.
- Despite the empty world and average visuals, the game creates a haunting, fairy-tale-like ambiance.
- The soundtrack is stunning and enhances the moodâ€”though it plays constantly and can become overwhelming.
- Voice acting performances lean toward the epic rather than realistic, but they effectively convey each characterâ€™s personality and intent
- Nice, fluid animations with smooth transitions between moves. The feeling on the controller is great. It's nice that most weapons have different move sets.
- Well designed boss battles. Uniquely designed encounters that blend platforming mechanics with reflex-based challenges
- Battles are mediocre yet mixing melee attacks with projectile magic is a nice idea that adds a layer of depth.
- A subtle, clever sense of humor lightens the tone without becoming silly.

The bad
- I know it's a 2010 game, yet I was expecting more in this remaster especially after the "Nier Automata" success. Most models are low-poly, textures are poor (sometimes tiled), and the world feels repetitive and generic. Invisible walls and frequent loading screens break immersion.
- Again, this is a remaster of an older game but in 2021 a lot of things look obsolete. It's open world logic is completely worn forcing you to blindly follow markers on the map. A lot of the main objectives look like fetch quest as you have to go to various characters to see what they need. Its world is too small with only a few regions that the game forces you to visit again and again to face different enemies that weren't there before. In addition to that each region is usually filled with copy-paste corridors. All this repetition makes it boring.
- Shallow RPG mechanics. Few abilities and weapon combinations mean limited build diversity. New gear is usually just a straight upgrade, removing strategic choices.
- You have to walk into unbelievable long distances. Quests often send you back and forth to the same locations with minimal shortcuts. A lot of times after beating all the enemies in a region and fulfilling the objective, you have to backtrack though empty rooms. The fast travel mechanics that it offers are silly and don't alleviate the grind.
- Battle is mediocre. Despite teaching various tactics, most fights devolve into button-mashing chaos. A lot of battles become an indistinct blend of enemies and balls. It usually feels like they're undesigned. In addition to that healing or using items via menu pauses breaks the flow and feels outdated
- Except from the bosses, regular enemies are completely generic. Aside from bosses, most foes are indistinct black shapes with no unique traits. They just filled every region with the same enemies. Easily some of the most boring encounters I've ever met in a video game.
- Pointless side quests: Tasks like â€œbring an eggâ€ or â€œfetch a watermelonâ€ lack narrative depth and disrupt the main storyâ€™s vibes and continuity. Overall pacing is problematic Repeated visits to the library to speak with Popola feel unimaginative.
- It has multiple endings, yet after the first playthrough it becomes a chore. While multiple playthroughs reveal new story elements, they require replaying large portions of the game with no changes at all. Unlike "Nier Automata" which offered fresh perspectives and gameplay shifts it forces you even to go through repeated dialogues smashing the skip button just to unlock a few new cutscenes. It's an unbelievable choice that they punish you with this boring repetitiveness if you want to learn the whole story. Even more unbelievable is that you have to find all weapons in order to go through ending C.
- Cameras are weird and problematic. The camera often fails to follow the protagonist properly, and manual rotation is sluggish. Sudden shifts to top-down or side-view angles are too often feel arbitrary and disorientingâ€”unlike "Automata, where such changes were purposeful and enhanced gameplay. Here all these side scrolling platforming sessions and scenes that look like old arcades seem to be rushed and not so successful.
- Boss battles are well designed with some interesting mechanics, yet this thing with their health bars is a joke. These are inconsistent and confusing. Bars refill or change without clear logic, making it hard to gauge progress and turning them into a gimmick.
- Despite the deep lore and the good writing the the core narrative is basic and often relies on melodramatic clichÃ©s like self-sacrifice or excessive epic moments. 
- There is no environmental sound design at all. Here music dominates every scene, leaving no room for ambient sounds that could enhance immersion. Even moments of silence would have added depth.
- Ok it's not a puzzle game but if you decide to put some of them in there better make them interesting. The few puzzle rooms are overly simplistic and feel like filler content for children.
- Unbalanced difficulty. The game is generally too easy.. You will die only one or two time during a few boss battles. There is no challenge at all. Also, In subsequent playthroughs enemies remain mid-game strong while youâ€™re at new game++ level. They cannot even touch you and you almost one hit kill them. Really boring.

I played Automata back in 2017. Being much younger, tolerating stuff like "you have to beat the game 3 times to reach the ending" wasn't really an issue. Now in 2025, I sadly do not have the same free time to spend it on games like Replicant.

First things first. This game should have been a complete remake. This game actually feels like a very good remaster, in the sense that you feel like you are playing a PS3 game. The problem is, this remaster was released in 2021. So many other very good games came out that year so we dont really have much when it comes to technology not being enough. Toylogic simply didn't take any risks. The gameplay is incredibly stale, upgrades are mostly unnecessary and boring, spells are pretty fun for the first couple of hours but then get forgotten. The game nearly always felt like a chore to play. And I had to finish the game twice (Well actually 3 times if you want to see the real ending but i couldnt be arsed and watched it on youtube.) They really should have mishmashed Automata's different weapon styles with Reincarnation's spells to make it unique.

Enemies. Boring. Small dude. Big dude. Big dude with shield. Even bigger dude. Even bigger dude with shield. The bosses were pretty cool but there sadly are 5 of them and you are constantly put against them because of the repetition which kills their uniqueness. Again, extremely boring due to repetitiveness. Which is a very common issue with the game overall.

Scenery. It is pretty decent looking. For a PS3 game. For a remaster that was released in 2021, it looks bleak, the colors are dead and the settings are just bland. Some scenes were pretty but I never got the same feeling I got from Automata's introductions to new areas. 

Characters. Now this is a strange topic because Nier games are all about mystery and being attached to these characters who are put through hell for us to enjoy. I don't like the brother sister troupe so it was a miss for me (which is a personal thing and not an objective critisism) but the tones the characters give off is very weird. Nier, the main dude, is basically a slave. First to his sister, then to the villagers, then to his comrades, and finally to the village leaders. He is one of those main characters who never asks anything and just helps people around for the sake of helping. Then does a complete 180 and becomes something completely else. With no buildup, it just doesn't work. Side characters are pretty unique but without spoilers, I don't really like how they evolve as well. They lose their uniqueness while becoming generic with each minute you spend together.

And yes. The story. Yes, Yoko Taro fashion, it tells a very unique story with intense twists and turns. But I highly doubt it's worth the 35+ hour slogfest of mashing 2 buttons while going from marker to a marker. My recommendation is just read / watch an explanation about the story and skip to NieR: Automata. If they remaster Drankengard like this, I'm staying the hell away from it this time around.

In my opinion, this is one of the most interesting political strategy games ever made. The atmosphere is outstanding, the music fits perfectly, and the graphics are lovely for a game of this genre.

If you're looking for a strategy game that focuses more on political depth and decision-making rather than just constant battles and sword-fighting, this is the one. I'm not saying the war mechanics are badâ€”far from itâ€”but the core of the game lies in governing, diplomacy, and managing your nation, rather than simply rushing to conquer everything like a careless child.

CRPG renaissance

Divinity: Original Sin â€“ Enhanced Edition is a tactical role-playing game that revitalizes the classic CRPG formula with depth, freedom, and smart writing. It combines strategic turn-based combat, meaningful player choice, and cooperative gameplay to create one of the most complete role-playing experiences of its generation.

The story follows two Source Hunters investigating a mysterious murder in the city of Cyseal, gradually uncovering a plot that threatens the fabric of reality. The narrative is layered with humor, moral ambiguity, and philosophical undertones. Dialogue choices matter, influencing character relationships, quests, and even combat outcomes.

Gameplay is defined by its interactivity. Almost every object, surface, and environmental element can be manipulated. Fire spreads, water conducts electricity, and poison ignites. Combat becomes a puzzle where creative thinking often wins over brute force. This system rewards experimentation, not repetition.

Character creation and progression are flexible. Players can customize skills, attributes, and abilities without being locked into rigid classes. Cooperative play enhances this freedomâ€”two players can explore, argue over choices, or separate to pursue different objectives simultaneously. The resulting dynamics make co-op feel organic rather than forced.

Visually, the Enhanced Edition improves textures, lighting, and interface clarity while keeping the gameâ€™s distinct hand-painted fantasy style. The redesigned UI and full voice acting make exploration and dialogue more immersive. Every conversation and environment feels alive and reactive.

The writing maintains a balance between wit and seriousness. Quests often carry multiple solutions, and morality is never simple. Whether youâ€™re solving a murder, arguing with a talking shell, or deciding the fate of an entire village, the game constantly invites critical thinking and reflection.

In essence, Divinity: Original Sin â€“ Enhanced Edition is a masterclass in player agency and tactical depth. Itâ€™s challenging, rewarding, and endlessly replayable. Every decision feels personal, every victory earned through intellect and creativity. It stands as one of the finest examples of modern role-playing design rooted in classic principles.

This game to me is one that deserves a mixed rating. While I liked the game and had fun playing it, there were plenty of times  when it felt more of a slog to get through. The world is semi open-world that is both good and bad. Constant Saving felt like a must

Starting off, making my characters was fun, there were a good amount of classes to choose from. Playing around with some starting skill options, personal customization was ok nothing too crazy for the Two Player Characters you create as my heroes.
A few voices to choose from, personalities etc. Not everything in the game is voiced, most MC dialogue gets voiced with their little side quips, side characters here and there, most dialogue will be read. A few companions to choose from, I choose two and rocked with them, since I believe if you swap them in later their level's won't match yours, needs more testing?

Combat was fun and not fun, while it worked and gave me chances to be creative with combining the environment, items I have, spells and such to fight, it meant the enemy could do the same. With the world being open-ish often I'd find myself in fights I wasn't going to win, the battles can drag on since the AI sometime is fast, othertimes It's like Internet Explorer making a turn. Getting wiped just to fight the same long tedious fight drags on, trying multiple strats just to get perma stunned by 5+ enemies. The wide variety of spells and weapon types means you have to adjust based on the enemy, with some damage types healing them, (my best weapons healed the final boss, that was fun).

Locales/Vibes- locations looked great, it felt like an adventure, from simple beaches (how original lol) to ancient caves and tombs to spirit realms & even to the ends of time. In the same vein some locations were terrible, like the Luculla Sandstorm,  nothing was fun about making a conga line with my party to pull the enemy, spending 20 minutes to beat a enemy then running away to escape combat and teleport away just to rinse and repeat. 
There are traps and secrets hidden in the world, things like hidden grave to lava traps.

Puzzles, some felt fun and rewarding, while the majority were just annoying and killed the pace and fun of the game, You'll need to be used to separating your party and multi-tasking with them, along with reading everything ever. Or needing very "specific" weights needed on weight plates. Many of them feel like they're trying to be overly clever and are doing too much imo. 

This is the kind of game where you need to interact and talk with everyone and everything, which takes forever. Even then you'll still miss things and interactions. If only I realized my choices in events that gave my character points in their personality things like "vindictive, pragmatic, romantic" etc actually affected my character stats and potential dialogue options that could lock you out of things. Along with knowing what items can actually be dragged onto others to work.

To me, this game would make one do new runs over and over to fix their mistakes if they get softlocked. So yeah you could respec everything except personality points from dialog and benefits/detriments, but what if you lose your skills? So what if i can buy them again or craft them again except the skills for my Knight and ranger? Ones that can't be gotten again? I committed to my build and mistake and suffered for it. Some skills felt useless and were a waste of precious talent points. My rogue had near max stealth skill, and I was still getting discovered, so I just used his "Make Invisible" skill which actually worked and was 1000x better.

Quick Side note, Don't sell Tenebrium items to merchants, I then had to deal with dying merchants for the rest of the game, I kept alive with my mage spamming Rejuvenates.

An annoyance to me was near the end game, I couldn't progress past a door needing me to have Blood stone/Star Stones, story/lore items that also double as "full party heals" basically omega tier heals. It said I didn't have enough but I already went everywhere I could ingame. So there I was backtracking the whole game searching high and low for these supposed stones. I found one, the only last one, but he still wouldn't open. How was I supposed to know I needed to use my rare healing stones? Then after that go to my homebase to talk to some merchants for the door to then open saying I was then worthy.

While I did enjoy my time with this game, those moments were here and there bogged down by slow moments, overtuned encounters, overly annoying puzzles, slow combat and general shenanigans one would expect from this style of game. Again I say to better enjoy the game, it'd take multiple runs/attempts. It'd be more fun for me now that I know how it plays out and how to spec better. I'd recommend it to people who like this type of game and difficulty, however to the casual RPG gamer who just wants to have easy fun without thinking, no stress kind of thing, this isn't for you.

Didnt like how the quest dialoque is written, feel like the character say a lot but end up say nothing. didnt like the fact this is linear game but masked like open world, the enemies not respawning so you just following straight line, meaning have to planning before-hand, putting wrong skillpoint will doomed your whole playthrough, so combat is your only playstyle, cant go rogue cant do rp, because end boss always hard. with a game that farming is not possible due to enemies not respawning, then doing RP is pointless, why even put trait/karma system in linear game? interesting rpg but i prefer divinity original sin 2. original sin is a very fleshed out and self contained story, but I didn't feel like that story ever did enough to capture or hold my interest to finish it. the combat is pretty weak and if you look around at all, you will quickly stumble on an encounter that is impossible at your current level. it feels less like "dont go there" and more like "dont go anywhere," and you wont. So get this, its a roleplaying game that gives you the choice between being good or bad with lockpicking skills, smokescreens, a sneaking and stealing system, but if you decide to roleplay an evil and resourceful character, then you may use your shovel on the first "suspicious mound" you come across. Youre even encouraged by some intriguing descriptions of soiling a fresh grave and a +heartless indicator over your heads. When suddenly BOOM PARTY WIPE NO YOU DONT GET TO ROLEPLAY IN THIS ROLEPLAY GAME, gravedigging big bad crime and lovely developers are going to add the option to what, make you deal with their shitty autosave as punishment? Oh, which in case you didnt know, the autosave doesnt activate after extensive menu juggling so if you just explored half a city, completed a quest, and spent an HOUR JUST FIDDLING WITH THE CRAFTING SYSTEM, congrats, THAT HOUR WAS WASTED because you couldnt remember which FUNCTION BUTTON the quicksave was bound to and figured the game wouldnt have a nonfunctional autosave system in place- WRONG AGAIN FUCKO. Feels like playing dnd with a dm that will happily wipe the whole party because he doesnt like that the characters did an "evil" action or refreshes the browser so the combat data is lost because you landed a crit on his cool new bad guy or spent too long minmaxxing HIS OWN GAME. IM GOING TO FINISH THIS GAME AS EVIL AS POSSIBLE NOW OUT OF SPITE. You wanted to show me an experience but what you did was took my money and spat in my mouth and instead of thanking you IM GOING TO GO FUCKING FERAL. ALSO IM REBINDING AUTOSAVE TO MIDDLE MOUSE BUTTON

Great game ruined by the ending.  Came back to this after never having completed it before.  Recurring theme with Larian games is amazing story and mechanics, but absolutely awful initiation in fights.  You either need to always sweat position for them or you have an unavoidable rigged fight.  Ending sequence involves a multistage fight where not once, but twice you are forced to have your characters amassed like idiots close together.  Can't really pregame potions with the no pause setup, summons despawn before  battle.  Stacking initiative is kind of pointless as it forces a start rotation.  This isn't highest difficulty, this is forced nonsense that removes all strategy.  All of your characters are force pulled in so that you can't hedge against the eventual fight.  The two different sides of enemies ignore each other to attack me exclusively.  I have absolutely no idea what the developers were expecting you to do here other than play one exact specific way cheesing certain stats, which is extremely boring.  Feel like I wasted my time on this playthrough, unless I use cheats to just skip to the story conclusion. 

9/10, just salting that the end fight is so poorly designed.

Divinity: Original Sin 2 is one of those games that remind you why you fell in love with RPGs in the first place.
The humor? Chef's kiss.
The characters? Absolute chaos goblins with personality.
The graphics? Weirdly gorgeous for a game thatâ€™s not exactly new anymore. Honestly, half the time I forgot this thing came out years ago, because everything looks like it has been polished by a team of very dedicated fantasy elves.

And the classes? Amazing. You can basically create anything from a teleporting rogue assassin who politely stabs people in the faceâ€¦ to a necromantic violinist who heals by bleeding on things. Truly art.

But thenâ€¦ Source Points happen.

Ah, yes. Source Points. The magical energy that fuels your strongest abilities, your coolest spells, is needed to acomplish dungeons/quests, andâ€”apparentlyâ€”your greatest frustration in life.

Itâ€™s not that the game limits you on them. That would actually be interesting, right? Making tough choices, thinking strategically, feeling the weight of your decisions?

Nope.
Divinity says: â€œYou can refill them endlessly, dear player!â€
And then quietly adds:
â€œâ€¦Just run back and forth like a lost chicken to do it.â€

Why?
Why give me infinite refillsâ€¦ but only if I prove my dedication by jogging across Rivellon like Iâ€™m training for a marathon?
Why ruin the pacing of such a brilliant game with a mechanic that feels like an unpaid internship?

Instead of epic adventure, I get Source Point Fetch Quest Simulator 2017.

And thatâ€™s when my enthusiasm died a dramatic, theatrical death. Not by combat. Not by a boss. But by pure, uncut inconvenience. Itâ€™s like the game whispered:
"You like fun? Too bad. Go touch another puddle of ghost juice, peasant."

So, Divinity: Original Sin 2 is still an incredible game with unforgettable humor, beautiful visuals, and rich gameplay.
But Source Points?
Yeah, no. Hard pass. When a mechanic makes me feel like Iâ€™m clocking in for my shift, I put down the controller and walk away.

Final Verdict:
A masterpiece held hostage by a mechanic that thinks I have the free time of a bored god. If Larian ever patches Source Points into something less annoying, Iâ€™m back in. Until thenâ€¦ Rivellon, itâ€™s not you. Itâ€™s your weird energy system.
